componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Sysco reports second quarter fiscal 2016 earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melissa. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Second Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chie
componenttext:
Thanks, Melissa. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Second Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer. We welcome Tom to our quarterly calls and look forward to his comments in just a few minutes. 
Before we begin, please note that statements made during this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements, and actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information about factors that could cause results to differ from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings. This includes, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 27, 2015, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. The reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the applicable GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation slides and can also be found in the Investors section of our website. All comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted. [Operator Instructions] 
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported a strong second quarter and a solid first half of the year. These results reflect the continuously improving execution of our portfolio of strategic initiatives by all of our associ
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported a strong second quarter and a solid first half of the year. These results reflect the continuously improving execution of our portfolio of strategic initiatives by all of our associates. Further, our favorable performance over the past several quarters validates that our ongoing focus on improving our customer's experience with Sysco and increasing productivity in all aspects of our business are key to our future success. 
From an overall economic and industry perspective, calendar year fourth quarter U.S. fee and consumer confidence data was mixed as favorable unemployment trends and lower gas prices somewhat offset increased concern about near-term business conditions and global uncertainty. Most recently, the precipitous drop in multiple stock market indices bears watching as it relates to potential adverse ramifications for consumers and our customers. 
As far as the restaurant industry data is concerned, the overall trend remained reasonably positive amid sluggish consumer spending. According to the National Restaurant Association, December marked the 11th consecutive month of food service sales growth. This closes out a strong year for the industry where food service sales exceeded grocery store sales throughout the year. That said, both MPD and Knapp-Track have shown some resent modest declines in traffic trends that we are closely monitoring. 
With respect to product cost deflation, we saw an acceleration during the second quarter, driven by key center-of-the-plate categories such as meat, poultry and pork as well as dairy. This trend has continued into the third quarter. And we currently believe that deflation headwinds will persist for at least the remainder of the fiscal year.
Now moving to our second quarter results. Total Broadline cases grew 3.4% and local cases grew 2.9%. Sales were up 0.6% despite being adversely impacted by both deflation of 1.2% and foreign exchange headwinds of 1.7%. Gross profit dollars grew 3.4% and gross margin increased 50 basis points. Adjusted operating income for the quarter grew $41 million or 10% compared to the prior year. Adjusted earnings per share grew 17%. And importantly, we had solid execution across the business, including U.S. Broadline. 
Reflecting on the first half of our fiscal 2016 performance, overall, our team executed well, and we are making good progress towards the achievement of our key financial objectives by focusing on the following 4 key levers: accelerating local case growth, improving gross margin, leveraging supply chain cost and reducing administrative cost. 
Specifically, we achieved the following during the first half of the year. Total Broadline local cases grew 2.8%. We grew gross profit by $121 million, expanded gross margin by 36 basis points and grew gross profit modestly faster than expenses. We grew adjusted operating income 4% or $38 million, and we grew adjusted earnings per share 7.5%.
As we enter the second half of our fiscal year, we have strong momentum in the business. We do, however, need to continue effectively manage the persistent deflationary headwinds that likely will challenge our performance going forward. Further, we are aggressively reviewing all aspects of our business for incremental cost savings opportunities to improve our financial performance. 
At our Investor Day presentation last September, we laid out 3 key results that our 3-year strategic plan is targeting through 2018: improve our customer's experience at Sysco, enhance associated engagement and achieve our financial objectives of increasing operating income by at least $400 million, growing earnings per share faster than operating income and achieving a 15% return on invested capital. I remain confident that we are well positioned to achieve those goals and now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I'm glad to be joining the call this morning with all of you. In my new role, I'm excited to bring our business operations, commercial functions and supply chain organizations together to drive improved executi
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. I'm glad to be joining the call this morning with all of you. In my new role, I'm excited to bring our business operations, commercial functions and supply chain organizations together to drive improved execution and a seamless approach to serving our customers. This approach will better position Sysco to provide exceptional service and support to our customers and ultimately, improve our returns to our shareholders. 
I'd like to begin my remarks regarding the second quarter by providing an update on some of the initiatives related to our 3-year plan and how they've already begun to have an impact on our business results. As we have mentioned before, our insights-based approach to understanding and meeting our customers' needs continues to guide our efforts. Our improved processes and tools in this area are allowing us to leverage our very robust base of information to design a variety of initiative to improve the retention and penetration of our current customers as well as to accelerate the addition of new customers.
And while we have much work still to do, we're beginning to see positive results. For example, during the second quarter, our U.S. Broadline operations delivered case growth of 3.9%, including local case growth of 3%; gross profit dollar growth of 5.5%, including an improvement margin of 57 basis points; and operating income growth of about 9%, supported by solid operating expense performance.
From a geographic perspective, we saw solid year-over-year improvement in both cases and gross margin across the U.S., with specific strength in the Mideast, Southeast and the Pacific markets. This was somewhat offset by signs of growth slowing in our traditionally strong southwest market due to the impact of the downturn in the energy sector. 
One example how we are driving increased case growth is in the area of fresh and local products, where we're helping to educate our customers that we have significant capability to our Broadline operations and our specialty companies to bring fresh and local produce to the market. As an example of how we differentiate ourselves in this segment in order to grow cases, our Sysco quality assurance team has partnered with the Produce Marketing Association to deliver good agricultural practices workshops to more than 800 small farmers since 2011, helping prepare our small local growers to meet our food safety standards.
As you know, improving gross margin is one of the key drivers of Sysco achieving our 3-year target, and our strong performance this quarter indicates we are making progress toward achieving our long-term objectives. To that point, I am pleased with how well we have managed the current deflationary environment, which has certainly slowed sales dollar growth. 
Our ability to manage this environment well is due in part to an increased focus on Sysco Brand and our category management efforts where we are able to use our purchasing scale, along with a more transparent process with our supplier partners to achieve our goals. We continue to see a variety of benefits for our customers, suppliers and Sysco as category management has become a standard part of how we now operate our business.
There are other areas that we know are improving our overall customers' experience of doing business with Sysco as well, including the way we're improving the service and support they're experiencing through our technology solutions. 
Our mobile order entry platforms, which has been piloted with customers for the past few quarters, has shown strong adoption rate with both customers and our marketing associates. Now that the pilots have been completed, we are in the process of fully deploying this ordering solution across the enterprise. Additionally, we soon expect to begin pilots for the next phase of our digital e-commerce platform, which will bring additional capability, tools and information critical to our customers to help them better run their business.
Finally, from a supply chain perspective, we have made solid progress toward our goal to improve overall service to our customers while driving higher productivity in our operations through our continuous improvement process. As mentioned earlier, while there's still a lot more work to be done, we are seeing improved operating expense trends, and we are targeting continuation of this performance throughout the balance of the fiscal year.
There are just a few -- these are just a few of the key priorities that are starting to impact our operational and financial results. And while we have much work to do, I'm confident we're on the right path to achieve our long-term objectives. 
In summary, our customer and operational strategies are being executed well in the field, and our headquarters teams are doing a terrific job of providing our organization with field-ready tools and processes that are enabling our success. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. We had a strong second quarter, especially in light of the increased deflation and continued currency headwinds. We also continued to make some solid early progress towards our fiscal 2016 plan and our 3-year go
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. We had a strong second quarter, especially in light of the increased deflation and continued currency headwinds. We also continued to make some solid early progress towards our fiscal 2016 plan and our 3-year goals.
We grew sales in the second quarter by approximately 1% year-over-year, despite going from inflation of 6% in the second quarter of last year to deflation of 1% this year, including deflation of nearly 2% in U.S. Broadline. We saw continued deflation in center-of-the-plate protein categories as supply recovers from various events in 2015. However, as Tom mentioned, we are managing this environment well, including improved processes and programs such as category management that have helped to lessen the impact of deflation.
Foreign exchange negatively impacted sales by 1.7%, with the U.S. dollar strength against the Canadian dollar responsible for the vast majority of the impact. On a constant currency basis, sales would have been up 2.2%.
Turning to case growth. Consistent with our 3-year plan to achieve disciplined case growth, we had another quarter of strong performance. Total Broadline case growth for the second quarter was 3.4% and local was 2.9%. This is the seventh consecutive quarter of year-over-year local case growth for the total Broadline.
Looking at gross profit and gross margins. We grew our gross profit at a solid 3.4% while also continuing to see expansion in gross margins, which grew by 50 basis points. The key drivers of gross margin improvement includes category management, a more beneficial mix of local business, higher [indiscernible] brand penetration in our local business and deflation. On a constant currency basis, gross profit growth was 5%.
Adjusted operating expenses grew 1.8% during the quarter and by 3.5% [ph] on a constant currency basis. The increase is mainly driven by the previously mentioned higher case volumes and planned investments in business technology. This increase in expense is partially offset by various decreases, including reducing indirect spend, reduced fuel costs and foreign exchange translation. This progress is reflected in our cost per case in U.S. Broadline, which is down $0.01 from the prior year.
Also note, while we experienced a relatively minor amount of certain items related to restructuring during the second quarter, we do expect to experience additional restructuring charges related to our 3-year plan over the next few quarters. 
As you know, a key part of our plan is to effectively manage the gap between gross profit dollar growth and expense growth. We achieved that objective during the second quarter, and as a result, grew adjusted operating income by 10.2% compared to the prior year and 11.6% on a constant currency basis. 
As it relates to taxes, at mid-January at an investor conference, we disclosed a $21 million benefit to income tax expense as a result of the favorable resolution of some international tax contingencies. This had the same impact on both our GAAP and adjusted tax rates, reducing both to around 31%. As a result and as mentioned during that webcast, we recorded a $0.03 benefit to earnings per share during the second quarter.
Compared to the prior year, adjusted net earnings grew 12.6% and adjusted earnings per share grew 17.1% and 19.5% on a constant currency basis due to higher operating income and reduced tax rates. A previously mentioned tax benefit increased earnings per share by $0.03. The share count decrease of 24.5 million shares related to the accelerated share repurchase program positively impacted earnings per share in the second quarter by approximately $0.02 versus the prior year. 
At the beginning of the second quarter, we executed the accelerated share repurchase program and therefore received the benefit from that repurchase for the entire quarter. Also note that we resumed our ongoing practice of buying back shares to offset dilution during the last few weeks of December. 
Cash flow from operations was $469 million for the first 26 weeks of fiscal 2016, up roughly 4% from last year. Working capital was a use of cash during the first 26 weeks of fiscal 2016 as it was during the first 26 weeks of fiscal 2015. The first half of the fiscal year typically requires a seasonal net investment in working capital that has been reduced during the second half of the fiscal year. Year-over-year, the comparison is favorable as we invested $143 million less cash in working capital during the first half of fiscal 2016 than we did in the first half of fiscal 2015. Net CapEx for the first 26 weeks was $237 million and free cash flow was $231 million.
Both cash flow from operations and free cash flow include the cash impact of certain items of $264 million in fiscal 2016 and $102 million in fiscal 2015. The certain items for 2016 are mostly related to the termination of the proposed merger with US Foods and from 2015 include items related to the proposed merger itself. Excluding the cash impact of certain items from both years, cash flow from operations grew by $179 million and free cash flow grew $237 million.
Now I would like to close with some commentary on the remainder of the fiscal year. First, we are on track to achieve our fiscal 2016 plan. Second, we expect deflation to persist for at least the remainder of the fiscal year. Third, we had a relatively strong fourth quarter last year, which will make fourth quarter comparison this year more challenging. Fourth, we now expect CapEx to be near the lower end of the previously stated $550 million to $600 million range. Finally, we expect a normalized tax rate of 36% to 37% over the remaining 26 weeks. 
In summary, we had a strong quarter, led by continued momentum from improved underlying business performance. That said, we have more work to do in order to achieve our fiscal 2016 financial objectives and our 3-year plan, including effectively managing deflation over the near term and increasing our focus on expenses. 
We continue to aggressively review every part of the company, looking for ways to reduce costs. Additionally, we have put in place a more rigorous process for managing expenses, including how we prioritize spending and focus investment on areas of projects that improve our ability to serve the customer better. And finally, we took advantage of continued lower fuel prices to increase the amount of fuel we locked in over the next 12 months.
I feel good about our ability to achieve the first year target of our 3-year plan, and we're working hard to be as aggressive as possible in identify incremental opportunities to exceed our Investor Day targets. Operator, we are now ready for Q&A.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So question on local cases. With local cases up about 3% in the quarter, I'm hoping you can provide some color here in terms of new customer growth versus higher share of wallet for existing customers. And over time, do you think you can grow local cases
componenttext: So question on local cases. With local cases up about 3% in the quarter, I'm hoping you can provide some color here in terms of new customer growth versus higher share of wallet for existing customers. And over time, do you think you can grow local cases in excess of the market rate?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Bill. I'll start and let Tom kind of give you some color from his perspective. We've historically been able to take share year in and year out, and we do that both on the local side of the business as well as the corporate side of the business. So ye
componenttext: It's Bill. I'll start and let Tom kind of give you some color from his perspective. We've historically been able to take share year in and year out, and we do that both on the local side of the business as well as the corporate side of the business. So yes, I would expect we will continue to take share. Obviously, what Joel referred to in his comments is we're trying to do that in a more disciplined way as we go forward here so that we give more of flow-through to the bottom line. The way I look at the local case growth is I talked about the lever of accelerating local case growth. The context there is we've had, I think, 7 quarters in a row now of local case growth, and the last few have been around 2% or more. So that lever is relative to where we were the last 2 or 3, 4 years as we were going through a lot of our change and some pretty tough macroeconomics. So that 2% to 3% range, I think, is what we're targeting. I think there's going to be some quarters where we're at the lower end of that range, somewhere at the higher end of the range. I think 2% or 3% is very solid growth if you look at what the forecasts are for the industry. But I'll let Tom speak to generally where it's coming from.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. I would just add we are seeing strong trends in restaurant traffic and restaurant sales so that's certainly helping, but really focused on promotional activity that actually drives new business. And also if you think about some of the too
componenttext: Thank you, Bill. I would just add we are seeing strong trends in restaurant traffic and restaurant sales so that's certainly helping, but really focused on promotional activity that actually drives new business. And also if you think about some of the tools we shared at the Investor Day around how we improve our penetration, we are seeing improved penetration with our local customers, driven primarily by some of those initiatives, whether it's some of the local products I'm talking -- I've been talking about, some of the innovation we've launched or even some of the additional services that we're providing those local customers. So we see good performance coming out of them from a variety of areas and believe we'll continue to see that kind of growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just you had discussed a more rigorous process towards expense management. Joel, I'm hoping you can elaborate a little more on this in terms of potential focus areas and whether this would be above and beyond what you laid out at Investor Day.
componenttext: Great. And just you had discussed a more rigorous process towards expense management. Joel, I'm hoping you can elaborate a little more on this in terms of potential focus areas and whether this would be above and beyond what you laid out at Investor Day.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. Number one, the way I think about those types of costs, and I think we've talked about this at other places, we think about it from the standpoint of processes, from people, from technologies, from the types of inves
componenttext: Sure. So a couple of comments on that. Number one, the way I think about those types of costs, and I think we've talked about this at other places, we think about it from the standpoint of processes, from people, from technologies, from the types of investments that we put into our company again in terms of how we think about prioritizing items. So in other words, one of the key things I called out in here is the ability to really prioritize and then focus on those spends that are going to drive the again, ultimately what's better for our customers. And so I think the -- some of the things that we've put in place, for example, are different committees to review and focus on technology spend, for example, in ways to have again a very tight process and making sure that we're focused in those projects that drive the best results primarily and focused on the customers. So I would say -- I mean, again, there's a lot of rigor around that. And in terms of your second part of your question, all I could really say to that, I think, is that we certainly will continue to focus on driving that, certainly with the deflation we're experiencing and the fact that our gross profit dollars are harder to come by. That increased focus on expenses is important. And so I can as I mentioned in, I think, in my script, that's certainly an area we're going to continue to focus on and certainly look to drive incremental improvements over and above our targets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if I could just add there, Zach, to Joel's comments, maybe a little more of a historical perspective. I mean, this company's always managed expenses very well, both operationally and corporate. Now over the last 3, 4, 5 years, we've invested
componenttext: Yes. I think if I could just add there, Zach, to Joel's comments, maybe a little more of a historical perspective. I mean, this company's always managed expenses very well, both operationally and corporate. Now over the last 3, 4, 5 years, we've invested a lot in particular on the corporate side, technology, processes, as Joel mentioned, commercial activities beginning to supply chain. So while those investments have been made over the last several years to create this path to transformation that we feel the company needs to go through, in which we're pretty far down the road on. What you're seeing today and what you've seen the last few quarters is we're beginning to get the benefits of a lot of those investments. So I would expect that the trajectory in that expense as a happens will flatten out. To Joel's point, we'll continue to get better and better at sequencing and prioritizing spend relative to customer needs and relative to what we need to deliver for our shareholders. And I'd say the one last opportunity we have particularly in the field is to be just more consistent in our execution, and we still see plenty of opportunity there. So again, historically, we've done a good job. What we're really telling here is we think there's opportunity both operationally as well as on the corporate side.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow-up on, I think there was a comment on deflation, making gross profit dollars a little bit harder to come by, but it was also a gross margin benefit from a rate standpoint. Can you just elaborate on how deflation impacted the P&L as t
componenttext: I guess just a follow-up on, I think there was a comment on deflation, making gross profit dollars a little bit harder to come by, but it was also a gross margin benefit from a rate standpoint. Can you just elaborate on how deflation impacted the P&L as the quarter progressed? And if it's going to continue, do you anticipate any change in the way it impacts the business?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, deflation impacts the P&L. I don't know that there was a big sequential impact and a lot of variability or on the sequential impact as the quarter progressed. But what we're saying is we saw a pickup from the first quarter to the second quarter. We'
componenttext: Well, deflation impacts the P&L. I don't know that there was a big sequential impact and a lot of variability or on the sequential impact as the quarter progressed. But what we're saying is we saw a pickup from the first quarter to the second quarter. We're seeing some similar trends here in January, and we kind of felt mathematically that will begin -- we began to see this, if you'll recall, back in March and in the fourth quarter of last year's when the inflation fell. So we thought just from a perspective that we would see a little more -- a little less deflation as we got into the second half of the fiscal year. And I would say what we're telling you today is it's still there. And we probably will expect to see it at least through the end of the quarter. It affects you different ways obviously. On the positive side, generally when our costs go down, we're able to pass that along to our customers and that's good for them, especially as they're dealing with some of their labor challenges. Your percentages look better so certainly, it contributed to the gross margin expansion. But the reality is it's not a great environment because you end up with fewer dollars to pay your expenses with. So to Joel's other point, when you have this level of deflation, it just reinforces the importance of managing our expenses very tightly.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: On an Unrelated follow-up, I know there were some comments about e-commerce. Can you just remind us where the current penetration is it relates to sales and how you think about that as a driver of the business going forward?
componenttext: On an Unrelated follow-up, I know there were some comments about e-commerce. Can you just remind us where the current penetration is it relates to sales and how you think about that as a driver of the business going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So regarding the e-commerce work we've been doing, we've been very focused on mobility solution. So think about it as an online ordering tool where our customers can use an iPad-type device or their phone to order. We've seen -- we've been piloting t
componenttext: Yes. So regarding the e-commerce work we've been doing, we've been very focused on mobility solution. So think about it as an online ordering tool where our customers can use an iPad-type device or their phone to order. We've seen -- we've been piloting this across the last couple of quarters. We now are in most of our operating companies with at least some of the customers and some of our districts. And so we're going to be expanding it now the rest of the country and more of a full deployment. We continue to see improved usage of the tool, but I'd say today, we're still in the low probably 9%, 8%, 9% of the orders going through that process. But we're seeing it basically double-digit improvement each quarter as we roll this. So the feedback's been very positive both from our own associates who also use the tool and from our customers. So we believe we're well on our way to significant increases in adoption and ultimately, a lot more of the orders being placed in that -- using that tool.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Wolf with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back to the gross profits. So just sequentially, they grew better even as sales got worse because of accelerated deflation. So I've heard the explanations around mix and so forth, but at least from my view, it looks like the deflation is at least kind of
componenttext: Back to the gross profits. So just sequentially, they grew better even as sales got worse because of accelerated deflation. So I've heard the explanations around mix and so forth, but at least from my view, it looks like the deflation is at least kind of benign or I mean, I know it becomes a headwind. But is there some element of sticky pricing where inflation was increasing in the last 3 years, it's tough for distributors to pass that through all at once? And is there some element where, to some degree, it doesn't have to come down quite as fast or is -- do you think everybody's just chasing the business and passing it through right away?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andy, thank you. You covered a lot there. Look, I think as I said, I believe the deflation, as you look at gross margin, i.e. the percent of sales, is clearly helping. However, as we've said very consistently over the years, it's not an ideal environment
componenttext: Andy, thank you. You covered a lot there. Look, I think as I said, I believe the deflation, as you look at gross margin, i.e. the percent of sales, is clearly helping. However, as we've said very consistently over the years, it's not an ideal environment to be in. If you look at this business historically, our customers generally are able to pass along a couple of points of inflation to their consumers year in and year out and they generally do. So to one of your points, what you're seeing here a little bit is some of the recovery what we gave up when we were dealing with 5 to 6 points of inflation, you can only pass along so much of that so quickly, and it's only appropriate to pass along so much so quickly. So when you have some deflationary trends, mathematically, it helps you a little bit. Perhaps there are situations where you can bring your prices down a little slower, but ultimately, it's an incredibly competitive environment, so we are out to compete in that business everyday and we want to do right by our customers, so I wouldn't put a lot of weight on that. I just think we're doing a very good job managing it. I've seen different cycles of deflation here over the last -- I don't know how many years but a lot of years, and this is, by far and away, the best we've ever managed it. And I think it goes back to what Tom covered and I'll let him speak again. We are actively -- we've been working on several commercial initiatives here for the last 2, 3, 4 years, whether it's segmentation, back to basics, revenue management, category management. These are all things that are allowing us to be more laserlike in terms of how we work with our customers and bring more consistency to our pricing. There's more to do there but -- so I would just say I think we're actually managing it quite well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is we've talked about the impact of the category management efforts we've embarked on over the last few years. That continues to be a significant driver for us. And we've also shared with you all the importance of our Sysco Bran
componenttext: The only thing I would add is we've talked about the impact of the category management efforts we've embarked on over the last few years. That continues to be a significant driver for us. And we've also shared with you all the importance of our Sysco Brand growth, and we're very focused on that Sysco Brand because we know that not only it's a great quality product for our customers but obviously, there are margin benefits for Sysco as well. And so I think really that's just one additional thing I'd add if that helps.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't underestimate this mix. We don't have to grow the local faster than the corporate. I mean, I think corporate still grew a little bit faster than local this quarter. But we bring more value to those street customers. We're able to leverage
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't underestimate this mix. We don't have to grow the local faster than the corporate. I mean, I think corporate still grew a little bit faster than local this quarter. But we bring more value to those street customers. We're able to leverage our Sysco Brand offerings in a broader way with our local case growth. And so if you go back to Investor Day and some of our commentary there, that first lever of accelerating local case growth, and if we can keep it in that 2% to 3% range, that's a very powerful lever for the throughput -- flow-through, if you will, to the bottom line of the company.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just follow up briefly on the category management that seems to be driving profits nicely? I think earlier on, it was really focused for you guys on the -- on your vendors and some of the things you were doing there to bring down costs. It sounds li
componenttext: Can I just follow up briefly on the category management that seems to be driving profits nicely? I think earlier on, it was really focused for you guys on the -- on your vendors and some of the things you were doing there to bring down costs. It sounds like it's more focused now on getting it into the sales side of the business and bringing it to the restaurants. Am I hearing that right as well?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- so yes, if you go through and obviously doing all the hard work and heavy lifting around the categories, selecting the right products and the right partners to do business with. Now that we're deeply into that, we've been through all the cat
componenttext: Well, it's -- so yes, if you go through and obviously doing all the hard work and heavy lifting around the categories, selecting the right products and the right partners to do business with. Now that we're deeply into that, we've been through all the categories, the majority of them, now we're very much focused on optimizing what we have. So you've heard us talk about innovative products. We've had some innovation that have been out over the last couple of quarters now that are starting to drive some incremental benefit for our customers and obviously for us. We also started to do much longer-range planning with a lot of these supplier partners. So it's become more of the way we operate. And I guess based on that or because of that, we're seeing the kind of consistent year-over-year benefits, while maybe not as great as they were in the early days as we started it, we're still seeing consistent benefits from that work.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, can I just start with maybe a big picture question? So last quarter, you sort of walked us through how the underlying business was better than the bottom line results, right? And that was I think more around like corporate cost and stuff. This quart
componenttext: Bill, can I just start with maybe a big picture question? So last quarter, you sort of walked us through how the underlying business was better than the bottom line results, right? And that was I think more around like corporate cost and stuff. This quarter, you got, I don't know, it's like your strongest EBIT growth quarter in sort of recent memory despite deflation. You got case growth and better profit per case and lower expense per case all lining up. Do you feel that you've kind of reached that inflection point that you were hinting at last quarter? I guess what's the big picture takeaway from this quarter if there is one at this point?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit like we got a little bit more out of it this quarter than we did in the first quarter. I think when I talked about that first quarter, that's when we really talked more about U.S. Broadline than we had in the past. I wanted you and the o
componenttext: It's a little bit like we got a little bit more out of it this quarter than we did in the first quarter. I think when I talked about that first quarter, that's when we really talked more about U.S. Broadline than we had in the past. I wanted you and the other investors to understand the quality of the underlying quarter. I think part of what we're seeing, and we've done some work on this, is the trajectory of the corporate spend coming out of last year and coming out of the proposed merger that ultimately was terminated, we still had some -- and we still do. We still have some trajectory of our corporate in particular on the technology side, in particular some of the areas that Tom's speaking to the -- with the digital and mobile platform. So those comparisons were not quite as tough in the second quarter as they were in the first so our corporate expense increase was a little bit less acute. We've got a little more margin improvement as you can see on the gross margin side. Even though we did see more deflation. Perhaps that helped us a little bit in the short term, but we also managed, I think, a little bit better. And you saw better cost management, I think, operationally as well. We are right around that flat cost per piece. Fuel helped us a little bit there but -- so I just think every little bit better and I just think this quarter is somewhat more reflective of really the quality of the earnings that we've seen. Now look, what I would to -- encourage you to do is look at the first half I spoke to, and what I see there is I see 4% operating income with improving trends. And that's kind of how we're looking at it. So we think we're in a good place for the first year piece of our 3-year goal. Joel can speak to that, but I think we talked about hitting 20% to 30% of our goal here in the first year. And we've got more work to do to hit or exceed the rest of that goal, both as it relates to continuing to address the deflation, in particular, grow those cases locally the way we are and have been. But we've got some more work to do on the expense side as well and you've heard us allude to that here. So I wouldn't quite call it an inflection point, but I would call it a validation of what I talked about in the first quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a couple of quick follow-ups. One just on case growth. Do you think weather sort of helped case growth at all? And then a follow-up on deflation, the last period that we saw more meaningful deflation, profit per case was down. And it doesn'
componenttext: Okay. And just a couple of quick follow-ups. One just on case growth. Do you think weather sort of helped case growth at all? And then a follow-up on deflation, the last period that we saw more meaningful deflation, profit per case was down. And it doesn't sound -- like it sounds like this period, you think you can sort of manage through that without seeing it. And I just want to confirm that, that's how you're thinking about things.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think weather played out a large role. It's always hard for us to talk about good weather. December was relatively modest so it might helped a little bit. I would tell you as far as this quarter goes, we had -- we finally had winter. We headed in
componenttext: I don't think weather played out a large role. It's always hard for us to talk about good weather. December was relatively modest so it might helped a little bit. I would tell you as far as this quarter goes, we had -- we finally had winter. We headed in the Mid-Atlantic area here a couple of weeks ago so that's [indiscernible] us a little bit our last week of January, first week of February. But so far, nothing crazy on the weather side this quarter either. I just think -- I'll let the other guys chime in here. I think on the gross profit, look, deflation is a very challenging environment to manage in terms of growing your gross profit dollars, and I just think we're doing a better job there for the reasons that Tom's taking you through. But the reality is we grew it 3.4%, which is not 4%, to Joel's point, was better than that when you adjust for currency. So I just think a lot of these commercial initiatives that we've been talking about for the last 2 or 3, 4 years, there are different stages of development and maturation beginning to see the benefits of them. But it is definitely a challenging environment, and that's why we're just being a little bit cautious and our [indiscernible] as it relates to second half of the year. Joel, you want to add anything?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I would just add to that in terms of the way we think about that is again Bill said it, the headwind is there, but the combination of solid volume growth and some of the margin expansion that cause us, coming from some of the initiativ
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I would just add to that in terms of the way we think about that is again Bill said it, the headwind is there, but the combination of solid volume growth and some of the margin expansion that cause us, coming from some of the initiatives that Tom's talked about, again, the category management, the brand. The brand within our local case growth, so in other words, we're growing our local cases and our brand or there that is growing, and so that's all positive. And so I think at the end of the day, again certainly obviously, we'd certainly love to take a little bit of inflation to [indiscernible] more that through. But I think those are the kind of the key levers that we think about as we combat inflation I think we've done a pretty good job of.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and we've talked a lot about local than we need to because I mean, that really is what's driving a lot of this along with the initiatives. But we also grew the corporate business this quarter as well, and we grew it in a profitable manner. So we actu
componenttext: Yes, and we've talked a lot about local than we need to because I mean, that really is what's driving a lot of this along with the initiatives. But we also grew the corporate business this quarter as well, and we grew it in a profitable manner. So we actually feel good about the overall quality of the case growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lots of questions on gross margin but was just curious. The factors that you called out category management, local case growth, your private brand, deflation, is that order of magnitude the right way to think about it? I mean, do you kind of go item by it
componenttext: Lots of questions on gross margin but was just curious. The factors that you called out category management, local case growth, your private brand, deflation, is that order of magnitude the right way to think about it? I mean, do you kind of go item by item of those 4 factors and say here's kind of what the impact was? And just wondering if you're willing to share any more detail with us on those.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, just to be clear, is that the way we think about what?
componenttext: Kelly, just to be clear, is that the way we think about what?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The impact of those factors on gross margin: category management, the local case growth, the private label penetration and the deflation.
componenttext: The impact of those factors on gross margin: category management, the local case growth, the private label penetration and the deflation.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well again, just for no other reason, make me feel good. I think about gross margin but I also think even more about gross profit dollars. So we're trying to address both here. You pay your bills with the dollars. I think on your point on the margin,
componenttext: Yes. Well again, just for no other reason, make me feel good. I think about gross margin but I also think even more about gross profit dollars. So we're trying to address both here. You pay your bills with the dollars. I think on your point on the margin, certainly, deflation of this magnitude is meaningful. It's very -- it's impossible to quantify what that is, but we would be less than genuine if we didn't say that was contributing to some of the margin improvement. But I would quickly go to the other things we've talked about here today, which is the importance of local case growth. Again, it doesn't have to be faster than the corporate, it just needs to be significant. The importance of growing the brand, and that's easier to do when you're growing your local cases and the maturation of the category management work that we're doing, along with some of the work that Tom is continuing to develop here on revenue management. But I'll -- you could talk to 10 people or 100 people in Sysco and probably get a little bit different answer on that question, so I'll let Tom and Joel jump in here as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I think the question is really more on is the prioritization that the way we look at it. I think we look at all of them coming together. At the end of the day, just local customer, if we are meeting or exceeding their needs, we're going to get the
componenttext: Again, I think the question is really more on is the prioritization that the way we look at it. I think we look at all of them coming together. At the end of the day, just local customer, if we are meeting or exceeding their needs, we're going to get the kind of growth that's required there. And we're focused on a lot of initiatives that in fact help them be successful. And I know we said that a few times but I think what's important for you to take away is the more they're successful, and therefore, the more we're successful with them, that is a big lever on our business because of the -- what we bring to them and the percentage of their business that is, in fact, Sysco Brand and the way that we partner with them. So I think I would say they all come together, and that's what makes the impact that you're seeing. I don't know that it's so one necessarily higher than the other. It's really more about making them work together.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the other point that Joel's made, I will make it again is just obvious point, we've had some challenges here in the last few years but -- to keep the right spread, if you will, between the gross profit growth and the expense growth.
componenttext: And I think the other point that Joel's made, I will make it again is just obvious point, we've had some challenges here in the last few years but -- to keep the right spread, if you will, between the gross profit growth and the expense growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the other point I would continue to emphasize is as inflation goes up and down, as our gross profit dollars are driven by the things we've talked about, again, to the point Bill has made, one of the really strong focuses we have is to
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the other point I would continue to emphasize is as inflation goes up and down, as our gross profit dollars are driven by the things we've talked about, again, to the point Bill has made, one of the really strong focuses we have is to drive the gap between gross profit dollar growth of expense growth, which again certainly this quarter, we did a good job of because [indiscernible] we have more inflation or less inflation one way or the other, that spread is really important to us, which is why we're going to continue to keep driving certainly on the gross profit dollar growth but focus on the expenses as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then, I guess, what -- in terms of expense growth, what was the impact of technology spend this quarter on your expenses?
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then, I guess, what -- in terms of expense growth, what was the impact of technology spend this quarter on your expenses?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that we historically really got in that detail, Kelly. What I would tell you is we still have some expense growth here at the corporate side. It's planned and virtually all of it's in the technology side.
componenttext: I don't think that we historically really got in that detail, Kelly. What I would tell you is we still have some expense growth here at the corporate side. It's planned and virtually all of it's in the technology side.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just I don't know if this is something you'd be prepared to answer, but it would help just because if and when we do return to inflationary environment, it's just something to keep in mind in terms of puts and takes on the gross margin. So I guess the que
componenttext: Just I don't know if this is something you'd be prepared to answer, but it would help just because if and when we do return to inflationary environment, it's just something to keep in mind in terms of puts and takes on the gross margin. So I guess the question is what percent of your sales are priced at cost plus the percentage markup versus the cost plus fixed penny per case? Because obviously, I mean, fixed penny per case customer, you're going to be benefiting in a deflationary environment from a gross margin perspective.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Karen, good morning. I would just say that you can presume that when we talked about our corporate customers as large customers, those are all some type of a cost contract. Some are markups, some are margins, some of our lines are $0.01 [ph] dollar p
componenttext: Yes, Karen, good morning. I would just say that you can presume that when we talked about our corporate customers as large customers, those are all some type of a cost contract. Some are markups, some are margins, some of our lines are $0.01 [ph] dollar per piece, whatever, $1 [ph] per pound. And on the local side, a lot of that is priced by the MA. Some of that is contractual. But we have and we don't plan giving you a lot of detail on price customers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess just switching gears. Two questions. I guess, the first is what you've you cut back in terms of CapEx this year in terms of coming in at the low end of the range? And then the second question I had is just obviously your thoughts re
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just switching gears. Two questions. I guess, the first is what you've you cut back in terms of CapEx this year in terms of coming in at the low end of the range? And then the second question I had is just obviously your thoughts reacting to your strong results this morning. I'm just curious how you think about the remaining buyback in light of the fact that obviously [indiscernible] better entry point during the quarter than it is now.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first one clarify your question on the second one. The first part on the CapEx I don't know that I'd really think about it as something we're cutting back on. I think the way I would just say is we target our CapEx spend as not based on s
componenttext: So I'll take the first one clarify your question on the second one. The first part on the CapEx I don't know that I'd really think about it as something we're cutting back on. I think the way I would just say is we target our CapEx spend as not based on some fixed number that we need to achieve or not achieve, but it's really truly driven by the needs of the business. And so I think the way I would just think about that is that as we've kind of talked before, we have a pretty rigorous process in terms of identifying and prioritizing our capital spending needs. And I would just say it this way that the way we look at this required spend this year for what our business is needing just happens to fall near the lower end of that range. So again, I don't necessarily look at our target as something that we sort of we have to achieve or some number we have to get to. It's based on the needs of our business and the ability to flex as it relates to that. And then the second [indiscernible]

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a shot at the second one, Karen you clarify for us. First of all, it's nice to have a quarter beat so it's nice to see the stock reacting. Our experience is it'll take 2 or 3 days for things to kind of level out in terms of how investors see t
componenttext: Let me take a shot at the second one, Karen you clarify for us. First of all, it's nice to have a quarter beat so it's nice to see the stock reacting. Our experience is it'll take 2 or 3 days for things to kind of level out in terms of how investors see the quarter. We've announced our intention to -- we've done the $1.5 billion that needs to be sold as Joel said, and today, it would still be our intention to do the remainder of the program next year. So if things were to change, we'll let you know but right now, that's still our intention. I would just reiterate though, going back to the first part of your question, we're always looking to invest in our business and will continue to do that in a way that supports of the disciplined growth that we talked about. Must a growing dividend continuously to be very important and will continue to look for good solid strategic acquisitions. So we're looking at all 4 of those opportunities but sitting here today, 2 hours into this thing, I think we haven't changed any plans.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth with Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wonder if you can give us a little update on how things are going at SYGMA on improving profitability there. And just also just a little more detail on what you're talking about there for the fourth quarter comparisons, why fourth quarter's going to be a
componenttext: Wonder if you can give us a little update on how things are going at SYGMA on improving profitability there. And just also just a little more detail on what you're talking about there for the fourth quarter comparisons, why fourth quarter's going to be a difficult comparison for you.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll speak briefly and let Tom give you more color. SYGMA, as we've said, is in somewhat of a turnaround mode, and we are continuing to see some better trends there as it relates to the customer mix and the expense management, that kind of thing, I would
componenttext: I'll speak briefly and let Tom give you more color. SYGMA, as we've said, is in somewhat of a turnaround mode, and we are continuing to see some better trends there as it relates to the customer mix and the expense management, that kind of thing, I would tell you. There's plenty of work to go there, but we're encouraged with the beginning of some transit were saying, but we're not there yet. I'll let Tom take the rest of SYGMA and let Joel talk to you about the fourth quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'll add on SYGMA's we're very focused on specific customers and profitability as well as improving our operational excellence in that business. And so the combination of those 2 things is how we are going to improve and get this thing back
componenttext: The only thing I'll add on SYGMA's we're very focused on specific customers and profitability as well as improving our operational excellence in that business. And so the combination of those 2 things is how we are going to improve and get this thing back on track. We've had certainly, over the last year, some challenges regarding drivers and driver retention, which is something that we are -- we've come out of an much better place now than we were probably 6 months ago. But it really is those 2 areas, making sure we've got the right customer mix and also that we're operating at the highest levels.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Joel. And then on the question on the fourth quarter, I think the comment there really relates to the fact that last year in the fourth quarter, our adjusted operating income grew nearly 6%. And certainly, we picked up nearly $30 million of operating
componenttext: It's Joel. And then on the question on the fourth quarter, I think the comment there really relates to the fact that last year in the fourth quarter, our adjusted operating income grew nearly 6%. And certainly, we picked up nearly $30 million of operating income from the prior year. And so I think it's -- the comment was really focused around the -- again, I often talk about growth on top of growth. And certainly and as I mentioned in my part of the script, I said we certainly -- we're certainly feel very good about how we're looking towards achieving our '16 planned objectives. But again, it's really more of a call out of the fact that the fourth quarter last year, we had very strong performance, and that's where the comparatives are up against we're referring to.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Meredith Adler with Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sean on for Meredith. I have a question on lower commodity costs and to what extent that's maybe resulting in restaurants investing some of that into being more promotional versus them using it offset labor expense. You think some of the driver of
componenttext: This is Sean on for Meredith. I have a question on lower commodity costs and to what extent that's maybe resulting in restaurants investing some of that into being more promotional versus them using it offset labor expense. You think some of the driver of case growth to some extent?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would be hard for us to assess and probably not even appropriate. I think Tom sees more customers than I do by see a few and I think this labor cost thing is top of mind for them right now. I know it's been a subject of some recent industry meetings. An
componenttext: I would be hard for us to assess and probably not even appropriate. I think Tom sees more customers than I do by see a few and I think this labor cost thing is top of mind for them right now. I know it's been a subject of some recent industry meetings. And I think that's where it's helping them. But Tom, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really. I can't say there was a big theme around more promotional activity that I'm seeing. They have lots of concerns out there right now, not the least of which is the labor environment.
componenttext: Not really. I can't say there was a big theme around more promotional activity that I'm seeing. They have lots of concerns out there right now, not the least of which is the labor environment.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Makes sense. Another question I have too was just on the driver or maybe drivers of non-Broadline inflation, just because it seems like there was deflation at Broadline at about negative 1.9%, which is approximately 80% of the business. So I'm just
componenttext: Sure. Makes sense. Another question I have too was just on the driver or maybe drivers of non-Broadline inflation, just because it seems like there was deflation at Broadline at about negative 1.9%, which is approximately 80% of the business. So I'm just wondering what's kind of driving inflation the remainder of the business.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what you're saying really is the deflation at the U.S. Broadline is driving the deflation in some of our other businesses, Karen's question on cost SYGMA has more the cost per piece, that type of -- the type of pricing so that's not going to be im
componenttext: I think what you're saying really is the deflation at the U.S. Broadline is driving the deflation in some of our other businesses, Karen's question on cost SYGMA has more the cost per piece, that type of -- the type of pricing so that's not going to be impacted as much. Some of our other guest supply, different type a product together. So Canada not as much. So I think all were saying is the U.S. Broadline is 80% of our revenue stream, and that's where the bulk of the deflation is.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to circle back a second on deflation. Bill, you said earlier, I know that something to the effect of deflation, of course, remaining a headwind. You initially thought it might subside kind of in the back half of the year but still kind of there.
componenttext: Just want to circle back a second on deflation. Bill, you said earlier, I know that something to the effect of deflation, of course, remaining a headwind. You initially thought it might subside kind of in the back half of the year but still kind of there. So just to clarify, are you guys thinking for the next quarter or 2 that kind of very similar levels to what you are seeing today, which, I guess, is similar to the quarter that was just reported? Or do you think that it could get a bit more of a headwind before then moderating?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wish I knew. I think what we're signaling as we think it's going to be with us at least 1 quarter or 2 longer at least and almost 2 points in U.S. Broadline this past quarter. I don't know that's going to get a whole lot worse than that. We'll just
componenttext: Yes, I wish I knew. I think what we're signaling as we think it's going to be with us at least 1 quarter or 2 longer at least and almost 2 points in U.S. Broadline this past quarter. I don't know that's going to get a whole lot worse than that. We'll just have to see. But I think the real message, let me be as clear as I can be, I probably and talk to you 6 months ago I would have thought by the fourth quarter, we would have been back more than neutral, and that's really not our assessment right now. But I'm not necessarily say it's going to get worse. I'm just saying it's probably not going to get a little better for another quarter or 2.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. That's fair enough. And maybe just one quick follow-up. You mentioned about the private brands a couple of times, also some of the newer fresh mix. I'm just kind of any update either qualitatively or hopefully quantitatively current percent of
componenttext: Okay, okay. That's fair enough. And maybe just one quick follow-up. You mentioned about the private brands a couple of times, also some of the newer fresh mix. I'm just kind of any update either qualitatively or hopefully quantitatively current percent of the mix where you may see that going may be some new categories that are coming on board.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as long as we continue to grow the local cases and continue to even as we go through the second [indiscernible] a lot of our suppliers and we work more on innovation, that type of thing, that gives us an opportunity to partner with our suppl
componenttext: Well, I think as long as we continue to grow the local cases and continue to even as we go through the second [indiscernible] a lot of our suppliers and we work more on innovation, that type of thing, that gives us an opportunity to partner with our suppliers both certainly their brand but also ours. So it's hard to move a number but you'll see the from the earnings release in that we had a nice move this quarter. So I don't -- I'm not going to try to predict how much more if we go up but there's a high correlation between local case growth and brand movement and Tom could give some color on that as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes, the specific numbers, I think, were communicated for U.S. Broadline total U.S. Broadline, it was about 36.5% of the mix and for the local business was 43.5% and local it was up about 43 basis points. So we continue to see growth there. We believe it is a differentiator for us, and it's something that our customers also see value in, both price value, but I think also from a quality perspective. I think the other thing that Bill just mentioned we're doing more innovative work and as we do work with our supplier partners on Sysco Brand innovation, that's going to help continue to contribute to these numbers. And I think I mentioned in the first couple of quarters, we had 16 items that we launched basically, innovative items in the marketplace and these are all generally Sysco Brand items, not all of them but a lot of them are. And that will continue to be a focus for us going forward.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would maybe reiterate a few comments I made and then add a few points. Sysco Brand, if you think about Sysco Brand, it's of value for a couple of reasons. 1 generally the cost to our customers is a little less than some of the national brands, so the
componenttext: So I would maybe reiterate a few comments I made and then add a few points. Sysco Brand, if you think about Sysco Brand, it's of value for a couple of reasons. 1 generally the cost to our customers is a little less than some of the national brands, so there's a natural benefit for them. But more importantly, we're very focused on the quality of these items. And I mentioned innovation, so we're always looking to ensure that the Sysco Brand items are, in fact, not only value-added bring increased value to the customer but that they are also driving kind of the base business components that these customers need. So I'd say are getting everything we can? I think we feel pretty good about where we're at today. We feel like certainly, we're not out of runway, but I think the more we can continue to focus on quality products bringing innovation to those items and making sure that we keep them in front of our customers, we used -- I think we talked about it at Investor Day, the business review process that we use. It's a great way for us to actually do of our products allowing them to see Sysco Brand and compare that the something else they might be you seeing, and it's always been a lot of that time is to help those customers see the value that's there and the opportunity that they have to improve their overall profitability by using their brand.

componenttext: All right. And maybe for Bill, do you think about some bigger secular trends, right? So local brand, CatMan. But obviously if the top line is healthy, GP dollars could grow at a nice rate, maybe even higher than what you've targeted over the last 3. How do you think about that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm all for it. But it's a little early to make that call, I think, John. So I think your thinking always is logical. We're 6 months in to this 3-year plan. I would just reiterate some things we talked about at September. The overall industry I would say,
componenttext: I'm all for it. But it's a little early to make that call, I think, John. So I think your thinking always is logical. We're 6 months in to this 3-year plan. I would just reiterate some things we talked about at September. The overall industry I would say, the overall environment and the outlook for our customers is better today than it was 2 or 3 years ago. It goes up and down by quarter and you can actually see and some of the stuff in the stock market goes down [indiscernible] numbers fall off the next month or next quarter or so. But I think if you look at secularly and go back 2 or 3 years, we're in a better place so that's a positive. Still, an incredibly intricately competitive world out there, so we need to be very responsive to that. I would just echo what I'd been trying to articulate here over the last 2 or 3 years, but in particular, last several months post the merger termination. We're extremely well positioned today because of all the work that we've done over the last 2, 3, 4 years on the commercial side to compete effectively do the right thing at by our customers but also grow in a disciplined way is still talked about in our margins. So if you look at those 4 levers we're talking about improving how we manage it ideally at least hold margin over the next 2 or 3 years, right now, we're up. Hopefully, we will grow certain if you were much better positioned to manage it well than what we were 2, 3, 4 years ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, John. We're speaking really cost of fuel. It's a little harder, and we really don't get into that level of detail in terms of our components of our cost of goods. But let me say it this way. Lower fuel is good, okay? It's generally g
componenttext: It's a good question, John. We're speaking really cost of fuel. It's a little harder, and we really don't get into that level of detail in terms of our components of our cost of goods. But let me say it this way. Lower fuel is good, okay? It's generally good for multiple reasons. One, is it gets -- on the margin generally gives a more discretionary income than they'll spend it. Historically, spend it more [indiscernible] I will say this. We really haven't seen a lot of that and perhaps lately, and we don't have a lot of our data on that so the most powerful thing on the field is if you extend it translates to greater discretionary income and the consumer uses it to that's a good thing for us. Haven't seen quite as much of that but we're hopeful that we'll see more. But you're actually right it's helps us on the cost of goods and to Joel's point helps us on the outbound. We kind of we average in the outbound. So it's definitely a modest tailwind, and we're taking advantage of it and hopefully will stay that way.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been able to grow, as I said, historically take share for many years and certainly, we got the local case growth moving again over the last several quarters. We don't have the data for '15. My sense is we've probably have taken some share I th
componenttext: Well, we've been able to grow, as I said, historically take share for many years and certainly, we got the local case growth moving again over the last several quarters. We don't have the data for '15. My sense is we've probably have taken some share I think a lot of the larger multi-originals are doing well. And so if I were to conjecture here, which is a dangerous thing and calls like this, my sense is that some of the better operator larger folks are taking share and may be coming from some of the smaller players. But the bottom line think in this business is that operators are going to take share. Large, small, good restaurant operators are going to continue to grow and do well corporate owned. And so I think our overall point of view would be the competitive environment remains very acute, remains very similar to what we've seen the last 2 or 3 years and the best operators both in terms of the customer base as well as on the distribution side are going to do the best.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today.
