headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to touch on private brand and gross. When you think about the ability to use the private brand portfolio to drive share and I know there's a lot of things that you're offering to your customers, but just maybe isolate that one. How effective i
componenttext: So I wanted to touch on private brand and gross. When you think about the ability to use the private brand portfolio to drive share and I know there's a lot of things that you're offering to your customers, but just maybe isolate that one. How effective is -- can that be at bringing on new customers? And I guess, part of that is the inertia that they might have to the brands that they're using today. And do you think you're using those brands as effectively as you could? What -- are there things that can be done maybe a little bit differently to drive -- to use those brands to drive some increased share gains? I mean, any thoughts, particularly from Tom on that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would maybe reiterate a few comments I made and maybe add a few points. So the Sysco Brand, if you think about Sysco Brand, it's of value for a couple of reasons. One, generally the cost to our customers is a little less than some of the national bra
componenttext: So I would maybe reiterate a few comments I made and maybe add a few points. So the Sysco Brand, if you think about Sysco Brand, it's of value for a couple of reasons. One, generally the cost to our customers is a little less than some of the national brands, so there's a natural benefit for them. But more importantly, we're very focused on the quality of these items. And I mentioned innovation, so we're always looking to ensure that the Sysco Brand items are, in fact, not only value-added, meaning they bring increased value to the customer, but that they're also driving kind of the base business components that these customers need. So I'd say, are we getting everything we can? I think we feel pretty good about where we're at today. We feel like certainly, we're not out of runway, but I think the more we can continue to focus on quality products, bringing innovation to those items and making sure that we keep them in front of our customers, and we use -- I think we talked about at the Investor Day the business review process that we use. It's a great way for us to actually do cuttings of our products, allowing them to see Sysco Brand and compare to something else they might be using, and it's how we spend -- a lot of that time is to help those customers see the value that's there and the opportunity that they have to improve their overall profitability by using their brand.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Then maybe for Bill. If you think about some bigger secular trends, right? So local, private brand, CatMan. I mean, you would think and I know this isn't fully built into your plan, but you would think that there may be a good chance here for s
componenttext: All right. Then maybe for Bill. If you think about some bigger secular trends, right? So local, private brand, CatMan. I mean, you would think and I know this isn't fully built into your plan, but you would think that there may be a good chance here for secular gross margin rate to be up pretty consistently. But obviously if the top line is healthy, right, then the GP dollars could grow at a nice rate, maybe even higher than what you've targeted over the last 3. How do you think about that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm all for it. But it's a little early to make that call, I think, John. So I think your thinking is -- always is logical. We're 6 months in to this 3-year plan. I would just reiterate some things we talked about in September. The overall industry I woul
componenttext: I'm all for it. But it's a little early to make that call, I think, John. So I think your thinking is -- always is logical. We're 6 months in to this 3-year plan. I would just reiterate some things we talked about in September. The overall industry I would say, the overall environment and the outlook for our customers is better today than it was 2 or 3 years ago. Now it goes up and down by quarter, and you can actually see and some of the stuff when the stock market goes down, some of the NRA numbers fall off the next month or the next quarter so. But I think if you look at it secularly and go back 2 or 3 years, we're in a better place, so that's a positive. It's still an incredibly and acutely competitive world out there, so we need to be very responsive to that. And I would just echo what I've been trying to articulate here over the last 2 or 3 years, but in particular, the last several months post the merger termination: we're extremely well-positioned today because of all the work that we've done over the last 2, 3, 4 years on the commercial side to compete effectively, do the right thing by our customers but also grow in a disciplined way, as Joel talks about, and manage our margins. So if you look at those 4 levers, we're talking about improving how we manage it ideally, we'll at least hold margin over the next 2 or 3 years. Right now, we're up. Hopefully, we will grow it, but I certainly feel we're much better positioned to manage it well than where we were 2, 3, 4 years ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, just a quick one for me. A follow-up on the fuel question. I think you kind of have a cost of fuel that's both embedded in your cost of sales and your operating expenses, so correct me if I'm wrong about that. But my question was, your supp
componenttext: At this point, just a quick one for me. A follow-up on the fuel question. I think you kind of have a cost of fuel that's both embedded in your cost of sales and your operating expenses, so correct me if I'm wrong about that. But my question was, your suppliers that deliver food to you, how much fuel savings may be -- was embedded over the past couple of quarters and what you anticipate over the next couple of quarters, just that their delivery costs are less to you, and therefore, you are price of -- your price of product could be lower and that could actually be helping your cost of goods sold if you thought about it in that way.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a good question, John. What we're speaking to is really our outbound cost of fuel. It's a little harder, and we really don't get into that level of detail in terms of our components of our cost of goods. But let me say it this way. Lower fuel is
componenttext: Yes. It's a good question, John. What we're speaking to is really our outbound cost of fuel. It's a little harder, and we really don't get into that level of detail in terms of our components of our cost of goods. But let me say it this way. Lower fuel is good, okay? It's generally good for multiple reasons. One, is it gets -- on the margin generally, people. It gives them more discretionary income and they'll spend it -- historically, spend it more going out to eat. Now, I will say this. We really hadn't seen a lot of that until perhaps lately, and we don't have a lot of hard data on that, so the most powerful thing on the field is, if you extend it, it translates to greater discretionary income, and the consumer uses it to go out to eat. That's a good thing for us. Haven't seen quite as much of that, but we're hopeful that we'll see more. But then, you're absolutely right, it helps us on the cost of goods and to Joel's point, it helps us on the outbound. We kind of weight average the outbound. So it's definitely a modest tailwind, and we're taking advantage of it, and hopefully it will stay that way.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Greg Badishkanian.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Yes, just a quick one. You mentioned that the competitive environment or the environment is very competitive, and I'm just wondering, has that changed any over the last few months? Is it pretty similar? Because obviously, you picked up some share,
componenttext: Great. Yes, just a quick one. You mentioned that the competitive environment or the environment is very competitive, and I'm just wondering, has that changed any over the last few months? Is it pretty similar? Because obviously, you picked up some share, so I'm just wondering if you'd noticed any change there or if -- who you think you're taking market share from. Is it broad based or maybe there's a retail or more national players that you're taking that share from?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been able to grow, as I said, historically take share for many years, and certainly, we got the local case growth moving again here the last several quarters. We don't have the data for '15. My sense is we've probably have taken some share. I
componenttext: Well, we've been able to grow, as I said, historically take share for many years, and certainly, we got the local case growth moving again here the last several quarters. We don't have the data for '15. My sense is we've probably have taken some share. I think a lot of the larger multiregionals are doing well. And so if I were to conjecture, which is always a dangerous thing in calls like this, my sense is that some of the better operators, the larger folks are taking share and may be coming from some of the smaller players. But the bottom line, I think, in this business is good operators are going to take share. Large, small, good restaurant operators are going to continue to grow into well, whether they're independent or corporate owned. And so I think our overall point of view would be the competitive environment remains very acute, it remains very similar to what we've seen the last 2 or 3 years, and the best operators both in terms of the customer base as well as on the distribution side are going to do the best.
