componenttext: Good morning. My name is Christy, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Sysco Fourth Quarter Fiscal Year 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the call over to Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade,
componenttext:
Thank you, Christie. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made during this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, and actual results could differ in a material manner. 
Additional information about factors that could cause results to differ from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings. This includes, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 27, 2015, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. The reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the corresponding GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation slides and can also be found in the Investors section of our website. All comments about earnings per share refer to diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted. 
Please note that the financial results announced today include a 14th week for the fourth fiscal quarter and a 53rd week for the fiscal year 2016 ended July 2, 2016. In fiscal 2015, the fourth quarter included 13 weeks and the year included 52 weeks. As such, the results discussed on the call will include GAAP results and non-GAAP results adjusted for certain items.
We will also share the adjusted non-GAAP results on a comparable 13-week and 52-week basis to provide reasonable year-over-year comparisons. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported strong fourth quarter and fiscal year financial results. Our performance reflects the soundness of our strategy, the commitment of our associates to supporting the success of our cu
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone. This morning, Sysco reported strong fourth quarter and fiscal year financial results. Our performance reflects the soundness of our strategy, the commitment of our associates to supporting the success of our customers and the consistently improving execution of our 3-year plan. 
For the quarter, on a comparable 13-week basis, Sysco delivered sales growth of 2% and gross profit dollar growth of nearly 5% while limiting adjusted operating expense growth to less than 2%, which resulted in adjusted operating income growth of approximately 15% compared to the prior year. Adjusted earnings per share grew approximately 15% as well.
These results were achieved in a market environment that is experiencing uneven trends and appears to have softened somewhat of late. While consumer confidence and unemployment data points remain relatively favorable compared to a few years ago, the current sentiment for customer spending on meals away from home seems to be trending slightly downward.
Turning to specific restaurant industry data. Overall sales trends weakened as reflected in current NPD and KNAPP-TRACK traffic and spend data. That said, according to the National Restaurant Association, restaurant operator expectations remain somewhat favorable.
Moving to our results for fiscal 2016, I'm very pleased with our performance during the year. The improving momentum in our business is the result of strong local case growth, gross profit growth with gross margin expansion and solid expense management. Specifically, for fiscal 2016, on an adjusted 52-week basis, we delivered the following results: total Broadline cases grew 3% and local cases grew 2.7%. Sales grew 1.5% to $50 billion even with the unfavorable impact of deflation and foreign exchange headwinds. Gross profit grew 3.6% to $9 billion and gross margin increased 38 basis points. 
Adjusted operating income increased 10% over the prior year to $2 billion and adjusted earnings per share grew 12%. In addition, free cash flow approximated $1.4 billion and adjusted return on invested capital was 14% for the full year. I'm particularly encouraged by our progress to date toward the achievement of our 3-year planned financial objectives, especially our goal to grow adjusted operating income by at least $500 million from fiscal 2015 to fiscal 2018. Our strong progress towards the achievement of these financial objectives is supported by a foundation that was built over the past several years through a series of commercial, supply chain and administrative initiatives. 
We continue to build on that foundation throughout fiscal 2016 by accomplishing several key objectives, including: leveraging customer insights to create new and enhanced sales and marketing programs; advancing our progress in several key commercial areas, including category and revenue management; shifting our technology strategy and related spend to a more customer-centric focus; and restructuring our business to drive greater efficiency, including streamlining our market structure, introducing a standard field organization model and further developing a functional structure in key support areas such as merchandising, supply chain and human resources.
All of these has been accomplished by consistently improving the execution of our strategy that is centered on 5 fundamental points: partnership, to profoundly enrich the experience of doing business with Sysco; productivity, to continuously improve productivity in all areas of our business; products, to enhance offerings through our customer-centric innovation program; people, leveraging talent, structure and culture to drive performance; and portfolio, continuously assessing new market opportunities and current business performance.
Regarding the latter point, we recently closed the acquisitions of -- the acquisition of the Brakes Group, a $5 billion European food service distributor with significant presence in the United Kingdom, France and Sweden. Brakes is a highly regarded company whose management team and strategy are well aligned with the vision we have for Sysco: to be our customer's most valued and trusted business partner. 
This acquisition will serve as a platform for future expansion in Europe. We're looking forward to working together with the entire Brakes team to execute their business strategy, and we feel fortunate to welcome them into the Sysco family. Joel will discuss with you in a few minutes the anticipated contribution of Brakes to Sysco's financial results.
As we ended the new fiscal year, we are executing our strategy at a high level, working effectively together as One Sysco, and we remain committed to the success of our customers. We have even bigger goals for fiscal 2017, and I'm confident in our ability to achieve our financial and business objectives in the year ahead and throughout the 3-year plan.
The new fiscal year brings an expanded global presence, enhanced technology and continued focus on our customers. Specifically, we intend to deliver solid local case growth, increase our gross profit, reduce cost in the right way and put processing tools in place that will further enable our associates to provide our customers with industry-leading service and support.
Our past and future success is driven by the ongoing dedication and commitment of all of our associates, and I thank each of them for their effort to deliver a very successful year in fiscal 2016. And now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 was a great year for Sysco, and I'm proud of the contributions made by all of our associates throughout the year. Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect a year of solid operating p
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 was a great year for Sysco, and I'm proud of the contributions made by all of our associates throughout the year. Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect a year of solid operating performance and excellent progress on several key multiyear initiatives that have begun to provide a strong foundation for success. 
Our favorable operating performance was driven by our ongoing focus on the key drivers of our 3-year plan, including accelerating our sales with local customers by providing them with exceptional service, improving gross margins and managing overall expenses. This morning, I'll provide an update on some of the initiatives related to our 3-year plan and how they have continued to positively impact our business results.  
The first of which is our focus on accelerating local case growth. During the year, we grew U.S. Broadline local cases 2.6% on an adjusted 52-week basis, the strongest performance we've had in several years. Also on an adjusted 52-week basis, gross profit in U.S. Broadline grew 4.7% for the fiscal year and gross margin increased 47 basis points, driven by our focus on profitable case growth, revenue management activities and improved Sysco Brand penetration. 
The focus our sales team has had on helping our customers succeed and grow has been further enhanced throughout fiscal year 2016. During the year, we remain focused on improving our industry-leading category management practices, fully deploying revenue management in the field and enhancing our sales training and support tools that continue to free up our marketing associates' time to better support our customers with business building solutions. 
We also rolled out various promotional programs and key initiatives throughout the year, including those that highlight product innovation and reinforce the Sysco Brand, which delivers tremendous value to our customers. That value is delivered through an unrelenting focus on the highest-quality products and best-in-class traceability from a food safety perspective. Finally, we continue to focus on delivering new and improved customer-facing technology solutions that add value to their business and allow our associates to be more efficient.
On the cost side, the expense management throughout the year was also solid and remains a key area of focus moving forward. For U.S. Broadline, during fiscal year 2016, we limited total adjusted expense growth to only 2.2% on a comparable 52-week basis compared to gross profit growth of 4.7%. We also reduced our overall cost per case in U.S. Broadline by $0.04 during the year. Adjusting for the impact of fuel prices, our adjusted cost per case in U.S. Broadline was flat.
As we've discussed, we have been very focused on reducing cost and improving productivity while continuing to deliver improved service levels to our customers. In fiscal year 2016, we reduced expenses in a number of key areas. In the supply chain area, we have reduced indirect spend and we'll continue to focus on maximizing transportation and warehouse efficiencies. We've also standardized our organizational design and reduced the number of our markets in the U.S. from 8 to 6. And throughout the organization, we have reduced overall SG&A costs.
In summary, our customer and operational strategies are solidly aligned around improving our customers' experience, engaging our associates at the highest level to improve execution and delivering our financial objectives as a part of our 3-year plan. In fiscal year 2016, we've made significant progress in all areas, and I remain extremely optimistic about the programs and processes we are putting in place that will enable our future success.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. As Bill and Tom have mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the fourth quarter and the full year. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including strong mobile case
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone. As Bill and Tom have mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the fourth quarter and the full year. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including strong mobile case growth, solid gross profit dollar growth and good cost management. I'll begin my remarks by speaking to our fourth quarter.
For the purposes of matching your models, our fourth quarter results reflecting an extra week include: sales growth of 10.0%, gross profit growth of 12.7%, adjusted operating expense growth of 9.6%, adjusted operating income growth of 23.4% and adjusted earnings per share growth of 23.1%. 
Excluding the extra week on a comparable basis, the fourth quarter results include: sales growth of 2.2%, gross profit growth of 4.7%, adjusted operating expense growth of 1.7%, adjusted operating income growth of 14.6% and adjusted earnings per share growth of 15.4%. 
Sales during the quarter were negatively impacted by both deflation of 1.2% and foreign exchange of 0.5%, largely offset by an increase in sales from acquisitions of 1.2%. On a comparable 13-week basis, total Broadline case growth for the fourth quarter was 2.2%, local was 2.4% and corporate managed growth was 2.0%.
During the fourth quarter, we had some certain items that impacted our results. In the prior year, we had acquisition costs of $390 million. In the current year, we had remeasurements of foreign-denominated cash due to lower exchange rates at quarter end as well as the premium on foreign currency option contracts for the Brakes acquisition. As a result, other expense, net for the quarter, was approximately $141 million, primarily driven by certain items from fiscal 2016. 
As it relates to taxes, our effective tax rate in the fourth quarter was 35% compared to negative 6% in the prior year. Both quarters' tax rates were reduced primarily from the impact of certain items, which lowered net income and resulted in lower tax rates. A similar event occurred last year related to the US Foods termination cost, which drove an unusual GAAP tax rate. On an adjusted for certain items basis, our tax rate would have been approximately 36.8% in both years.
Now turning to our results for the year. Our fiscal 2016, including the extra week, included: sales growth of 3.5%, gross profit growth of 5.7%, adjusted operating expense growth of 4%, adjusted operating income growth of 12.1% and adjusted EPS growth of 14.1%. 
To provide a relevant comparison to the prior year, all income statement measures I discuss from this point forward will be adjusted for certain items and presented on a 52-week comparable basis. Looking at our full year results, we grew sales by 1.5% year-over-year despite deflation of 0.7%. We saw continued deflation in center of the plate protein categories such as meat and seafood, along with deflation in dairy. 
Sales from acquisitions increased sales by 0.7%. During the year, we closed 5 acquisitions, including Gilchrist & Soames and Northstar Seafood. Foreign exchange negatively impacted sales by 1.3%, largely driven by the U.S. dollar strength against the Canadian dollar. The negative impact we have been experiencing on a comparative basis is lessening as we begin to wrap the initial decline and relative value of the Canadian dollar. On a constant-currency basis, sales would have been up 2.7%.
Turning to case growth. Consistent with our 3-year plan to achieve disciplined case growth, we had strong performance for the year. On a comparable 52-week basis, total Broadline case growth for the year was 3%, local was 2.7% and corporate managed was 3.3%.
Looking at gross profit and gross margins for the year. We grew our gross profit at a solid 3.6% while also continuing to see expansion in gross margins, which grew by 38 basis points. The key drivers of gross margin improvement included category management of our beneficial mix of local business, higher Sysco Brand penetration in our local business and deflation. On a constant-currency basis, adjusted gross profit growth was 4.8%.
Adjusted operating expense on a comparable 52-week basis grew [ph] 2% for the year and by 3.3% on a constant-currency basis. This increase is mainly driven by the previously mentioned higher case volumes and incentive accruals and was partially offset by various decreases, including reducing indirect spending, reduced fuel costs and foreign exchange translation. This progress is reflected in our reduced cost per case, as Tom mentioned, which was flat, excluding fuel price changes.
As a result, adjusted operating income for the year was $1.96 billion, up 9.6% compared to the prior year and up 10.6% on a constant-currency basis. Compared to the prior year on a 52-week basis, adjusted net earnings grew 8% and adjusted earnings per share grew 12%. For the full year, cash flow from operations was $1.9 billion, up approximately 24% from last year. It is important to note that a timing difference in tax payments impacted our cash flow during fiscal 2016.
Net working capital improved by 6/10 of 1 day [ph] for the full year compared to last year. This was largely driven by improvements in inventory. Net CapEx for the full year was $504 million and free cash flow was $1.4 billion. Both cash flow from operations and free cash flow included the cash impact of certain items of $280 million in fiscal 2016. As a reminder, the certain items for 2016 are mostly related to termination of the proposed merger with US Foods. Lastly, we improved our adjusted return on invested capital to approximately 14% during the fiscal year, up from approximately 13% in the prior year. 
Now I'd like to close some commentary on the outlook for fiscal 2017. The deflationary trend has been persistent over the last 4 quarters and will likely continue for the remainder of the calendar year, creating a modest sales and gross profit headwind for the first half year. 
The restaurant environment appears to be softening, and as a result, we anticipate modest case volume growth for the next quarter or 2. Capital expenditures during fiscal 2017 are expected to be approximately 1% of sales, including Brakes. We intend to continue to improve working capital days to achieve our 3-year planned goal of 4 days improvement when comparing fiscal 2018 to fiscal 2015. And we expect to complete our $3 billion 2-year share repurchase program during fiscal 2017. We anticipate a benefit of approximately $0.03 to $0.04 to diluted EPS in fiscal 2017, driven by reduction in average shares outstanding.
Regarding the addition of Brakes to Sysco's financial results, we expect the combined company will have roughly $55 billion in annualized revenue on a pro forma basis. In their most recent fiscal year ending December of 2015, Brakes reported nearly $5 billion in revenue, up roughly approximately 6.5% from 2014. They also reported an approximately 5% adjusted EBITDA margin with a double-digit growth rate. 
Roughly 2/3 of their revenue comes from the United Kingdom where they have a leading share. We continue to believe this acquisition will be modestly accretive to adjusted earnings per share by lower to mid-single digits in fiscal 2017, with acceleration in fiscal 2018 and beyond. This acquisition is also expected to reduce our normalized effective tax rate to about 35% to 36%.
In summary, we had a strong quarter and year, reflecting continued momentum from our underlying business, including strong local case growth, solid gross profit dollar growth and good cost management. That said, we have more work to do in order to achieve the full financial objectives of our 3-year plan. We are committed to serving our customers and delivering a high level of execution in all areas of our business that will improve our financial performance in both the near and long term. I feel confident in our ability to continue to execute our plan.
Operator, we are now ready for Q&A.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about gross margins and how much of the expansion was driven by deflation and then how much was the result of other factors like increased private label penetration or category management, et cetera?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about gross margins and how much of the expansion was driven by deflation and then how much was the result of other factors like increased private label penetration or category management, et cetera?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Always a great question, a challenging one to answer that specifically. I think you will see some correlation over the last 4, 5 quarters where as we've seen some deflation, the margins have moved up. We were making good progress on relative margin trends
componenttext: Always a great question, a challenging one to answer that specifically. I think you will see some correlation over the last 4, 5 quarters where as we've seen some deflation, the margins have moved up. We were making good progress on relative margin trends before that. But I would tell you that we believe that a significant amount of the improvement is coming from a lot of these initiatives I referred to and that Tom spoke to in more detail along the lines of. Category management, revenue management, the work we're doing in segmentation, tools we're providing our sales force. So can't quantify exactly but these come from multiple sources.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the only thing I would add is you heard me talk about fully deploying revenue management. We're now at a place where we've got it within our entire organization. And so I think we continue to believe that, as Bill said, a combination of all those thi
componenttext: Yes, the only thing I would add is you heard me talk about fully deploying revenue management. We're now at a place where we've got it within our entire organization. And so I think we continue to believe that, as Bill said, a combination of all those things are allowing us to manage the difficult deflationary environment we've been in.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And then as a follow-up, you mentioned the uneven environment. I just wanted to see if you can comment further on restaurant industry trends and specifically what you're seeing from both your independent customers and your chain cu
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And then as a follow-up, you mentioned the uneven environment. I just wanted to see if you can comment further on restaurant industry trends and specifically what you're seeing from both your independent customers and your chain customers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not just what we're seeing. I think it's what we're hearing from other folks that are speaking to their results, both in the operator side and some of our peers in the industry. So I think it's just a little bit softer. I think the good news here, pe
componenttext: It's not just what we're seeing. I think it's what we're hearing from other folks that are speaking to their results, both in the operator side and some of our peers in the industry. So I think it's just a little bit softer. I think the good news here, people are still relatively optimistic, both consumer confidence, in general, and the restaurant operators, when you look at those indices and compare them over the last couple of years. Generally, the outlook is favorable. But we're just seeing some softening in terms of the slope of the growth. And specifically, we're seeing it in traffic continue to be flat and check size often some segments flat and other segments. So it's no one place. It's a relative comment. We're still seeing growth but it's just not the same trajectory that we saw a couple of quarters ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel from Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel from Guggenheim.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start either for Bill or Tom. So a lot of your end customers are struggling a little bit with the value equation relative to eating at home and when you're thinking about the next several years with wage inflation likely to increase in the resta
componenttext: So let me start either for Bill or Tom. So a lot of your end customers are struggling a little bit with the value equation relative to eating at home and when you're thinking about the next several years with wage inflation likely to increase in the restaurant space. What are you doing today or more importantly, you look out over the next 2 or 3 years to help them deal with that? So what are the opportunities as it relates to maybe more Sysco Brand, selective price investments? How do you think about helping them compete and maybe drive some market share for yourself?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'll start and let Tom kind of get into the meat of that a little bit more. I think just from my perspective, this marketplace has been extremely competitive for most of my career and even more so since 2009, and we continue to see that. I think som
componenttext: John, I'll start and let Tom kind of get into the meat of that a little bit more. I think just from my perspective, this marketplace has been extremely competitive for most of my career and even more so since 2009, and we continue to see that. I think some operators are doing fine. And the best operators are going to do well and the best distributors are going to do well, and I think that will continue to play out. So I think it's -- everyone has their own unique challenges, but if you're investing in your business, if you're listening to your customer base and if you can scale, which you're good at, I think you're going to continue good success here. So you had a couple of things that we're doing but I'll let Tom take you through and remind the group here all the different things that we're doing to differentiate ourselves to our customers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, maybe just to build on a couple of things. While you're right, there are some reports out there of some traffic headwinds for some of these folks, the good news for them obviously is in the deflationary environment is their cost of products, in gene
componenttext: John, maybe just to build on a couple of things. While you're right, there are some reports out there of some traffic headwinds for some of these folks, the good news for them obviously is in the deflationary environment is their cost of products, in general, are not necessarily going up, so that's been a good thing for those restaurant operators. But from our perspective, we spend a lot of our time trying to think about what are those areas where we can help them be more successful. And you mentioned labor rates potentially going up, that's obviously a key concern of many of these operators today. And so whether it's Sysco Brand, where we bring not only value but also things I talked about, which is great reliability and traceability and high-quality products, that's a big area of focus for us. These tools, things -- think about some of the innovative products we're bringing, we're focused on how do we reduce the labor cost for these operators. So if there are products that are labor-saving type of products in the preparation that allows them to leverage some of those things to offset maybe some potential labor increases they're seeing. And as Bill said, I think technology and tools, in general, that allow them to manage their business more efficiently are also things we're focused on. So it's a really combination of things, but it's -- you're right, there's a lot of things that they're dealing with and I think the more we can focus on helping them be successful, that's a good place for us to be.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then secondly, I know it's early but have you seen any reaction or change in Brakes performance with their end demand post-Brexit? Or that ends up being kind of an overblown issue?
componenttext: All right. And then secondly, I know it's early but have you seen any reaction or change in Brakes performance with their end demand post-Brexit? Or that ends up being kind of an overblown issue?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's overblown, John. I think it's just early to tell. Heading into Brexit, I would say as we got into March and April, we did see, through their eyes, we've got some feel for it in terms of the data out there. And there were some slowing in
componenttext: I don't think it's overblown, John. I think it's just early to tell. Heading into Brexit, I would say as we got into March and April, we did see, through their eyes, we've got some feel for it in terms of the data out there. And there were some slowing in their business in the U.K. just in general, and a lot of that was attributed to the uncertainty of Brexit. And I think the implied thought would be that once there was certainty, then things would kind of bounce back a little bit. I think I assumed certainly would be to remain and obviously went the other way. So now what you got is continued uncertainty. So I just think it's going to be extended period of time here. And I think it'll play out politically, it'll play out economically. So a little slower in the U.K. right now. The good news for us is we've seen some good things coming out of France and Sweden, albeit that's about 1/3 of their business. So I think as far as Brexit is concerned, I think we're all watching it. And to this point, I don't know that I've seen any clear analysis in terms of what this specific impact is going to be at a certain point in time. My judgment would say that it's going to play out over the next 2 or 3 years. It will become business as usual here over that period of time, and it'll be somewhat of a headwind in the context of uncertainty that our people will work through in the marketplace.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think just one thing if I could add, it's Joel. I would just remind you, certainly, while there's some short-term instability that this creates, to some extent, we certainly remain very bullish as a long-term value creator for this company grea
componenttext: Yes, and I think just one thing if I could add, it's Joel. I would just remind you, certainly, while there's some short-term instability that this creates, to some extent, we certainly remain very bullish as a long-term value creator for this company great management team, a great platform for future growth and again just an overall good long-term view despite some slight, again, some short-term instability as a result.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly from Credit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to start with just the outlook. So you got it to 20% to 30% of the $500 million EBIT target in 2016, I think, which at the high end of that would be $150 million. You're just at $173 million excluding the extra week, $217 million if you include i
componenttext: I'd like to start with just the outlook. So you got it to 20% to 30% of the $500 million EBIT target in 2016, I think, which at the high end of that would be $150 million. You're just at $173 million excluding the extra week, $217 million if you include it. I guess the first part of this question is sort of what drove that upside to how you're initially thinking about things? And then as we think about 2017, you talked about 50% to 60%, which is probably like $300 million at the high end of the range. That does seem kind of low. So how should we think about 2017 given that you're ahead of where you thought you'd be at this point?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, thank you. I'll start and let Joel give you detail a little bit more. I would say in terms of why our performance for '16 was better than originally what we projected, I think part of it is just having the time to refine the plan and to go deep on the
componenttext: Ed, thank you. I'll start and let Joel give you detail a little bit more. I would say in terms of why our performance for '16 was better than originally what we projected, I think part of it is just having the time to refine the plan and to go deep on the plan and our execution was just very good. And so if you put all those some type of context, our merger agreement with US Foods was terminated in late June. We regrouped as a management team very quickly, and in July put together the framework over the 3-year plan and share to that with the investor group in September and along with our board. And so I wouldn't say we were cautious but we certainly were thoughtful in terms of what we were leading people to. And as we've built some momentum, if you'll recall first quarter, we had a very solid quarter in U.S. Broadline, but there's some tailwinds with incentives and that kind of -- our headwinds with incentives, and the first quarter was a little flattish and then very strong second, third and fourth. So we built momentum as the year went along to bring it back to the numbers, we've been able to manage this deflationary environment very well and create a good spread between our gross profit growth and our expense growth by managing our expenses very smartly and thoughtfully. So overall, I would just say the execution has been good, very good. And as we got deeper into the year, we were able to raise our estimate to $500 million. Not quite ready to do that right now would like to give further into this plan. We're 1/3 of the way through it, so I'd like to see another quarter or 2 and see how we perform, see how the marketplace performs and reassess that outlook at that point in time. Joel?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's really the context, Ed, that I'd put that into is that again, we're through the first year now of our 3-year plan. To the point that you made, build certainly some of them got some good momentum in the business. And in the end, again,
componenttext: Yes, I think that's really the context, Ed, that I'd put that into is that again, we're through the first year now of our 3-year plan. To the point that you made, build certainly some of them got some good momentum in the business. And in the end, again, a little bit of softness that we're seeing in the industry but certainly feeling good about where we're at. I think the comment Bill kind of closed is the right close as well is that again still early on and the like to get a little bit of time under our belt before we take a look at if there's anything else we wanted to do there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one follow-up. One of the, to me, more impressive sort of under-the-radar accomplishments for you guys is this dramatic improvement in the free cash flow. Can you talk just a little bit about what's been driving that and the opportunity tha
componenttext: Okay. And just one follow-up. One of the, to me, more impressive sort of under-the-radar accomplishments for you guys is this dramatic improvement in the free cash flow. Can you talk just a little bit about what's been driving that and the opportunity that you see? Last year, I know payable seems like fairly large opportunity. Just thoughts on sort of where we can expect that line item to sort of play out over the next couple of years.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So I think a couple of things on that. I mean, certainly, number one, we had -- we've got very strong operating performance. And so that's certainly again this has generated a good part of the free cash flow. You talked about the focus we've ha
componenttext: Yes, sure. So I think a couple of things on that. I mean, certainly, number one, we had -- we've got very strong operating performance. And so that's certainly again this has generated a good part of the free cash flow. You talked about the focus we've had on working capital. We've had some aggressive goals at the start of our 3-year plan. And I think one of the primary benefits of this year was in our focus in inventory, and we made some good progress in that area. And I think you'll continue to see opportunities there, again both on the payables area as well as inventory and some in the AR as well. So we've got some continued focus on working capital that I believe we're making good progress on, will continue to drive that. We did have some benefit this year, as I mentioned, some timing issues on cash taxes. Things that were related to the timing of payments and the ability to accelerate some deductions. Having said that, we also did have something, some stuff going the other way on the US Foods payment that we made in the first quarter of this year. So I would guess, what I would say in general, as I think the level of free cash flow you're seeing that we experienced this year is a pretty reasonable view of what I believe is the business can generate here as we move forward over the next couple of years. And so I think we're in a good place where we're going to continue driving the initiatives that we're driving and continue to improve that performance as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem from Wells Fargo.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: It looks like there was a conversion in total Broadline versus the local case growth in the quarter. Can you talk about the drivers here and how trends played out just throughout the quarter? And you mentioned already the performance of chain versus indep
componenttext: It looks like there was a conversion in total Broadline versus the local case growth in the quarter. Can you talk about the drivers here and how trends played out just throughout the quarter? And you mentioned already the performance of chain versus independent, but what about your institutional customers like the health care and retail verticals? How are they trending?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Zach, could you be a little more clear on what you mean by conversion?
componenttext: Zach, could you be a little more clear on what you mean by conversion?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, when you look at the Broadline case trend and the local case trend, they both converged at that...
componenttext: Well, I mean, when you look at the Broadline case trend and the local case trend, they both converged at that...

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Numbers, okay, got it. So let me take the first part and I'll let Tom talk about the segments a little bit. I think it's just what you said. I mean, we, and obviously, anybody in this business understands that where we have the opportunity to bring the mo
componenttext: Numbers, okay, got it. So let me take the first part and I'll let Tom talk about the segments a little bit. I think it's just what you said. I mean, we, and obviously, anybody in this business understands that where we have the opportunity to bring the most value is in that locally managed, highly street-oriented customer base and we continue to focus there in a myriad of ways that we spoke to in terms of commercial initiatives, supply chain, all that type of thing. And that's continued to pay dividends for us here over the last 2 years-plus. So we feel good about that. We also want to continue to grow that corporate managed business in the right way. And so you're seeing the slope of that growth follow somewhat. It's still positive and there's still very, very important relationships we have out there are some very large customers that work for us as well from a profitability standpoint. So balance is always key here. And it's key if you're running an operating company and it's key from the overall corporate standpoint and which you saw here was a quarter with pretty good balance. And any point in time, one segment, if you want to call it that for the moment, may be growing a little faster than the other, and that's okay, but generally we're looking to grow both in the right way with good discipline. And we've been making great strides here over the last year or 2. So I'll let Tom speak a little bit to the segment performance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'll add is around this segment to think you mentioned change and also health care, we continue to feel good about each of the segments and their growth potential for us. Obviously, health care continues to be, I think, a growth segment for
componenttext: The only thing I'll add is around this segment to think you mentioned change and also health care, we continue to feel good about each of the segments and their growth potential for us. Obviously, health care continues to be, I think, a growth segment for this industry. And I think the chain business, while it's going to have its choppiness, depending on which customer you're talking about, overall that business, I think, is going to continue to be solid out there. For us I think it's a really -- as Bill said, a balance. And so looking at different customers and relative profitability in where we can actually have the most value is where we're trying to focus our efforts. And clearly, that's in that local restaurant segment certainly probably more so than in the chain restaurant segment. But overall, I think we don't see necessarily other than some of the chain numbers you've seen from some of those companies, we see fairly consistent performance across these segments.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then to touch on Brakes quickly, can you talk about just margin opportunities there? You mentioned it's a 5% adjusted EBITDA margin, but can you talk about some of the facility and productivity efforts there? And how do you think about the long-term m
componenttext: And then to touch on Brakes quickly, can you talk about just margin opportunities there? You mentioned it's a 5% adjusted EBITDA margin, but can you talk about some of the facility and productivity efforts there? And how do you think about the long-term margin opportunity and how that can play out?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as Joel said, we made a significant investment here for the [indiscernible] long term. We certainly expect them to be able to grow their business on the top line. They have a very similar approach as we do especially in the U.K. in terms of a discip
componenttext: Well, as Joel said, we made a significant investment here for the [indiscernible] long term. We certainly expect them to be able to grow their business on the top line. They have a very similar approach as we do especially in the U.K. in terms of a disciplined approach. They are, as we've alluded to in the past, going through some significant transformative changes of their own, a fair amount of which is playing out in the supply chain in the United Kingdom, where they're consolidating warehouses into warehouses that look more like ours where you have multiple capacity, storage capacity all in one building, which in and of itself will create cost savings, improved productivity that kind of thing. So certainly, the supply chain, in particular in the U.K., is an opportunity for Brakes to expand their margins but there's other opportunities as well starting with growing with the right customers and making sure that those customers are interfacing with them and ordering product in the way that they want sort of channels that they prefer. So they have a lot of the same opportunities that we have.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to just follow-up on the independents. I realize it moderated slightly but still very solid growth, I think, if you look over the past several years at least. So just wondering if you -- when you analyze that segment, what are you seeing there that
componenttext: Wanted to just follow-up on the independents. I realize it moderated slightly but still very solid growth, I think, if you look over the past several years at least. So just wondering if you -- when you analyze that segment, what are you seeing there that's really the drivers there? Is it still pretty broad-based? Are there any ethnic categories or regions or when you talk to your customers there, is there any difference in take-out or dine-in trends? Just trying to understand what you think the real drivers are for the independent or local case growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take a stab at that. If you think about the independent segment, there's been a lot of discussion around whether it's growing or not growing. I think the way we look at it is we have significant opportunity to grow in that segment. And I think
componenttext: Sure, I'll take a stab at that. If you think about the independent segment, there's been a lot of discussion around whether it's growing or not growing. I think the way we look at it is we have significant opportunity to grow in that segment. And I think if you think about the fact that there are many distributors in the industry, there's opportunity for us to earn additional share of that business from our customers. So we're very focused on delivering the kind of things that they need, which we talked about a lot of those value drivers for our customers. And whether it's things like Sysco Brand are some of the tools we're bringing to help them manage their business better. In addition, you mentioned some segments, and you've heard us talk about some of the ethnic segments. We obviously -- there's been a nice tailwind in the Hispanic, Latino restaurant segment. It's been a focus area for us. And so we continue to look at those types of opportunities where there's nice kind of tailwinds that we can provide incremental value to those folks and also grow our business. And then I'd just say that overall, that segment feels like they're picking up some share potentially in this away from home. And whether it's additional opportunities for home deliveries you talked about, we hear and we all see some of these trends taking place with some of these folks who are creating that opportunity for those local restaurants, and I think they are, in fact, benefiting from some of those technology solutions as well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. And then in terms of deflation, I think it was called out as one of the drivers or maybe not drivers, one of the factors that favorably impacted gross margin this year. And I think you called it out as a gross profit headwind f
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. And then in terms of deflation, I think it was called out as one of the drivers or maybe not drivers, one of the factors that favorably impacted gross margin this year. And I think you called it out as a gross profit headwind for the first half of next year. So just curious, is that just because of the sales impact? Or is there a change in how you expect the deflation to impact your gross margin in the first half of '17?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, Joel explained to it to you better than I can, but I hate to say it's just the way you think about math, so gross profit is dollar so when you're selling a case for whatever, 0.7% or 1% less than you did same time last year, you're obviously taking
componenttext: Kelly, Joel explained to it to you better than I can, but I hate to say it's just the way you think about math, so gross profit is dollar so when you're selling a case for whatever, 0.7% or 1% less than you did same time last year, you're obviously taking fewer dollars to pay your expenses with that said, from on a percentage basis, it can contribute to expansion of your margin.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's really the main point. I mean, if you think about a portion of our business but being on cost-plus and just, in general, where the cost of goods, there is again some margin percentage increase, but it is a typically a headwind on a gro
componenttext: Yes, I think that's really the main point. I mean, if you think about a portion of our business but being on cost-plus and just, in general, where the cost of goods, there is again some margin percentage increase, but it is a typically a headwind on a gross profit dollars themselves. Of course, having said that, certainly, there's great work being done by Tom and his team and our associates actually to offset some of that to the extent we can.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom made an interesting point which I think from a customer's perspective, while we're not a fan of deflation in this -- we're now, as we speak, in our fifth quarter of it, so that's -- we don't think that, that's particularly a good thing for our custome
componenttext: Tom made an interesting point which I think from a customer's perspective, while we're not a fan of deflation in this -- we're now, as we speak, in our fifth quarter of it, so that's -- we don't think that, that's particularly a good thing for our customers or for us certainly over the medium to long term. With that said, if it was going to happen probably came the right time for customer basis dealing with so much inflation as well. So it probably good on the customer side, and we've been able to manage it well, but we would certainly prefer to see no inflation, modest inflation, that type of thing in the more steady-state environment.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Ajay Jain from Pivotal Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Ajay Jain from Pivotal Research.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned the slowdown in traffic from NPD and I think you cited KNAPP-TRACK also. I think last week, case growth was also sequentially weaker slightly at US Foods. So I just wanted to ask, apart from the softe
componenttext: Bill, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned the slowdown in traffic from NPD and I think you cited KNAPP-TRACK also. I think last week, case growth was also sequentially weaker slightly at US Foods. So I just wanted to ask, apart from the softer industry-wide trends, are there any kind of company-specific factors in terms of any slowdown in case growth? And has there been any change in the trendline quarter-to-date in terms of traffic and average check? Is there an incremental change in your trajectory quarter-to-date?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well again, we're talking about our earnings for the June quarter, and what I'm telling you is we've seen a softening in the customer base, both from the data that you cited Ajay as well as what we see. So obviously what we're signaling here is there is s
componenttext: Well again, we're talking about our earnings for the June quarter, and what I'm telling you is we've seen a softening in the customer base, both from the data that you cited Ajay as well as what we see. So obviously what we're signaling here is there is some softening in the business as they also said, we're still seeing growth and I would expect that will continue to see growth perhaps not at the same trajectory. I also secular development I think it's just -- it goes through these cycles and time will tell whether it's cycle or not. But if you read all the data that we all are exposed to which what you're seeing and the industry's but he consisted what you're seeing in the economy right now. It's growth but it's modest. And I think that's what our customers are dealing with right now. So our focus continues to be how do we support our customers to grow their business profitably and do the same for us at the same time. And I've never felt better about our ability to do that. We've got a great team here, a very solid strategy. We're executing well, so we're going to impact and control what we can control and will work through cycles as they come and go.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just had one follow-up question on Brakes I think you got several questions on Brexit. Can you specifically talk about the currency impact and just on restaurant spending overall in the U.K. because I guess, of the currency impact could be viewed as
componenttext: And I just had one follow-up question on Brakes I think you got several questions on Brexit. Can you specifically talk about the currency impact and just on restaurant spending overall in the U.K. because I guess, of the currency impact could be viewed as threefold. You've got the direct P&L impact, which is fairly straightforward but then the currency also impacts the purchasing power of the U.K. consumers, and it also affects your purchase price for the acquisitions. So I think you're partly hedged on a currency impact, but can you just comment on how big of an incremental impact there is from Brexit compared to what you anticipated when you consummated the merger? And then can you also just talk about current case trends at Brakes? I think you mentioned that they took a little bit of a step backwards, but can you confirm whether they're positive or negative based on year-over-year comparisons?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that 3 questions or one? Okay. Let me try, Ajay. Actually, I think what I said about Brakes is in the U.K. market, in general, what we've seen is for March and April, I know it's connected to Brexit, the uncertainty of the Brexit vote. And since the vo
componenttext: Is that 3 questions or one? Okay. Let me try, Ajay. Actually, I think what I said about Brakes is in the U.K. market, in general, what we've seen is for March and April, I know it's connected to Brexit, the uncertainty of the Brexit vote. And since the vote, we've seen some softening over there in that market and the data and the government data will support that as well. We're not in a position obviously to comment on the numbers. We've just closed that deal in less than [ph] 1.5 month. We'll talk more about that certainly in November when we release for the first quarter. But we feel good about -- as Joel said, we feel very good about this acquisition about the leadership, investment for the long term, acquisition platform, all the things we said from the beginning. So Brexit, I'm going to let Joel take you through the currency issues. I think we managed it quite well actually as far as the transaction goes. As you said, there's the normal translation of earnings and that type of thing. And while I'm not going to all your points I would just say from my perspective, the bigger issues as far as Brexit is concerned is always what comes down to in our markets as well is what's the impact on the consumer. I think it's less about foreign exchange at the consumer level. And because of some of the uncertainty, we've seen some softening over there. The weather, you hear all the same things, weather in London, it's summertime and kind of thing, so I think is going to be some ups and downs, position to talk about it in November. But overall, we're very pleased with the acquisition. We have a lot of work to do there and we're very excited about it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add a couple of things. I mean, the translation impacts again certainly will be something we'll be dealing as we move forward. In terms of the price itself, I mean, as we mentioned, there was actually -- we had a foreign currency remeasu
componenttext: Yes, I would just add a couple of things. I mean, the translation impacts again certainly will be something we'll be dealing as we move forward. In terms of the price itself, I mean, as we mentioned, there was actually -- we had a foreign currency remeasurement that basically resulted from the fact that at the end of the year, we're holding sterling on our balance sheet for the purchase price. Of course, the deal closed right after the year. And so we had the balance sheet needs to be revalued to the exchange rate that exist at that point in time. Our team did a great job in hedging to protect us on the upside and purchasing currency opportunistically to maximize our ability to minimize that foreign exchange devaluation, but we did experience some of that, some of which was also reflected in the in purchase price. But overall, again, I would just tell you will continue to manage through that stuff, and as Bill said, continue to focus on driving focus on the customers and the operational performance in that company.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back -- sorry to harp on the softness, recent softness question. I guess if you had to build kind of rank potential causes, I mean, I would think value equation maybe being out of whack is on the list, but maybe recent unrest, terrorism domesti
componenttext: Just going back -- sorry to harp on the softness, recent softness question. I guess if you had to build kind of rank potential causes, I mean, I would think value equation maybe being out of whack is on the list, but maybe recent unrest, terrorism domestically, Olympics, staying at home, anyway you can kind of rank any of that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know I would rank any of that in my top 3. But Karen [indiscernible] some of that, we obviously read a lot and try to learn as much as we can from folks components of the industry. I just think it's a little bit of a malaise. I just think it's --
componenttext: I don't know I would rank any of that in my top 3. But Karen [indiscernible] some of that, we obviously read a lot and try to learn as much as we can from folks components of the industry. I just think it's a little bit of a malaise. I just think it's -- are going to have these cycles and soft cycles in any point in time and some of it we are going up against some stronger numbers a year ago. So there's some math in it. But it just feels a little bit softer out there I think people are being a little more cautious with their spend, maybe election, maybe I'm not sure. So I guess, I wouldn't want to just conjecture here, but I don't think it's in the Olympics. And I don't think it's any one thing, in particular, I just think it's a little softer, and it seems to be showing up in multiple places, so I don't think it's a certain type of customer per se or anything like that. I just think it's one of these of sub cycles that were going to go through and time will tell whether it's a 3- to 6-month deal or longer. But again, from our perspective, we've been managing through some pretty significant headwinds with deflation over the last year, and I couldn't be more pleased with how we've been executing. So again, we can't totally control the industry top line, but I feel good about what we're doing in our space and how we're driving earnings at the same time staying very close to our customers and focusing what's important to them. So that's the best I can probably give you from our stance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I'm just curious, one of your competitors recently gave some data on percent of sales from independent restaurants coming from an e-commerce platform -- from their e-commerce platform at a pretty high 50%. I guess I'm just w
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I'm just curious, one of your competitors recently gave some data on percent of sales from independent restaurants coming from an e-commerce platform -- from their e-commerce platform at a pretty high 50%. I guess I'm just wondering if it would give us some color and where you stand on mobile penetration as a percent of independent sales or just an update on where you're at with that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Tom speak more specifically. I would just remind you that our strategy is really predicated on being most valued business partner, so we're not setting goals per se for certain percentage of Sysco Brand or a certain percentage of orders through m
componenttext: I'll let Tom speak more specifically. I would just remind you that our strategy is really predicated on being most valued business partner, so we're not setting goals per se for certain percentage of Sysco Brand or a certain percentage of orders through mobile or digital. With that said, we certainly understand that we need to make the experience of Sysco as easy as possible and certainly being able to online when you want to order the way you want to order those are very important and increasingly important to our customers. So we've got a lot of good work going on with our digital platform to make that experience a more positive one and a productive one for our customers. So our numbers are modest but they're beginning to grow, but again, the overall target is here is to drive the business in the right way not necessarily particular percentage. Go ahead.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just love build a little bit on that. I think in the past, we've talked about we've been somewhat in this kind of high single-digit, just below 10%. Now through the fourth quarter, now we're seeing over 10% of our orders from these local customers coming
componenttext: Just love build a little bit on that. I think in the past, we've talked about we've been somewhat in this kind of high single-digit, just below 10%. Now through the fourth quarter, now we're seeing over 10% of our orders from these local customers coming through this mobile or digital platform. So we do see some progression continue to happen, but as Bill said, it's really for us about creating the environment where they can order how they want, when they want and where they want. And so there also a few tools we needed to build to be able to get in place to enable them to do that more effectively, and we've got some of those tools now in place. And that we believe will continue to see that number grow as more customers have that interest. But we also know from a lot of work we do that our marketing associates are one of the most highest valued resource we have that we provide our customers. So we're trying to make sure that we balance the -- how the order with the services and support they need to get day in and day out from our selling resources. So we feel good about the progress that certainly will probably see that continue to grow. But we're very focused on the overall customer experience and letting them choose.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth from Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little color on the deflation by category? And are there certain quarters where you're going to start lapping at some of the bigger headwinds?
componenttext: Could you give us a little color on the deflation by category? And are there certain quarters where you're going to start lapping at some of the bigger headwinds?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're lapping them. So it has started and I think generally, it's in the meat, seafood and some dairy. Joel, is that about right?
componenttext: We're lapping them. So it has started and I think generally, it's in the meat, seafood and some dairy. Joel, is that about right?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is the deflation cooling for you now or is it still as heavy? I mean, pretty big deflationary number this quarter.
componenttext: So is the deflation cooling for you now or is it still as heavy? I mean, pretty big deflationary number this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say it's moved around a little bit the last 3 quarters, but I'd say relatively steady from where we were after a year ago, 6 months ago.
componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's moved around a little bit the last 3 quarters, but I'd say relatively steady from where we were after a year ago, 6 months ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to get into the softening of the backdrop a little bit, wanted to get your thoughts on restaurant store growth out there. Because a lot of those health indicators you were looking at are same-store sales measures. So I'm curious, do you thi
componenttext: Okay. And just to get into the softening of the backdrop a little bit, wanted to get your thoughts on restaurant store growth out there. Because a lot of those health indicators you were looking at are same-store sales measures. So I'm curious, do you think there's overstoring going on out there as part of the problem and what's been your percentage of business from new stores over the last several years?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think when you go back to 2009, 2010, clearly, there was oversupply, overcapacity. And I think there's been a pretty good correction since that time. I believe we've seen some modest reduction in restaurant, number of restaurants you over the last
componenttext: Mark, I think when you go back to 2009, 2010, clearly, there was oversupply, overcapacity. And I think there's been a pretty good correction since that time. I believe we've seen some modest reduction in restaurant, number of restaurants you over the last year or so, but nothing to the degree what we saw 4 and 5 years ago. So there's maybe a little bit of a modest correction. I don't think that, that's an overriding issue. I think it's somewhat self-correcting. We don't really track our sales -- new stores. The way we track it, Mark, we track new business for us, which is making a content operator that we didn't sell a year ago this time then we track lost business of just of the ops where we had a sale a year ago, and we don't have any, and then we track penetration. So the softening, if you will, is probably shown up a little more on the case penetration side right now.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do you think the strength you had in local is enough to kind of overpower some of the broader industry softening?
componenttext: Okay. And do you think the strength you had in local is enough to kind of overpower some of the broader industry softening?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I feel very good about our 3-year plan and I feel very good about how we're executing the business. And if that's your question, I think bottom line is we feel good about the momentum we have. We feel really good about the year just past and there's a lit
componenttext: I feel very good about our 3-year plan and I feel very good about how we're executing the business. And if that's your question, I think bottom line is we feel good about the momentum we have. We feel really good about the year just past and there's a little softer we've got good things going on with gross profit, we're managing our expenses very hard right now and we're very committed to the plan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-ups to earlier questions. I guess first, related to Ed's question on EBIT growth target. I think you had previously looked for 55% to 65% of the goal coming from gross profit and the remainder in supply chain and administrative costs. A
componenttext: A couple of follow-ups to earlier questions. I guess first, related to Ed's question on EBIT growth target. I think you had previously looked for 55% to 65% of the goal coming from gross profit and the remainder in supply chain and administrative costs. As you think about the better execution driving the upside, where do you think that is impacted those buckets most and where is the biggest opportunity going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look Steve, I think both those lines are critical lines but certainly, you have to start with gross profit. I mean, we make $9 billion in gross profit. That's more than the sales of many, many of the people that we compete with head to head. So that
componenttext: Well, look Steve, I think both those lines are critical lines but certainly, you have to start with gross profit. I mean, we make $9 billion in gross profit. That's more than the sales of many, many of the people that we compete with head to head. So that's a huge number that we've been able to grow very nicely on an adjusted basis over the last year to 2 years. And how do we do that? I mean, it comes back to the levers that we talked about. Case growth with a particular emphasis on local case growth, managing the margins, utilizing a lot of tools, many of which are technology-based today and taking a hard look at where our potential is in terms of territories within each district within each OpCo. So assessing the opportunity for growth by territory, by district, by OpCo, taking advantage of some of the revenue management tools that Tom and his teams or have put in place over the last year to just know beginning to mature, continue to utilize category management across both from leveraging our spend but also bringing innovation to that product, staying close to our customers, refining our customer insight to be as currently possibly can into some of the need to some of those operators are as they face the challenges. So you have to start with gross profit, and your ability to grow those dollars, and we've done a nice job then expect us to continue to do well. With that said, as I said in terms of the pillars of our strategy, we need to be more productive and everything we do. And we set some goals out there and certainly running the business at a flat cost per piece for yet another year here is a very appropriate, yet aggressive goal, and it's going to be paramount for us to have success this year to do that. So we've got some good momentum there in supply chain. We're managing our SG&A very well. So I feel very good about our corporate spend as well. We're still spending some money in business technology to kind of tools that we've been talking about year in particular on the commercial side. So I think we're spending the money in the right place. Over time, we'll continue to flatten out that corporate spend, try to keep the flat cost per case, keep cost per case flat in the field and that combination of good solid gross profit growth and well-managed expenses should serve us very well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the one thing I'll just add to that, even if you think about the model and how we look at that spread between gross profit dollars and operating expense dollars, I think one of the things we've remained focused on is that delta between those 2. An
componenttext: I think the one thing I'll just add to that, even if you think about the model and how we look at that spread between gross profit dollars and operating expense dollars, I think one of the things we've remained focused on is that delta between those 2. And so even in times when we've had some impact of deflation on the gross profit dollars, again, we've continued to focus on driving the expenses to where we look at that spread. And again on a year-to-date basis, we are up a little over 1.5% in terms of that delta between those 2. And so the only other thing I may call out is just to think about because that's certainly the way we think about that and again whether deflation goes up or down, that relative spread between the 2 is certainly part of our model and something we've done really well on the point Bill was.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think the difference in this conversation we're having today versus 3, 4, 5 years ago is what I spoke to in terms of the foundation that we built with a lot of our transformative work, a lot of the initiatives that we put in place. We have tool
componenttext: Yes, and I think the difference in this conversation we're having today versus 3, 4, 5 years ago is what I spoke to in terms of the foundation that we built with a lot of our transformative work, a lot of the initiatives that we put in place. We have tools today, we have structure, we have the right people to do this. It's not easy. It's still a very competitive environment out there, but we're much better positioned today to accomplish these things than we were 5 years ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And within that, you talked about the good work on the digital platform. Where do you think your systems are relative to peers? And does the shift away from SAP change your ability to implement some of these tools?
componenttext: And within that, you talked about the good work on the digital platform. Where do you think your systems are relative to peers? And does the shift away from SAP change your ability to implement some of these tools?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, a big part of our ongoing strategy here was to reallocate our, what we call, our business technology spend more to the customer-facing side of the business. So I think the direction is right, the spend is right. We're making good strides. B
componenttext: Well, clearly, a big part of our ongoing strategy here was to reallocate our, what we call, our business technology spend more to the customer-facing side of the business. So I think the direction is right, the spend is right. We're making good strides. But we've got some work to do to get the -- not just the digital platform but all the tools we use behind the scenes both operate the business and assess the performance of the business. We still have some good work to do here to improve and that will be a perpetual opportunity. So good work to do, but I think strategically we're spending the money in the right place and we'll continue to invest appropriately in that part of our business.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask about the M&A landscape, and in particular, with your more of an entry into the fresh and the ethnic products, Trinity, Northstar, to name a couple this year. Just kind of how you feel your traction's going, where you are from an assortment
