headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned the slowdown in traffic from NPD, and I think you cited KNAPP-TRACK also. And I think last week, case growth was also sequentially weaker slightly at US Foods. So I just wanted to ask, apart from
componenttext: Yes, Bill, in your prepared comments, I think you mentioned the slowdown in traffic from NPD, and I think you cited KNAPP-TRACK also. And I think last week, case growth was also sequentially weaker slightly at US Foods. So I just wanted to ask, apart from the softer industry-wide trends, are there any kind of company-specific factors in terms of any slowdown in case growth? And has there been any change in the trendline quarter-to-date in terms of traffic and average check? Is there any incremental change in your trajectory quarter-to-date?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we're talking about our earnings for the June quarter, and -- but what I'm telling you is we've seen a softening in the customer base, both from the data that you just cited, Ajay, as well as what we see. So obviously, what we're signaling he
componenttext: Well, again, we're talking about our earnings for the June quarter, and -- but what I'm telling you is we've seen a softening in the customer base, both from the data that you just cited, Ajay, as well as what we see. So obviously, what we're signaling here is there is some softening in the business. As I also said, we're still seeing growth, and I would expect that we'll continue to see growth perhaps not at the same trajectory. I don’t' see there's any big secular development. I think it's just -- you go through these cycles and time will tell whether it's a mini cycle or not. But yes, if you read all the data that we all are exposed to, what you're seeing in this industry is pretty consistent what you're seeing in the economy right now. It's growth, but it's modest. And I think that's what our customers are dealing with right now. So our focus continues to be how do we support our customers to grow their business profitably and do the same for us at the same time, and I've never felt better about our ability to do that. We've got a great team here, a very solid strategy. We're executing well. So we're going to impact and control what we can control, and we'll work through cycles as they come and go.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I just had one follow-up question on Brakes. I think you already got several questions on Brexit. Can you specifically talk about the currency impact and just on restaurant spending overall in the U.K.? Because I guess the currency impact could
componenttext: Okay. And I just had one follow-up question on Brakes. I think you already got several questions on Brexit. Can you specifically talk about the currency impact and just on restaurant spending overall in the U.K.? Because I guess the currency impact could be viewed as threefold. You've got the direct P&L impact, which is fairly straightforward, but then the currency also impacts the purchasing power of the U.K. consumers and it also affects your purchase price for the acquisition. So I think you're partly hedged on the currency impact. But can you just comment on how big of an incremental impact there is from Brexit compared to what you anticipated when you consummated the merger? And then can you also just talk about current case trends at Brakes? I think you mentioned that they took a little bit of a step backwards, but can you confirm whether they're positive or negative based on year-over-year comparisons?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was that 3 questions or one there? Okay, let me try, Ajay. Actually, I think what I said about Brakes is in the U.K. market in general, what we've seen is for March and April, I know it's connected to Brexit, the uncertainty of the Brexit vote. And since
componenttext: Was that 3 questions or one there? Okay, let me try, Ajay. Actually, I think what I said about Brakes is in the U.K. market in general, what we've seen is for March and April, I know it's connected to Brexit, the uncertainty of the Brexit vote. And since the vote, we've seen some softening over there in that market, and the data and the government data will support that as well. We're not in a position, obviously, to comment on their numbers. We've just closed that deal last month. Now we'll talk more about that certainly in November when we release for the first quarter. But we feel good about -- as Joel said, we feel very good about this acquisition, about the leadership, investment for the long term, acquisition platform, all the things we said from the beginning. So Brexit, I'm going to let Joel take you through the currency issues. I think we managed it quite well actually as far as the transaction goes. As you said, there's the normal translation of earnings and that type of thing. And while I'm not going to dispute all your points, I would just say from my perspective the bigger issue as far as Brexit is concerned is always -- is what it comes down to here in our markets as well is what's the impact on the consumer. I think it's less about foreign exchange at the consumer level. And because of some of the uncertainty, we've seen some softening over there. The weather -- I mean, you hear all the same things, weather in London in summertime and that kind of thing. So I think there's going to be some ups and downs, and we'll be in a better position to talk about it in November. But overall, we're very pleased with the acquisition. And we have a lot of work to do there and we're very excited about it.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add a couple of things. I mean, the translation impacts, again, certainly, will be something we'll be dealing with as we move forward. In terms of the price itself, I mean, as we mentioned, there was actually -- we had a foreign currency
componenttext: Yes, I would just add a couple of things. I mean, the translation impacts, again, certainly, will be something we'll be dealing with as we move forward. In terms of the price itself, I mean, as we mentioned, there was actually -- we had a foreign currency remeasurement that basically resulted from the fact that at the end of the year, we're holding sterling on our balance sheet for the purchase price. Of course, the deal closed right after the year, and so we had -- the balance sheet needs to be revalued to the exchange rate that exists at that point in time. Our team did a great job of hedging to protect us on the upside and purchasing currency opportunistically to maximize our ability to minimize that foreign exchange devaluation. But we did experience some of that, some of which was also reflected in the end purchase price. But overall, again, I would just tell you that we'll continue to manage through that stuff and, as Bill said, continue to focus on driving focus on the customers and the operational performance of that company.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Karen Short from Barclays.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back -- sorry to harp on the softness -- the recent softness question. I guess if you had to, Bill, kind of rank potential causes, I mean, I would think value equation maybe being out of whack is on the list but maybe recent unrest, terrorism d
componenttext: Just going back -- sorry to harp on the softness -- the recent softness question. I guess if you had to, Bill, kind of rank potential causes, I mean, I would think value equation maybe being out of whack is on the list but maybe recent unrest, terrorism domestically, Olympics, people staying home. Any way you can kind of rank any of that?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I would rank any of that as my top 3. But Karen, just reviewing [ph] some of that, we, obviously, read a lot and try to learn as much as we can from folks that follow components of the industry. I just think it's a little bit of a malais
componenttext: I don't know that I would rank any of that as my top 3. But Karen, just reviewing [ph] some of that, we, obviously, read a lot and try to learn as much as we can from folks that follow components of the industry. I just think it's a little bit of a malaise. I just think it's -- the -- you're going to have these cycles and soft cycles at any point in time, and some of it, we're going up against some stronger numbers a year ago. So there's some math in it. But it just feels a little bit softer out there. I think people are being a little more cautious with their spend. Maybe the election, maybe -- I'm not sure. So I guess I wouldn't want to just conjecture here. But I don't think it's the Olympics. And I don't think it's any one thing in particular. I just think it's a little softer, and it seems to be showing up in multiple places. So I don't think it's a certain type of customer per se or anything like that. I just think it's one of these of soft cycles that we're going to go through, and time will tell whether it's a 3- to 6-month deal or longer. But again, from our perspective, we've been managing through some pretty significant headwinds with deflation over the last year, and I couldn't be more pleased with how we've been executing. So again, we can't totally control the industry top line, but I feel good about what we're doing in our space and how we're driving earnings and, at the same time, staying very close to our customers and focusing on what's important to them. So that's the best I can probably give you from our [indiscernible] stance.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I'm just curious, one of your competitors recently gave some data on percent of sales from independent restaurants coming from an e-commerce platform at -- from their e-commerce platform at a pretty high 50%. I guess I'm jus
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I'm just curious, one of your competitors recently gave some data on percent of sales from independent restaurants coming from an e-commerce platform at -- from their e-commerce platform at a pretty high 50%. I guess I'm just wondering if you could give us some color on where you stand on mobile penetration as a percent of independent sales or just an update on where you're at with that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll let Tom kind of speak to it more specifically. I would just remind you that our strategy is really predicated on being the most valued and trusted business partner. So we're not setting goals per se for a certain percentage of Sysco Brand or a c
componenttext: Yes, I'll let Tom kind of speak to it more specifically. I would just remind you that our strategy is really predicated on being the most valued and trusted business partner. So we're not setting goals per se for a certain percentage of Sysco Brand or a certain percentage of orders through mobile or digital. With that said, we certainly understand that we need to make the experience with Sysco as easy as possible. And certainly being able to order online, when you want to order, the way you want to order it, those are very important and increasingly important to our customers. So we've got a lot of good work going on with our digital platform to make that experience a more positive one and a productive one for our customers. So our numbers are modest, but they're beginning to grow. But again, the overall target is -- here is to drive the business in the right way. It's not necessarily at a particular percentage. Go ahead, Tom.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Karen, I'll just, well, build a little bit on that. I think in the past, we've talked about we've been somewhat in this kind of high single-digit, just below 10%. Now -- through the fourth quarter now, we're seeing over 10% of our orders from these loc
componenttext: So Karen, I'll just, well, build a little bit on that. I think in the past, we've talked about we've been somewhat in this kind of high single-digit, just below 10%. Now -- through the fourth quarter now, we're seeing over 10% of our orders from these local customers coming through this mobile or digital platform. So we do see some progression continue to happen. But as Bill said, it's really, for us, about creating the environment where they can order how they want, when they want and where they want. And so there were also a few tools we needed to build to be able to get in place to enable them to do that more effectively, and we've got some of those tools now in place and that we believe we'll continue to see that number grow as more customers have that interest. But we also know from a lot of work we do that our marketing associates are one of the most highest valued resource we have and -- that we provide our customers. So we're trying to make sure that we balance the how they order with the service and support they need to get day in and day out from our selling resources. So we feel good about the progress, but certainly, we'll probably see that continue to grow. But we're very focused on that overall customer experience and letting them choose.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Wiltamuth from Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little color on the deflation by category? And are there certain quarters where you're going to start lapping out of some of the bigger headwinds?
componenttext: Can you give us a little color on the deflation by category? And are there certain quarters where you're going to start lapping out of some of the bigger headwinds?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're lapping them. So it has started. And I think generally, it's in the meat, seafood and then some dairy. Joel, is that about right?
componenttext: We're lapping them. So it has started. And I think generally, it's in the meat, seafood and then some dairy. Joel, is that about right?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is the deflation cooling for you now? Or is it still as heavy? I mean, there's a pretty big deflationary number this quarter.
componenttext: So is the deflation cooling for you now? Or is it still as heavy? I mean, there's a pretty big deflationary number this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say it's moved around a little bit the last 3 quarters, but I'd say relatively steady from where we were half a year ago, 6 months ago.
componenttext: Yes, I'd say it's moved around a little bit the last 3 quarters, but I'd say relatively steady from where we were half a year ago, 6 months ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to get into the softening of the backdrop a little bit. I wanted to get your thoughts on restaurant store growth out there because a lot of those health indicators you were looking at are same-store sales measures. So I'm curious, do you th
componenttext: Okay. And just to get into the softening of the backdrop a little bit. I wanted to get your thoughts on restaurant store growth out there because a lot of those health indicators you were looking at are same-store sales measures. So I'm curious, do you think there's overstoring going on out there as part of the problem? And what's been your percentage of business from new stores over the last several years?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think when you go back to 2009, 2010, clearly there was oversupply or overcapacity. And I think there's been a pretty good correction since that time. I believe we've seen some modest reduction in restaurants -- number of restaurants here over the
componenttext: Mark, I think when you go back to 2009, 2010, clearly there was oversupply or overcapacity. And I think there's been a pretty good correction since that time. I believe we've seen some modest reduction in restaurants -- number of restaurants here over the last year or so, but nothing to the degree what we saw 4 and 5 years ago. So there's maybe a little bit of a modest correction. I don't think that, that's an overriding issue. I think it's somewhat self-correcting. We don't really track our sales -- new stores. The way we track it, Mark, is we track new business for us, which is making a count to an operator that we didn't sell a year ago this time. Then we track lost business, which is just the opposite where we had a sale a year ago and we don't have any. And then we track penetration. So the softening, if you will, is probably showing up a little more on the case penetration side right now.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And do you think the strength you've had in local is enough to kind of overpower some of the broader industry softening?
componenttext: Okay. And do you think the strength you've had in local is enough to kind of overpower some of the broader industry softening?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I feel very good about our 3-year plan and I feel very good about how we're executing in the business. And if that's your question, I think bottom line is we feel good about the momentum we have. We feel really good about the year just past. And if it is
componenttext: I feel very good about our 3-year plan and I feel very good about how we're executing in the business. And if that's your question, I think bottom line is we feel good about the momentum we have. We feel really good about the year just past. And if it is a little softer, we've got good things going on with gross profit, we're managing our expenses very hard right now and we're very committed to the plan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-ups to earlier questions. I guess first, related to Ed's question on EBIT growth targets, I think you had previously looked for a 55% to 65% of the goal coming from gross profit and the remainder in supply chain and administrative costs
componenttext: A couple of follow-ups to earlier questions. I guess first, related to Ed's question on EBIT growth targets, I think you had previously looked for a 55% to 65% of the goal coming from gross profit and the remainder in supply chain and administrative costs. As you think about the better execution driving the upside, where do you think that has impacted those buckets most? And where is the biggest opportunity going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, Stephen, I think both those lines are critical lines. But certainly, you have to start with gross profit. I mean, we make $9 billion in gross profit. That's more than the sales of many, many of the people that we compete with head to head. So
componenttext: Well, look, Stephen, I think both those lines are critical lines. But certainly, you have to start with gross profit. I mean, we make $9 billion in gross profit. That's more than the sales of many, many of the people that we compete with head to head. So that's a huge number that we've been able to grow very nicely on an adjusted basis over the last year to 2 years. And how do we do that? I mean, it comes back to the levers that we've talked about: case growth with a particular emphasis on local case growth; managing the margins; utilizing a lot of the tools, many of which are technology -- based today; and taking a good, hard look at where our potential is in terms of territories within each district, within each OpCo. So assessing the opportunity for growth by territory, by district, by OpCo; taking advantage of some of the revenue management tools that Tom and his teams are -- have put in place over the last year that are just now beginning to mature; continue to utilize the category management process both from leveraging our spend but also bringing innovation to that product; staying close to our customers; refining our customer insight where -- to be as current that we possibly can in terms of what the needs of those operators are as they face the challenges. So you have to start with gross profit and your ability to grow those dollars. And we've done a nice job there, and I expect us to continue to do well. With that said, as I said in terms of the pillars of our strategy, we need to be more productive in everything we do. And we've set some goals out there, and certainly running the business at a flat cost per case for yet another year here is a very appropriate yet aggressive goal, and it's going to be paramount for us to have success this year to do that. So we've got some good momentum there in the supply chain. We're managing our SG&A very well. So I feel very good about our corporate spend as well. We're still spending some money in business technology to kind of create those tools that we've been talking about year in particular on the commercial side. So I think we're spending the money in the right place. Over time, we'll continue to flatten out that corporate spend, try to keep the flat cost per case -- keep cost per case flat in the field. And that combination of good, solid gross profit growth and well-managed expenses should serve us very well.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the one thing I'd just add to that, even -- if you think about the model and how we looked at that spread between gross profit dollars and operating expense dollars, I think one of the things we've remained focused on is that delta between those 2
componenttext: I think the one thing I'd just add to that, even -- if you think about the model and how we looked at that spread between gross profit dollars and operating expense dollars, I think one of the things we've remained focused on is that delta between those 2. And so even in times when we've had some impact of deflation on the gross profit dollars, again we've continued to focus on driving the expenses to where we look at that spread. And again, on a year-to-date basis, we're up a little over 1.5% in terms of that delta between those 2. And so the only other thing I may call out is just to think about -- because that's certainly the way we think about that. And again, whether deflation goes up or down, that relative spread between the 2 is -- certainly, keep our remodel is [ph] something we've done really well on, the point Bill just made.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think the difference in this conversation we're having today versus 3, 4, 5 years ago is what I spoke to in terms of the foundation that we built with a lot of our transformative work, a lot of the initiatives that we've put in place. We have t
componenttext: Yes, and I think the difference in this conversation we're having today versus 3, 4, 5 years ago is what I spoke to in terms of the foundation that we built with a lot of our transformative work, a lot of the initiatives that we've put in place. We have tools today. We have structure. We have the right people to do this. It's not easy. It's still a very competitive environment out there. But we're much better positioned today to accomplish these things than we were 5 years ago.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And within that, you talked about the good work on the digital platform. Where do you think your systems are relative to peers'? And does the shift away from SAP change your ability to implement some of these tools?
componenttext: And within that, you talked about the good work on the digital platform. Where do you think your systems are relative to peers'? And does the shift away from SAP change your ability to implement some of these tools?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, a big part of our ongoing strategy here was to reallocate our -- what we call our business technology spend more to the customer-facing side of the business. So I think the direction is right. The spend is right. We're making good strides.
componenttext: Well, clearly, a big part of our ongoing strategy here was to reallocate our -- what we call our business technology spend more to the customer-facing side of the business. So I think the direction is right. The spend is right. We're making good strides. But we've got some work to do to get the -- not just the digital platform but all the tools we use behind the scenes both to operate the business and assess the performance of the business. We still have some good work to do here to improve, and that will be a perpetual opportunity. So good work to do, but I think strategically we're spending the money in the right place, and we'll continue to invest appropriately in that part of our business.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice end to the year, guys. Wanted to ask about the M&A landscape. And in particular, with your -- more of an entry into the fresh and the ethnic products, Trinity, North Star, to name a couple this year. Just kind of how you feel your traction's going, w
componenttext: Nice end to the year, guys. Wanted to ask about the M&A landscape. And in particular, with your -- more of an entry into the fresh and the ethnic products, Trinity, North Star, to name a couple this year. Just kind of how you feel your traction's going, where you are from an assortment standpoint and how that kind of factors into your thoughts as you look at any potential further opportunities going forward.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think over the last several years, Vinny, as you know, we've done a lot with special meats, specialty produce, guest supply in terms of bringing those businesses into our company. They're now what we think of as core; 5 or 10 years ago, they would
componenttext: Well, I think over the last several years, Vinny, as you know, we've done a lot with special meats, specialty produce, guest supply in terms of bringing those businesses into our company. They're now what we think of as core; 5 or 10 years ago, they would have been adjacencies. So certainly, we've got the foundation there as well. And what you've seen here over the last 3 to 5 years is we're integrating it much better. I'll let Tom speak a little more specifically, but there's still opportunity out there in particular on the geographic side, I think, where we have some holes we'd love to fill in geographically. But good momentum with the recent acquisitions.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I'll just add, Vinny, that, as Bill said, we really view those specialty areas now being more core to our business. And I think the -- our ability to round that portfolio of businesses out across the U.S. will create those opportunities like
componenttext: Yes, I think I'll just add, Vinny, that, as Bill said, we really view those specialty areas now being more core to our business. And I think the -- our ability to round that portfolio of businesses out across the U.S. will create those opportunities like with North Star in Florida. And so we'll continue to look for those opportunities as they come up and -- but believe that's an important part of our growth. This whole fresh, the local focus that you keep hearing about and seeing out there is something that we are very focused on through both our produce and specialty meat and seafood companies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And maybe just a superfast follow-up here on the ERP, the 12 that are being converted back to the enhanced ERP systems. I think you were at kind of the first, second one a couple of months ago. Just a quick update there where you are in that
componenttext: Okay, great. And maybe just a superfast follow-up here on the ERP, the 12 that are being converted back to the enhanced ERP systems. I think you were at kind of the first, second one a couple of months ago. Just a quick update there where you are in that process.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a 12-month process. And we've done one. It went very well, and we're on schedule. So we're in a good place.
componenttext: Yes, it's a 12-month process. And we've done one. It went very well, and we're on schedule. So we're in a good place.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe from JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Obviously, you ended the year at your -- at a gross margin high for the year, and it's actually one of your highest gross margins that you've had in many years. So when we think about fiscal '17, is the right run rate of cost of goods sold or gross
componenttext: Great. Obviously, you ended the year at your -- at a gross margin high for the year, and it's actually one of your highest gross margins that you've had in many years. So when we think about fiscal '17, is the right run rate of cost of goods sold or gross margins, is it the fourth quarter? Or should we still consider that you can -- that year-on-year might play an effect as opposed to taking just that fourth quarter result and running that forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would never take one quarter and extrapolate too much, John. I think you look at the year, you look at the trends, you look at the environment that we've just described. And obviously, we have plans to grow the gross profit and manage expenses very well
componenttext: I would never take one quarter and extrapolate too much, John. I think you look at the year, you look at the trends, you look at the environment that we've just described. And obviously, we have plans to grow the gross profit and manage expenses very well. But I wouldn't trend anything off of one quarter, good or bad.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: And are you at the level when you do look at that percent where you're kind of in a competitively good place where it's a good gross margin for you and in terms of the relative value that your customers are getting and how your competition is competing ag
componenttext: And are you at the level when you do look at that percent where you're kind of in a competitively good place where it's a good gross margin for you and in terms of the relative value that your customers are getting and how your competition is competing against you? In other words, is there any risk like we've seen in previous periods that some of your competition starts to use their gross margin in an effort to gain traffic share?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 15, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can speak for that. I mean, as I've said, I think, for a long, long time, it's a very competitive environment out there. There's a lot of salespeople out there in the street and a lot of very sophisticated customers. So pricing is always going to be a k
componenttext: I can speak for that. I mean, as I've said, I think, for a long, long time, it's a very competitive environment out there. There's a lot of salespeople out there in the street and a lot of very sophisticated customers. So pricing is always going to be a key part of how customers look at value. I think what you heard Tom say is as we look at revenue management, which pricing is a component but not the only component, we're getting better in terms of strategically and tactically facing up with each customer one-on-one and really understanding what is key for them. But we have the tools to make sure we're highly competitive in our key items but also where there's opportunity to grow. So when you look at our economic model, it's really about having the right price for the right item and the right day for that customer, for the street business and remain very competitive with our contract customers. And to do that, you need to continue to take costs out to become more efficient. So I wouldn't say there's anything in particular going on right now that's different than what we've experienced over the last 2 or 3 years, and that I wouldn't -- and I also think we still have opportunity to be more consistent in our pricing, and that should be a win for our customers and win for us.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions.I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell, Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions.
I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. Please go ahead.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lindsay. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Lindsay. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made during this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, and actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information about factors that could cause results to differ from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings. This includes, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended July 2, 2016, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. The reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the corresponding GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation slides and can also be found in the Investors section of our website.
Additionally, the results for our first quarter fiscal 2017 incorporate for the first time the financial performance of the newly acquired Brakes Group. As such, we will reference throughout our presentation today Sysco's financial results both including and excluding this acquisition. [Operator Instructions]
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone.I'm very pleased with our start in fiscal 2017. And this morning, we reported strong first quarter financial results. These results reflect our relentless focus on improving our customers' experience with Sysc
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone.
I'm very pleased with our start in fiscal 2017. And this morning, we reported strong first quarter financial results. These results reflect our relentless focus on improving our customers' experience with Sysco, the benefits of several key business initiatives that we have implemented over the past few years and the contributions from our new colleagues at Brakes who joined Sysco in early July.
For the quarter and excluding the impact of Brakes, sales grew 1%, gross profit grew 5%, while operating expense grew less than 2%, which resulted in adjusted operating income growth of 15%. After reflecting the business results of Brakes, adjusted operating income grew 24% to $627 million and adjusted earnings per share grew to $0.67.
While we benefited from some favorable year-over-year expense comparisons which Joel will touch on in a few minutes, these results were achieved in an uneven economic environment that is impacting our customers' business. Some metrics reflect positive implications for longer-term consumer demand such as steadying unemployment levels, modest GDP growth, increased consumer confidence and healthy momentum in the housing market.
However, the restaurant industry, which represents approximately 60% of the foodservice market, is not currently experiencing the level of growth we have seen in recent quarters. Restaurant traffic continues to show year-over-year declines and restaurant spend has decelerated as well. More specifically, recent data from both NPD and KNAPP-TRACK show weakening overall sales trends.
That said, we continue to execute our business plan and key initiatives very well. I am pleased with our progress to-date toward the achievement of our 3-year financial goals and I remain confident in our ability to accomplish our strategic objectives over the long-term.
Our improved and increasingly consistent performance for the past 2 years is attributed to multiyear foundational work we have carried out in customer insights, category management, revenue management, supply chain efficiencies and administrative expense management. The benefits of these work streams have positioned us to continue to effectively support the needs of our customers and profitably leverage our volume growth.
Moving forward, we will build on this momentum by maintaining our customer-centric approach while focusing on targeted, disciplined and profitable growth. Both Tom and Joel will provide more detail about these specific initiatives we are currently implementing and the related benefits.
Turning to the Brakes transaction. We continue to work closely with our experienced and talented leadership team to support their growth, drive after transformative initiatives and identify additional acquisition opportunities. I'm very excited about the long-term benefits that this business will provide Sysco.
In summary, we are off to a good start to fiscal 2017 and I'm encouraged with the progress we are making as we approach the midpoint of our 3-year plan. I'm especially appreciative of the efforts and contributions from all 65,000 of our associates as we strive to fully realize our vision for Sysco: to be our customers' most valued and trusted business partner.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom Bené, Sysco's President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone.Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect solid operating performance and continued progress against several of our key multiyear initiatives. Our favorable operating performance continues to be
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone.
Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect solid operating performance and continued progress against several of our key multiyear initiatives. Our favorable operating performance continues to be driven by our ongoing focus on the key levers of our 3-year plan, including delivering accelerated case growth through our focus on local customers, improving gross margins and managing overall expenses, both in our supply chain and administrative functions.
This morning, I'll be providing an update on our business results based on our new segment reporting structure, which highlights U.S. Foodservice operations, International Foodservice operations, SYGMA and all other.
During the quarter, U.S. Foodservice operations, which is primarily comprised of U.S. Broadline, specialty meat, FreshPoint and our European Imports business, grew sales 0.8%, driven by overall case growth in the U.S. Broadline of 1.8%, with local cases driving our growth at 1.9%.
Gross profit in U.S. Foodservice operations grew 4.3% for the quarter and gross margin increased 68 basis points, driven by a combination of factors including our ongoing category management efforts, which is how we now go-to-market with an improved product assortment and centralized approach for a majority of our product procurement, which in turn helps us drive out costs for ourselves and our suppliers; second, improved Sysco Brand performance with our local customers; the deployment of a suite of revenue management tools and processes that bring more discipline to our sales and merchandising teams and, ultimately, more consistent pricing to our customers; and the impact of deflation.
During the quarter, we continued to focus our sales teams on initiatives and activities that will help our customers succeed and grow their business. We have been implementing a variety of sales training and support tools that build overall capability within our selling organization. And we have restructured some of the work within that organization to both free up our marketing associates' time and provide access to our targeted resources to better support our customers.
These efforts, in conjunction with ongoing enhancements to our e-commerce tools which allow our customers to choose how they place their orders with Sysco, are enabling us to better leverage our marketing associates to spend more time supporting our customers with unique programs, innovative products and other business-building solutions.
From a cost perspective, our expense management for the quarter was solid and remains a key area of focus for us moving forward. For U.S. Foodservice operations during the first quarter, we limited total adjusted operating expense growth to 1.8%. Our supply chain performance is progressing well and we are seeing positive momentum from our productivity initiatives and continuing process improvements that are driving efficiencies.
For U.S. Broadline, cost per case improved by $0.04 for the quarter and, on a fuel price-neutral basis, cost per case was flat. The continuous improvement efforts in our facilities and the continued investment in training for our warehouse associates and drivers has allowed us to build further capability throughout our supply chain. One such example is the implementation of a labor forecasting tool that enables us to proactively manage hours at our facilities based on the anticipated workload for each shift. We also remain on track to deliver our previously communicated administrative cost reductions, both in corporate and within the operations.
Moving to International Foodservice operations, which is made up of Canada, Europe, Bahamas, International Food Group and our joint ventures in Mexico and Costa Rica. Sales were up $1.3 billion and adjusted operating income increased $50 million, both driven by our recent acquisition of the Brakes Group. We appreciate the Brakes Group early performance and continue to look forward to working with the management team on achieving our collective plans in the future.
During the quarter, Brakes performed reasonably well in the U.K. amidst a challenging environment and performance in both brands in Sweden was relatively strong. Our business in Canada is off to a good start for the fiscal year as we are effectively managing cost within a deflationary and somewhat soft market environment. And lastly, our joint ventures in both Costa Rica and Mexico had solid performance in the first quarter of fiscal year 2017.
SYGMA continues to make progress against their key business initiatives and had 4% sales growth for the first quarter. We continue to feel confident in their ability to deliver their full year growth goals and objectives.
In summary, our customer and operational strategies are solidly aligned around improving our customers' experience, engaging our associates at the highest level to improve execution and delivering our financial objectives as part of our 3-year plan. We have continued to make significant progress in all areas for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, and I remain optimistic about the programs and processes we are putting in place that will enable our future success.
Now I'll turn the call over to Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone.As Bill and Tom had mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the first quarter. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including local solid case growth, strong gross
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone.
As Bill and Tom had mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the first quarter. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including local solid case growth, strong gross profit dollar growth and good cost management as well as a solid contribution from Brakes. The results that I'll cover for you this morning include Brakes, which significantly impacted our results.
In summary, for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, sales grew 11.2%, gross profit dollars grew 20.3%, operating expense growth was 19.2%, all of which resulted in adjusted operating income growth of 23.8% and our adjusted earnings per share grew 28.8%. Sales during the quarter were positively impacted by the inclusion of Brakes in our results, though partially offset by deflation of 2.2% in our legacy Sysco business.
Continuing with gross profit and gross margins beyond the addition of Brakes, the key drivers of improvement included category management, revenue management, higher Sysco Brand penetration in our local business and deflation. The categories impacted most by deflation continue to be the Center of the Plate, protein and dairy. We expect the trend to continue into calendar 2017. That said, we continue to manage this environment effectively as evidenced by our strong gross profit dollar growth.
The increasing expenses during the quarter beyond the addition of Brakes were mainly driven by the previously mentioned higher case volumes and a timing shift of expenses related to our option grants from the second quarter into the first and was partially offset by various decreases in indirect spend, fuel costs, favorable comparisons to the prior year which included planned investments and technology spend related to our 3-year plan and foreign exchange translation.
As it relates to taxes, our effective tax rate in the first quarter was 32.9% compared to 36.3% in the prior year period. The decrease in tax rate is driven by tax credits, lower tax rates in the U.K. due to new tax laws that were recently passed and the mix of business as we grow in lower rate jurisdictions. Compared to the prior year, adjusted net earnings grew 20.7%.
Cash flow from operations was $249 million, which is $510 million higher compared to the same period last year. Free cash flow was $111 million, which is $492 million higher compared to the same period last year. The significant improvements in both are due mainly to improved working capital performance and payments made on the prior year related to the proposed merger with US Foods.
Net CapEx for the quarter was $138 million.
I'm pleased with our net working capital performance for the quarter. We had a net 2-day improvement versus the prior year and a 2.8-day improvement versus fiscal 2015 and are making good progress towards our 3-year goal of a 4-day improvement. These improvements are driven primarily by improvements of all 3 phases of working capital: payables, receivables and inventory.
Our first quarter results included some certain items that were mostly related to the Brakes acquisition, including amortization associated with the transaction. As a reminder, in the prior year, we had significant amount of certain items primarily related to the termination of the proposed merger with US Foods.
Now I'd like to transition to 3 business updates. First, regarding Brakes. As a reminder, we initially guided that the acquisition will be modestly accretive to fiscal 2017 earnings per share by low to mid-single digits. We are now updating that guidance due to finalizing the treatment of amortization as a certain item and believe this acquisition will be accretive to adjusted earnings per share by high single digits in fiscal 2017, with acceleration in subsequent years assuming constant currency.
For the first quarter, Brakes was approximately $0.04 accretive to our business on an adjusted basis. It is important to note that Brakes' business does have some seasonality as the performance is more heavily weighted to the first half of the year. Accordingly, we do not expect the same accretion each quarter, in particular in quarter number 3.
Second, regarding fuel expense. We expect the favorability we've had over the past few quarters to begin to lap in November.
Separately, we are enhancing our fuel strategy. In the past, we used a third party to forward buy fixed price contracts approximately 12 months out. Going forward, we are transitioning the management of our fuel expense by using derivatives to hedge our exposure. By separating the management of our fuel purchases from our risk management, we will allow for more effective management of the risks. We'll continue to cover approximately 2/3 of our needs with hedges in place to minimize volatility in price.
Finally, we are announcing today the upsizing of our credit facility from $1.5 billion to $2 billion and we'll upsize our commercial paper lines accordingly to provide greater liquidity to support our growing business.
In summary, we had a quality quarter reflecting continued momentum from our underlying business, including solid local case growth, strong gross profit dollar growth and good cost management. That said, we have more work to do in order to achieve the full financial objectives of our 3-year plan. We are committed to serving our customers and delivering a high level of execution in all areas of our business that improve our financial performance in both the near and long-term. I'm confident in our ability to continue to execute our plan.
Operator, we are now ready for Q&A.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: It's actually Ryan Gilligan on for Karen. I guess, first off, can you just give us the bridge and year-over-year change in gross margins in the International segment? It seems like Brakes is driving a lot of that improvement and we're just wondering if this is a new level of gross margin that we should expect, if there's any onetime impacts in there.

And generally, I would tell you that, in Europe, gross margins are higher and the expenses are higher.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have a lot of good work going on over there in their own transformation, as we've spoken to a little bit before so there's opportunity in the supply chain. They're doing some things with their warehouses where they're moving from multiple wareh
componenttext: Well, they have a lot of good work going on over there in their own transformation, as we've spoken to a little bit before so there's opportunity in the supply chain. They're doing some things with their warehouses where they're moving from multiple warehouses to service some market to one, which is what we see. And there's always opportunities on the administrative side of the business. So I think there will be opportunities that's a big part of their plan. And I don't know that they'll get to our number necessarily because they have a different market. But there's certainly upside there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, that's helpful. And I guess just last question, can you comment on how cases trended throughout the quarter and the outlook for them going forward, I guess, just given that comparisons start to get tougher these next 2 quarters?
componenttext: Got it, that's helpful. And I guess just last question, can you comment on how cases trended throughout the quarter and the outlook for them going forward, I guess, just given that comparisons start to get tougher these next 2 quarters?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Tom. So as I said, the local cases were up 1.9% in U.S. Broadline. And yes, that's been a little above falloff from what we'd experienced in the last couple of quarters of fiscal year '16. I think based on what we're seeing in the restaurant se
componenttext: So this is Tom. So as I said, the local cases were up 1.9% in U.S. Broadline. And yes, that's been a little above falloff from what we'd experienced in the last couple of quarters of fiscal year '16. I think based on what we're seeing in the restaurant segment, I think we believe it will be -- continue to be a slight decline from what it's been at the end of last year, but we still feel fairly confident we'll see continued case growth in the local segment of our business. We're very focused on, as Bill said in his comments, profitable growth, and we want to make sure that we're focused on those right customer segments but we still believe we can grow our local cases.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just start with a follow-up to that last question? Could you just help us understand what you're seeing from an organic case growth standpoint? I don't know how -- if you could sort of frame that for us at all relative to the 1.8% and the 1.9%? Just
componenttext: Can I just start with a follow-up to that last question? Could you just help us understand what you're seeing from an organic case growth standpoint? I don't know how -- if you could sort of frame that for us at all relative to the 1.8% and the 1.9%? Just curious as to the role that acquisitions are playing into this.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start and I'm going to let Joel and Tom maybe add some color here. But I would say that is largely the organic growth that we're experiencing. What Tom said was if you go back a year, I think we were in the mid-2s, the high 2s in different qu
componenttext: Well, let me start and I'm going to let Joel and Tom maybe add some color here. But I would say that is largely the organic growth that we're experiencing. What Tom said was if you go back a year, I think we were in the mid-2s, the high 2s in different quarters, not every quarter was the same. So if you go back to my comments, basically, we're seeing some slowness out there, soft and I guess is the better word in terms of overall growth in the restaurant segment and ours is off a little bit as well. So it just reinforces the importance of solidifying those customer relationships and getting penetration and where there's that opportunity where customers are growing as well as continue to stay really locked in on retaining our customers and identifying opportunities as we go along. So the 1.8% and 1.9% is largely organic growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's very helpful. And just one second question here that I wanted to ask you about, and I kind of asked about it last quarter too. But you maintained your 3-year target, your results so far had been really impressive. I mean, this is a gre
componenttext: Okay, great. That's very helpful. And just one second question here that I wanted to ask you about, and I kind of asked about it last quarter too. But you maintained your 3-year target, your results so far had been really impressive. I mean, this is a great quarter. Can you just talk to us about how you're thinking about that goal at this point, whether you think we'll get an update at some point relatively soon? And as we just sort of sit back and try to consider how things play out from here, Bill, what are the moving parts that we should really be thinking about from here sort of like good or bad going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the moving parts, we've touched on here just now. I think we're seeing some softness out there. I think other people are seeing the same thing on a relative basis. And so we're very focused on trying to get our case growth back up over 2%. I
componenttext: Well, I think the moving parts, we've touched on here just now. I think we're seeing some softness out there. I think other people are seeing the same thing on a relative basis. And so we're very focused on trying to get our case growth back up over 2%. I think that's very important. We're real pleased with how we're managing the margins and still growing the business and taking care of our customers in the right way. And a lot of the steps we took back in the spring to initiate deeper expense reductions are benefiting us right now. So I think the things that we can influence and control, we're doing a really good job with. We're probably a little cautious in terms of the overall macro out there for our customers. We still got 2 points of deflation out there, largely driven by those  [indiscernible] category so those will be 2 areas where we're probably a little bit cautious. Obviously, -- we're in our third year in of earnings growth, and I think this is the fourth quarter of double-digit earnings growth on an adjusted basis, so obviously the bar gets higher and we're ready for that, so we feel very good overall by what we're doing. A little cautious on the environment. I think to your first question, the way I'm looking at that is we're 1 quarter into this year, and we're just not quite to the halfway point of the 3-year plan. So I'm going to get a little further into this year and get halfway through the 3-year plan, and then I think we'll be able to reassess where we are on the goals.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: So on the M&A impact in the quarter, first of all, was there any M&A impact to U.S. Broadline's beyond Brakes? And then secondly for Brakes, total sales came in a bit higher than I thought. Maybe you could talk about just volume trends there and what the impact of FX was. And just with the high single-digit accretion for the year, what are you anticipating for total sales growth for the year for Brakes?

componenttext: Again, we're not going to get into bridges or trends on individual businesses or segments. But I think as Tom pointed out, I'm going to let Tom speak to this. Obviously, there' some challenges in the U.K. right now. We thought the Brakes Group performed well, given the environment and very nicely in France and Sweden. I think that's as much as I probably can add right now. Tom, you got anything?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe to answer your first question too, Zach. The very little impact in U.S. cases from the acquisitions, as we mentioned a minute ago, so those numbers were basically kind of organic growth numbers. And the only thing I'd add on Brakes is that we t
componenttext: Yes, maybe to answer your first question too, Zach. The very little impact in U.S. cases from the acquisitions, as we mentioned a minute ago, so those numbers were basically kind of organic growth numbers. And the only thing I'd add on Brakes is that we think the team's off to a really good start. Bill mentioned the transformational initiatives they've been operating against are all moving along nicely. And I think we feel very comfortable with overall how that business is performing. And the U.K. certainly got some bumpiness in the economy both, driven by a lot of things going on over there right now. And I think we feel very comfortable with where they're at and how they're [indiscernible].

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would just add. I mean, you asked about the FX part of that. Obviously, the weakening Sterling certainly plays into this so there is some FX impact. But on an aggregate basis to the organization, we had fairly minor impact from FX for this quar
componenttext: Yes, and I would just add. I mean, you asked about the FX part of that. Obviously, the weakening Sterling certainly plays into this so there is some FX impact. But on an aggregate basis to the organization, we had fairly minor impact from FX for this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then just, I guess, let's all take it on a high level here on the operating environment. Could you comment on the -- just a little bit about underlying restaurant trends. With them being a little choppy, are you seeing any
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then just, I guess, let's all take it on a high level here on the operating environment. Could you comment on the -- just a little bit about underlying restaurant trends. With them being a little choppy, are you seeing any change to the competitive environment here, particularly with the impact of deflation versus food away from home -- or food at home widening a little bit? Are you seeing anything as far as just continued challenges for your customers and then competition from your peers?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the challenges are what I'd referenced -- you've got several quarters in a row now where traffic is actually down. And while the spend is up, it's not rising at the same rate it was rising. So yes, there's currently a softening out there. I
componenttext: Well, I think the challenges are what I'd referenced -- you've got several quarters in a row now where traffic is actually down. And while the spend is up, it's not rising at the same rate it was rising. So yes, there's currently a softening out there. I mean, whether it's because of the election or relative pricing and between grocery store and restaurants, what others kind of critiqued. I think there's ebbs and flows in many cycles of economies and I think we're going through that right now. But I think it just puts a premium on quality operators, both in terms of our customer base as well as ourselves. And we feel good about what we're doing and we're doing everything we can to support our customers. As far as the competitive environment, I wouldn't say there's any change. It's acutely competitive as we've talked about before. All different types of competitors out there. We feel we're very well positioned. It does play out differently in some markets but overall, I'd say it's about the same.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe starting a question for Tom. When you think about moving case growth back up, is there are a lot of clear things you can do to help your customers stimulate demand? Or is it really more taking share from other distributors in the environment we'r
componenttext: So maybe starting a question for Tom. When you think about moving case growth back up, is there are a lot of clear things you can do to help your customers stimulate demand? Or is it really more taking share from other distributors in the environment we're in today?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say I'm not sure there's a lot word we can do to help stimulate demand. What we can do is make sure that each of our customers is operating as effectively as they can, and that they've got obviously the right products and the right pricing so th
componenttext: Well, I'd say I'm not sure there's a lot word we can do to help stimulate demand. What we can do is make sure that each of our customers is operating as effectively as they can, and that they've got obviously the right products and the right pricing so that they can be successful. But as far as stimulating demand into their -- or traffic into their locations, that's a little bit harder from where we sit. But I think there's a lot we are doing to help them be successful and I think that's we continue to focus, and we believe very strongly that's much responsibility as they are still help ensure that healthy and effective in what they're doing. And obviously, the tools that we bring them every day, I think, makes a big difference there. What was the second part of your question?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it was really that -- you want to get case growth back up, is it more market share-driven, which, I guess, do you think from what you can see, is your share -- the rate at which you're taking share from others in the space, maybe the smaller guys, i
componenttext: Well, it was really that -- you want to get case growth back up, is it more market share-driven, which, I guess, do you think from what you can see, is your share -- the rate at which you're taking share from others in the space, maybe the smaller guys, is that -- it looks like it's accelerating. Is that fair?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard for us to obviously know that directly because as you know, lots of competitors in this environment. We certainly believe we're continuing to grow at least at the industry, if not outpacing that. As we've talked for the last couple
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard for us to obviously know that directly because as you know, lots of competitors in this environment. We certainly believe we're continuing to grow at least at the industry, if not outpacing that. As we've talked for the last couple of years, we've tried to focus our efforts in a couple of areas. One, where there's natural growth taking place. We talked in the past about some of the segments where you're seeing growth, whether it be the Hispanic Latino segment out there, where we've really focused some of our energy and efforts to provide support to those operators or certainly looking at geographies where we've got opportunities. So I think we continue to execute our strategy and we feel like it's working. And we're hopefully gaining share from lots of different places based on how well we're taking care of our customers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just lastly, if you think about supermarket foodservice, maybe just remind us kind of relative size of that business for you, it's still pretty small I think. And where you think as you look out 3, 5 years or longer, how much bigger ca
componenttext: All right. And then just lastly, if you think about supermarket foodservice, maybe just remind us kind of relative size of that business for you, it's still pretty small I think. And where you think as you look out 3, 5 years or longer, how much bigger can that get?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is still relatively small for us. I don't have the exact numbers from Technomic, but I think that they say that, that  retail segment, I think, is about 7% of the market, if my guess is -- if memory serves me right. I think that for us, we certai
componenttext: Well, it is still relatively small for us. I don't have the exact numbers from Technomic, but I think that they say that, that  retail segment, I think, is about 7% of the market, if my guess is -- if memory serves me right. I think that for us, we certainly have opportunity to grow there. I think it really is a matter of what's the best way for us to grow there. We talked a couple of years ago about our relationship with Kroger. We feel like we continue to have opportunity as they grow in that space. But I think it really comes down to how consumers decide to purchase their food away from home. And that retail segment certainly, I know, is a big focus for a lot of the retails pick up maybe some more share from their consumer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
