componenttext: Curious if you could just talk a little bit about the local case growth. I know it's hard to really know exactly how much the market is growing there. But do you feel like you took some share there? I realize it's slow but still pretty solid, so just any color around that 1.9%.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we're just talking, I feel like it really is hard. We don't have a good view for the entire market. I'd say what we continue to see is we're getting growth from new customers. We are seeing a little bit of softness in some of the penetration of existin
componenttext: As we're just talking, I feel like it really is hard. We don't have a good view for the entire market. I'd say what we continue to see is we're getting growth from new customers. We are seeing a little bit of softness in some of the penetration of existing customers. We think that might be driven by some of the more external information that's out there around restaurant traffic. But broadly speaking, we feel like we're just serving the broader independent restaurant segment well. And as we do that, we probably are gaining some share but it's really hard to tell exactly where that might be coming from.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I guess just another question on the 3-year target. So I realize you may not be updating those or feel the need to update those. But I guess, given that Brakes is now just a significant part of the story over the next couple of years, do
componenttext: Got it. And then, I guess just another question on the 3-year target. So I realize you may not be updating those or feel the need to update those. But I guess, given that Brakes is now just a significant part of the story over the next couple of years, do you have any color just on how we should think about that 3-year target with Brakes included?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I'm going to start and I'll let Joel give you a little more on this. So one of the reasons we are providing more [indiscernible] this time on the segment information is to make sure that we're clear on the international versus the U.S. And then wha
componenttext: Kelly, I'm going to start and I'll let Joel give you a little more on this. So one of the reasons we are providing more [indiscernible] this time on the segment information is to make sure that we're clear on the international versus the U.S. And then what we will do, so we have a 3-year target and we have a 3-year goal. We will continue to track that in calls like this and investor presentations periodically and give you some sense on where we are in that original goal for the businesses that existed at that time and then how we're doing on the rest of it. So we're going to simultaneously track that 3-year goal and also begin to build a new 3-year plan here over the next few months. And then we'll put that out to you at some point in calendar '17.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think Kelly, the thing I would add to that is it's just as a reminder, we -- part of this target was to be very clear with all of you in the way that we are holding our sales accountable ultimately hold us accountable is this very clear specifi
componenttext: Yes, and I think Kelly, the thing I would add to that is it's just as a reminder, we -- part of this target was to be very clear with all of you in the way that we are holding our sales accountable ultimately hold us accountable is this very clear specific target for the legacy business. And so as we go through this, again, what you can expect from us is to continue to have a very clear delineation, again both how we look at the organization as a whole but continued very clear tracking on the things that we talked about at our original Investor Day and again, tracking our target against that. So that will be hopefully very clear and separate out for all of you.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of reconcile, obviously, we know that there were some puts and takes with Brakes and tax and all that type of stuff this quarter. But you did several times, of course, again say today about the softening from the macro, which you had a
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of reconcile, obviously, we know that there were some puts and takes with Brakes and tax and all that type of stuff this quarter. But you did several times, of course, again say today about the softening from the macro, which you had alluded to last quarter as well. So I guess maybe any more color you can give on that restaurant softness in terms of any particular types of customers or geographies? And kind of going forward, do you expect things to get kind of sequentially worse or more, just kind of roughly stay around these levels, which are off the kind of previous highs?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start. Look, the one thing I would point us to is on an adjusted basis, if you exclude the impact of Brakes, we grew our operating income 15%. And that's the fourth quarter in a row where we've had double-digit increases on adjusted operating income.
componenttext: I'll start. Look, the one thing I would point us to is on an adjusted basis, if you exclude the impact of Brakes, we grew our operating income 15%. And that's the fourth quarter in a row where we've had double-digit increases on adjusted operating income. So I think that what we feel good about and hopefully what that tells others is whether we've got 2.5% or 3% case growth or 1.5% to 2% case growth, we're doing everything we can on the top line as well as how we manage it from there to deliver on our commitment. And so at this point, we feel very good about how we're managing the environment. In terms of where it goes from here, I can just tell you internally, Tom and his team are very, very focused on penetration, improved retention and where appropriate, bringing on new quality customers. So we're doing everything we can in a disciplined way to grow the top line. But clearly, it puts a premium on managing our expenses here and continue to find ways to price in a way that works for us as well as our customers. So that's the part we can control and influence. As far as where the market goes, it's really hard to call right now, given everything's going on in the country. But we're preparing for where we're at. I think the hopefully get somewhat better. But we're not really on the business of making those projections.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe just a quick follow-up on Brakes specifically. In the past, I think we were all kind of given the impression that at this point at least, it was more or less kind of stay on its own, largely kind of be run separately over there
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Maybe just a quick follow-up on Brakes specifically. In the past, I think we were all kind of given the impression that at this point at least, it was more or less kind of stay on its own, largely kind of be run separately over there. Can you guys, I know it's still early, but can you give us maybe a qualitative sense as kind of the last few months how that overall integration is going, and if you think there are opportunities to kind of bring it more under kind of one roof over time?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, the way we're looking at this strategically is there's a lot of exciting things about Brakes. We've talked about quality of their team, the part of Europe that they now bring us into and our ability to use that business as a platform for future acq
componenttext: Again, the way we're looking at this strategically is there's a lot of exciting things about Brakes. We've talked about quality of their team, the part of Europe that they now bring us into and our ability to use that business as a platform for future acquisition growth and a lot of other things. So strategically, the way we look at it is it's [indiscernible] candidate, the 2 foundational parts of our international business. And we expect it to continue to grow and to allow us to continue to find ways to do acquisitions. And that's basically it from my perspective. Joel, do you want to add something?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what I would just say a little bit of color, I mean, we certainly have regular ongoing conversation and business reviews with their team. But again, as Bill mentioned just to remind you, when we talked about this the deal initially is again,
componenttext: Yes, I think what I would just say a little bit of color, I mean, we certainly have regular ongoing conversation and business reviews with their team. But again, as Bill mentioned just to remind you, when we talked about this the deal initially is again, we -- they have a very strong engine team. We feel really good about their people and the work that they're doing that continue to transform their business. We certainly see that again with an opportunity around that business stand-alone overlap end [indiscernible] we have certainly continue to look for opportunities though to [indiscernible] upside in the deal. But I would just tell you again, a lot of good ongoing dialogue but certainly got a strong management team running that business as a stand-alone entity.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan with Bank of America.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about gross margin excluding Brakes. Still up very significantly in the quarter, and so I wanted to get your sense on what were the key drivers? You mentioned 4. How would you rank them during the quarter specifically? And also how di
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about gross margin excluding Brakes. Still up very significantly in the quarter, and so I wanted to get your sense on what were the key drivers? You mentioned 4. How would you rank them during the quarter specifically? And also how did deflation impact the gross margin this quarter?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. Let me -- I did talk about 4 different drivers, and I think we continue to believe each of those is contributing to the work we're doing. [indiscernible] deflation component, we know it certainly impacts the gross margin percent, but it's als
componenttext: This is Tom. Let me -- I did talk about 4 different drivers, and I think we continue to believe each of those is contributing to the work we're doing. [indiscernible] deflation component, we know it certainly impacts the gross margin percent, but it's also, I think probably most important to think about those other 3 areas that we're focused on because that's how we manage the dollar side of it. Category management continues to be a very positive for us. As you know, we've been basically in that operating model now for the last 3 years and it's why we've gone through, I'd say the major cycle with that. We continue to work with our suppliers, and we look at long-term partnerships that continue to provide value for us and ultimately for our customers. So category management continues to be a very important part of what we do and how we operate. Revenue management has been something that now is fully deployed within our organization. And I think we've got a really good set of processes and tools and ultimately routines for our sales and merchandising teams to leverage in the marketplace. And it allows us to be, I think, a little quicker on our feet and be able to do the things that we need to do to make sure that our customers' pricing is right on a regular basis, and it's driving really more consistency customers as well. And then lastly, partly with the work we're doing category management but on a continued focus on Sysco Brand, which brings value also to our customers and obviously delivers additional profitability for [indiscernible] has been a key driver for us, and we continue to see improvement within [indiscernible] our local customers with our local business. And we again saw an improvement in Sysco Brands last quarter. So really is a combination of all of those and hard for us to kind of tease apart each of them individually, but I can tell you that each of them is definitely playing a role.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add there, Marisa, is the thing I feel the best about here is going back to Tom's prepared comments, we grew the gross profit dollars over 4% in U.S. Foodservice business. So deflation hurts you when you talk about gross profit doll
componenttext: The only thing I would add there, Marisa, is the thing I feel the best about here is going back to Tom's prepared comments, we grew the gross profit dollars over 4% in U.S. Foodservice business. So deflation hurts you when you talk about gross profit dollars. So all those things Tom just outlined, I think, are all key reasons why we're able to do that in an environment where you're looking meaningful deflation.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. If I could follow up on the revenue management, now that it's fully deployed, when do you anticipate seeing more of the benefit flow through?
componenttext: Got it. If I could follow up on the revenue management, now that it's fully deployed, when do you anticipate seeing more of the benefit flow through?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's -- when I say it's fully deployed, I mean, it's out there now for a couple of quarters. And so I think we're seeing the benefits right now. If you -- if the question is, does that have an end point? I think it's too early to even know t
componenttext: Well, I think it's -- when I say it's fully deployed, I mean, it's out there now for a couple of quarters. And so I think we're seeing the benefits right now. If you -- if the question is, does that have an end point? I think it's too early to even know that. It's an ongoing process that we follow now, and I think it's really more about being disciplined in how we approach pricing in the marketplace.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of with Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, just kind of sticking with the gross profit dollar growth subject here. When I think about your $500 million EBIT growth goal for -- over the next 3 years or through 2018, if you will, can you remind me what the inflation or deflation assumption was
componenttext: Bill, just kind of sticking with the gross profit dollar growth subject here. When I think about your $500 million EBIT growth goal for -- over the next 3 years or through 2018, if you will, can you remind me what the inflation or deflation assumption was originally?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the original model -- this is Joel. That was about a 2%. If you'll recall, we had differential between our volume and sales growth that we rolled out initially talked about that 2% rate.
componenttext: Yes, the original model -- this is Joel. That was about a 2%. If you'll recall, we had differential between our volume and sales growth that we rolled out initially talked about that 2% rate.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of following up to that, now that we're on our fifth quarter of consecutive deflation but also considering how well you guys have been driving your gross profit dollar growth despite this backdrop, how do we think about kind
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, kind of following up to that, now that we're on our fifth quarter of consecutive deflation but also considering how well you guys have been driving your gross profit dollar growth despite this backdrop, how do we think about kind of you guys reaching that ultimate goal? I believe the original mix was somewhere 55% to 65% of that $500 million EBIT growth goal came from gross profit dollar growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I'll start with that and you guys can add in. I think it's -- I think we're still looking at that in a relatively consistent way as we had initially outlined. I think the really important part of this though is to -- one of the things we've t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I'll start with that and you guys can add in. I think it's -- I think we're still looking at that in a relatively consistent way as we had initially outlined. I think the really important part of this though is to -- one of the things we've talked about a bit externally is this gap or this delta between our growth in gross profit dollars and the growth in expense dollars. And so one of the things again, we certainly have done a good job of managing through this deflationary times and still continue to grow of our growth and gross profit dollars. We've also done a good job, I think, of focusing and driving expenses downward as both Joel and Tom had talked about. I think when we looked at that plan and sort the puts and takes of what was going to drive it, we certainly knew we could have had more inflation, could've had less inflation. Some of those factors are what they are. But the reality of it is our continued focus on that gap and that delta between those 2 numbers, I think, is really important.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think where we're at right now, I think we're we've been, to your point, over the last few quarters is we're not on track to hit the sales number. I think that original goal we were looking at 4% sales growth with 2 points of inflation and directio
componenttext: Yes. I think where we're at right now, I think we're we've been, to your point, over the last few quarters is we're not on track to hit the sales number. I think that original goal we were looking at 4% sales growth with 2 points of inflation and directionally about the same amount of GP growth. So we've got to get the GP a different way, and that's what we've been able to do here so far. And we're really encouraged by that as well as managing expenses. So I think it's more of a play on the top line than anything else.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and there's still one final thing I'd add to that is if you'll recall when we increased our targets from $400 million to $500 million, that was primarily again driven by some change in some of the way we viewed our expenses. And so again, if you want
componenttext: Yes, and there's still one final thing I'd add to that is if you'll recall when we increased our targets from $400 million to $500 million, that was primarily again driven by some change in some of the way we viewed our expenses. And so again, if you want to look at that shift again a little bit, is as I mentioned earlier, pretty consistent with the top, a little bit more of a shift toward some of the expense side as we roll out when we increased our targets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's helpful. And then just quick housekeeping one for you, Joel. What's the reasonable tax rate to be assuming on a go forward?
componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And then just quick housekeeping one for you, Joel. What's the reasonable tax rate to be assuming on a go forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think at the end of last year, we guided somewhere in the 35% to 36% range. So with some of the -- one of the things we've talked about at this was actually a tax law change in the U.K. that moved the statutory rate essentially from 18% to 17%.
componenttext: Yes, so I think at the end of last year, we guided somewhere in the 35% to 36% range. So with some of the -- one of the things we've talked about at this was actually a tax law change in the U.K. that moved the statutory rate essentially from 18% to 17%. I would say that would take our view of that probably on the low end of the guidance that we put out before. A couple of things in this quarter, I think, we called out that there were some onetime deals, and so I would say the rate you see in this quarter is a bit lower than you should anticipate going forward. But I think low end of our guidance is probably a fair way to look at that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ajay Jain with Pivotal Research Group.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ajay Jain with Pivotal Research Group.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the currency impact. I think Joel, you mentioned that the impact overall wasn't that significant in the quarter. And my understanding is that any hedges that were in place were terminated at the end of last year. And I'm also sure that
componenttext: I had a question on the currency impact. I think Joel, you mentioned that the impact overall wasn't that significant in the quarter. And my understanding is that any hedges that were in place were terminated at the end of last year. And I'm also sure that you're very well aware that there was a pretty dramatic swing in the exchange rate for the pound year-over-year during the quarter. So can you give any more color on why there wasn't any significant drag from currency in the quarter? I would have assumed that earnings would have been better without the currency impact, but I'm just surprised that you're seeing there really wasn't that much of an impact at all.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Ajay, I mean, the point I was really making is without a doubt, you're correct in your statement regarding the hedges. I think, if you think about the magnitude of the Brakes business as a percentage of our entire business, there's really wh
componenttext: Yes, I think, Ajay, I mean, the point I was really making is without a doubt, you're correct in your statement regarding the hedges. I think, if you think about the magnitude of the Brakes business as a percentage of our entire business, there's really where my comment was targeted at that. What we talked about over the past few quarters was a difference that was primarily driven by the Canadian exchange rate. But that's -- that has pretty much mitigated frankly. And so again, if you think about that business as a percentage of our total, certainly the Brakes earnings would have been higher. And if you factor the sterling, the weakness in the sterling, I guess, my comment was really the whole organization the overall impact wasn't that significant.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think to Joel's point, you're talking about 65% of 10% of the business.
componenttext: I think to Joel's point, you're talking about 65% of 10% of the business.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And a also just wanted to follow up on the earlier question is on that 3-year plan and maybe I'll just frame my question a little differently. So I know you're going to be giving an update later in the year. But since you are tracking your progres
componenttext: Got it. And a also just wanted to follow up on the earlier question is on that 3-year plan and maybe I'll just frame my question a little differently. So I know you're going to be giving an update later in the year. But since you are tracking your progress pretty closely, can you just at least confirm where things are right now? on a run-rate basis relative to that $500 million growth target? So if you were to give a current snapshot, can you confirm whether you're comfortable ahead of plan are there still supposed to be kind of more back-end loaded assumptions on those 3-year objectives?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, I feel good about where we're at, we're 5 quarters into it. We've been trending 10% to 15% earnings growth every quarter. That's consistent with the plan. We've got some benefit next year with the depreciation as it relates to the business tech
componenttext: As I said, I feel good about where we're at, we're 5 quarters into it. We've been trending 10% to 15% earnings growth every quarter. That's consistent with the plan. We've got some benefit next year with the depreciation as it relates to the business technology. So from what I said, I would say we're comfortably on track right now and looking to reassess here at the end of the second quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way -- and I'll just add to that, I mean, I think at the end of last year, we talked about some initial percentage targets. I think at the end of last year, we were slightly ahead of those targets. I think we've talked about though and ag
componenttext: Yes, I think the way -- and I'll just add to that, I mean, I think at the end of last year, we talked about some initial percentage targets. I think at the end of last year, we were slightly ahead of those targets. I think we've talked about though and again, we had a strong quarter this quarter, but an ongoing basis, we've -- I said Bill said before, we'd certainly like to get a couple of quarters under our belt before we think about doing any differently there. And so that's really the way I would think about our progress. We're feeling good, we're in a good place but let's see how this plays out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, how would you describe, if you could comment on the case volume trends at Brakes year-over-year in the U.K. market in particular? I mean, can you confirm if they were positive or negative?
componenttext: Okay. And finally, how would you describe, if you could comment on the case volume trends at Brakes year-over-year in the U.K. market in particular? I mean, can you confirm if they were positive or negative?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we've got an international segment. We're going to give you some color on the components of that. I would tell you that their business softened through the calendar year even before Brexit. And I think it's more about just the uncertainty in that e
componenttext: Again, we've got an international segment. We're going to give you some color on the components of that. I would tell you that their business softened through the calendar year even before Brexit. And I think it's more about just the uncertainty in that economy whether it was leading up to Brexit or post-Brexit. And it's -- if you read all the different accounts so far, it hasn't been as bad perhaps us people thought it might have been and I think we're seeing that as well. On the other hand, if there's still a lot of uncertainty here over the next 2 or 3 years. So I think they're -- just on said in his prepared remarks, I think we performed reasonably well given the environment.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JPMorgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: One quick one and then one question if I may. Firstly, there seems to be some confusion about what non-GAAP G&A should be for the business in '17 and maybe even '18. Bill, I think in the last question, you mentioned some technology write-off that you had
componenttext: One quick one and then one question if I may. Firstly, there seems to be some confusion about what non-GAAP G&A should be for the business in '17 and maybe even '18. Bill, I think in the last question, you mentioned some technology write-off that you had done recently that may benefit that line. I hate to ask such a specific question because a lot of people are continue to have some really different estimates can you give us a little more specific help on that specific line?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with that. I'll take a couple of things on that. One of the things you see in our certain item reconciliation this quarter is that we'll see this in our were Q. Our G&A is up a bit for this quarter and it's for a couple of different reasons.
componenttext: Let me start with that. I'll take a couple of things on that. One of the things you see in our certain item reconciliation this quarter is that we'll see this in our were Q. Our G&A is up a bit for this quarter and it's for a couple of different reasons. Number one, as we talked about last year, we actually expected some the of the SAP system there was an acceleration of the amortization related to that. And so there's roughly $30 million, I'd say, on the certain item related to that this year that's part of our DNA. There's also as a result of the Brakes deal, there is both additional depreciation and amortization as part of that. And so I think if you look at our overall G&A expense for this particular quarter relative to where we've been, those are really the 2 primary contributors on that line as it relates to this. What Bill is referring to as -- in his comments earlier, if you'll recall at the time, and we increased our target from $400 million to $500 million and again, a while back, we had made a couple of comments as it relates to that, number one was the fact that a component of that difference was related to the fact that we -- with that  changeover in our technology strategy that there would be some benefits once again, the asset was fully written off again accelerated amortization we've been experiencing at the end of last year and through this about benefit to that starting in 2018. So I think that's really what goes relating to on that. And so hopefully that gives you some clarity on some of the comments and a little bit of be done on that. But you should expect accelerated amortization from that plus the Brakes to be present throughout the rest of this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can confirm from this [indiscernible].
componenttext: I can confirm from this [indiscernible].

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: And I think I did understand that, but I think if you look at street estimates, you'll see that people have some pretty different estimates for DNA. Look unusually different customers were DNA in '17 and '18, and that's why I was wondering if you're willing to give a little bit more specific guidance on that one specific line.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean...
componenttext: Yes, I mean...

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you guys need adjust this a quarter ago through certain item schedule, work with Neil and I would expect we will get more consistency.
componenttext: I think you guys need adjust this a quarter ago through certain item schedule, work with Neil and I would expect we will get more consistency.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, we will do our best as always. And then the next question obviously, the restaurant industry, just taking from an operator perspective, slower traffic, higher labor cost, I mean, it's one of the obvious things that a restaurant company does is
componenttext: All right, we will do our best as always. And then the next question obviously, the restaurant industry, just taking from an operator perspective, slower traffic, higher labor cost, I mean, it's one of the obvious things that a restaurant company does is come to their supplier and try to get this lowest prices of possible. I mean, are you seeing your restaurant customers may be asking even more from you than they have in the past, even if they see your gross margin results and ask you to give some of the gross margin back to them as they try to protect their own profitability?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Tom. I'd say John, couple of things. As we said earlier, it continues to be a very competitive out there. Whether it's a chain restaurant customer or street customer for us. And I think the way we try to look at value we bring to those custo
componenttext: Well, this is Tom. I'd say John, couple of things. As we said earlier, it continues to be a very competitive out there. Whether it's a chain restaurant customer or street customer for us. And I think the way we try to look at value we bring to those customers is certainly beyond just price. We offer a wide range of obviously products and services to these folks. We believe we bring them value each and every day. We talked a little bit about Sysco Brand earlier and Sysco Brand is a great example of where we're able to bring basically lower cost of goods to our customers and put them in a position where they can earn as much as they can from their offering. But I it's well beyond just products and pricing. And so I'd say it's the whole portfolio of things we bring to them that's allowed us to be successful and certainly what we believe is the right strategy for us going forward. But doesn't take away from the fact that it's competitive out there each and every day, and we just have to make sure that we're doing those right things in the market. We absolutely believe we need to be price competitive, and that's one of the components of what we focus on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, John, just to reinforce that, this is happening in an environment of 2 points of deflation right now. So the customers, they're benefiting from the food cost deflation. What we're doing, what Tom addressed earlier with the revenue management
componenttext: And I think, John, just to reinforce that, this is happening in an environment of 2 points of deflation right now. So the customers, they're benefiting from the food cost deflation. What we're doing, what Tom addressed earlier with the revenue management is using a lot of tools to be more consistent, more targeted in our pricing that will still need to compete as he points out every day for that business. And interestingly to me on the data that we see, to your point, while benefiting from deflation, they got some labor pressures they've been out there for a while now, but the restaurant is a group continue to pass along about a 2-point increase so to their customers and that has been incredibly consistent through every cycle that we've seen here. So I think right now, they are managing it pretty well and the deflation is helping them at some point, I guess, it could become more acute if we were to see the deflation reverse. But as I think Joel pointed out, we don't see that happening here, at least not in this calendar year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016

componenttext: And there are no further questions in queue. Thank you for your participation on today's call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions.I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell, Vice Pre
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. We will begin today's call with opening remarks and introductions.
I would like to turn the call over to Neil Russell, Vice President of Investor Relations and Communications. Please go ahead.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lindsay. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Lindsay. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Sysco's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. Joining me in Houston today are Bill DeLaney, our Chief Executive Officer; Tom Bené, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, please note that statements made during this presentation that state the company's or management's intentions, beliefs, expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, and actual results could differ in a material manner. Additional information about factors that could cause results to differ from those in the forward-looking statements is contained in the company's SEC filings. This includes, but is not limited to, risk factors contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended July 2, 2016, subsequent SEC filings and in the news release issued earlier this morning. A copy of these materials can be found in the Investors section at sysco.com or via Sysco's IR app.
Non-GAAP financial measures are included in our comments today and in our presentation slides. The reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the corresponding GAAP measures are included at the end of the presentation slides and can also be found in the Investors section of our website.
Additionally, the results for our first quarter fiscal 2017 incorporate for the first time the financial performance of the newly acquired Brakes Group. As such, we will reference throughout our presentation today Sysco's financial results both including and excluding this acquisition. [Operator Instructions]
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Executive Officer, Bill DeLaney.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone.I'm very pleased with our start in fiscal 2017. And this morning, we reported strong first quarter financial results. These results reflect our relentless focus on improving our customers' experience with Sysc
componenttext:
Thank you, Neil, and good morning, everyone.
I'm very pleased with our start in fiscal 2017. And this morning, we reported strong first quarter financial results. These results reflect our relentless focus on improving our customers' experience with Sysco, the benefits of several key business initiatives that we have implemented over the past few years and the contributions from our new colleagues at Brakes who joined Sysco in early July.
For the quarter and excluding the impact of Brakes, sales grew 1%, gross profit grew 5%, while operating expense grew less than 2%, which resulted in adjusted operating income growth of 15%. After reflecting the business results of Brakes, adjusted operating income grew 24% to $627 million and adjusted earnings per share grew to $0.67.
While we benefited from some favorable year-over-year expense comparisons which Joel will touch on in a few minutes, these results were achieved in an uneven economic environment that is impacting our customers' business. Some metrics reflect positive implications for longer-term consumer demand such as steadying unemployment levels, modest GDP growth, increased consumer confidence and healthy momentum in the housing market.
However, the restaurant industry, which represents approximately 60% of the foodservice market, is not currently experiencing the level of growth we have seen in recent quarters. Restaurant traffic continues to show year-over-year declines and restaurant spend has decelerated as well. More specifically, recent data from both NPD and KNAPP-TRACK show weakening overall sales trends.
That said, we continue to execute our business plan and key initiatives very well. I am pleased with our progress to-date toward the achievement of our 3-year financial goals and I remain confident in our ability to accomplish our strategic objectives over the long-term.
Our improved and increasingly consistent performance for the past 2 years is attributed to multiyear foundational work we have carried out in customer insights, category management, revenue management, supply chain efficiencies and administrative expense management. The benefits of these work streams have positioned us to continue to effectively support the needs of our customers and profitably leverage our volume growth.
Moving forward, we will build on this momentum by maintaining our customer-centric approach while focusing on targeted, disciplined and profitable growth. Both Tom and Joel will provide more detail about these specific initiatives we are currently implementing and the related benefits.
Turning to the Brakes transaction. We continue to work closely with our experienced and talented leadership team to support their growth, drive after transformative initiatives and identify additional acquisition opportunities. I'm very excited about the long-term benefits that this business will provide Sysco.
In summary, we are off to a good start to fiscal 2017 and I'm encouraged with the progress we are making as we approach the midpoint of our 3-year plan. I'm especially appreciative of the efforts and contributions from all 65,000 of our associates as we strive to fully realize our vision for Sysco: to be our customers' most valued and trusted business partner.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom Bené, Sysco's President and Chief Operating Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone.Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect solid operating performance and continued progress against several of our key multiyear initiatives. Our favorable operating performance continues to be
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone.
Sysco's financial results announced this morning reflect solid operating performance and continued progress against several of our key multiyear initiatives. Our favorable operating performance continues to be driven by our ongoing focus on the key levers of our 3-year plan, including delivering accelerated case growth through our focus on local customers, improving gross margins and managing overall expenses, both in our supply chain and administrative functions.
This morning, I'll be providing an update on our business results based on our new segment reporting structure, which highlights U.S. Foodservice operations, International Foodservice operations, SYGMA and all other.
During the quarter, U.S. Foodservice operations, which is primarily comprised of U.S. Broadline, specialty meat, FreshPoint and our European Imports business, grew sales 0.8%, driven by overall case growth in the U.S. Broadline of 1.8%, with local cases driving our growth at 1.9%.
Gross profit in U.S. Foodservice operations grew 4.3% for the quarter and gross margin increased 68 basis points, driven by a combination of factors including our ongoing category management efforts, which is how we now go-to-market with an improved product assortment and centralized approach for a majority of our product procurement, which in turn helps us drive out costs for ourselves and our suppliers; second, improved Sysco Brand performance with our local customers; the deployment of a suite of revenue management tools and processes that bring more discipline to our sales and merchandising teams and, ultimately, more consistent pricing to our customers; and the impact of deflation.
During the quarter, we continued to focus our sales teams on initiatives and activities that will help our customers succeed and grow their business. We have been implementing a variety of sales training and support tools that build overall capability within our selling organization. And we have restructured some of the work within that organization to both free up our marketing associates' time and provide access to our targeted resources to better support our customers.
These efforts, in conjunction with ongoing enhancements to our e-commerce tools which allow our customers to choose how they place their orders with Sysco, are enabling us to better leverage our marketing associates to spend more time supporting our customers with unique programs, innovative products and other business-building solutions.
From a cost perspective, our expense management for the quarter was solid and remains a key area of focus for us moving forward. For U.S. Foodservice operations during the first quarter, we limited total adjusted operating expense growth to 1.8%. Our supply chain performance is progressing well and we are seeing positive momentum from our productivity initiatives and continuing process improvements that are driving efficiencies.
For U.S. Broadline, cost per case improved by $0.04 for the quarter and, on a fuel price-neutral basis, cost per case was flat. The continuous improvement efforts in our facilities and the continued investment in training for our warehouse associates and drivers has allowed us to build further capability throughout our supply chain. One such example is the implementation of a labor forecasting tool that enables us to proactively manage hours at our facilities based on the anticipated workload for each shift. We also remain on track to deliver our previously communicated administrative cost reductions, both in corporate and within the operations.
Moving to International Foodservice operations, which is made up of Canada, Europe, Bahamas, International Food Group and our joint ventures in Mexico and Costa Rica. Sales were up $1.3 billion and adjusted operating income increased $50 million, both driven by our recent acquisition of the Brakes Group. We appreciate the Brakes Group early performance and continue to look forward to working with the management team on achieving our collective plans in the future.
During the quarter, Brakes performed reasonably well in the U.K. amidst a challenging environment and performance in both brands in Sweden was relatively strong. Our business in Canada is off to a good start for the fiscal year as we are effectively managing cost within a deflationary and somewhat soft market environment. And lastly, our joint ventures in both Costa Rica and Mexico had solid performance in the first quarter of fiscal year 2017.
SYGMA continues to make progress against their key business initiatives and had 4% sales growth for the first quarter. We continue to feel confident in their ability to deliver their full year growth goals and objectives.
In summary, our customer and operational strategies are solidly aligned around improving our customers' experience, engaging our associates at the highest level to improve execution and delivering our financial objectives as part of our 3-year plan. We have continued to make significant progress in all areas for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, and I remain optimistic about the programs and processes we are putting in place that will enable our future success.
Now I'll turn the call over to Joel Grade, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone.As Bill and Tom had mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the first quarter. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including local solid case growth, strong gross
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and good morning, everyone.
As Bill and Tom had mentioned earlier, we are pleased with the results for the first quarter. Our growth reflects continued momentum from our underlying business, including local solid case growth, strong gross profit dollar growth and good cost management as well as a solid contribution from Brakes. The results that I'll cover for you this morning include Brakes, which significantly impacted our results.
In summary, for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, sales grew 11.2%, gross profit dollars grew 20.3%, operating expense growth was 19.2%, all of which resulted in adjusted operating income growth of 23.8% and our adjusted earnings per share grew 28.8%. Sales during the quarter were positively impacted by the inclusion of Brakes in our results, though partially offset by deflation of 2.2% in our legacy Sysco business.
Continuing with gross profit and gross margins beyond the addition of Brakes, the key drivers of improvement included category management, revenue management, higher Sysco Brand penetration in our local business and deflation. The categories impacted most by deflation continue to be the Center of the Plate, protein and dairy. We expect the trend to continue into calendar 2017. That said, we continue to manage this environment effectively as evidenced by our strong gross profit dollar growth.
The increasing expenses during the quarter beyond the addition of Brakes were mainly driven by the previously mentioned higher case volumes and a timing shift of expenses related to our option grants from the second quarter into the first and was partially offset by various decreases in indirect spend, fuel costs, favorable comparisons to the prior year which included planned investments and technology spend related to our 3-year plan and foreign exchange translation.
As it relates to taxes, our effective tax rate in the first quarter was 32.9% compared to 36.3% in the prior year period. The decrease in tax rate is driven by tax credits, lower tax rates in the U.K. due to new tax laws that were recently passed and the mix of business as we grow in lower rate jurisdictions. Compared to the prior year, adjusted net earnings grew 20.7%.
Cash flow from operations was $249 million, which is $510 million higher compared to the same period last year. Free cash flow was $111 million, which is $492 million higher compared to the same period last year. The significant improvements in both are due mainly to improved working capital performance and payments made on the prior year related to the proposed merger with US Foods.
Net CapEx for the quarter was $138 million.
I'm pleased with our net working capital performance for the quarter. We had a net 2-day improvement versus the prior year and a 2.8-day improvement versus fiscal 2015 and are making good progress towards our 3-year goal of a 4-day improvement. These improvements are driven primarily by improvements of all 3 phases of working capital: payables, receivables and inventory.
Our first quarter results included some certain items that were mostly related to the Brakes acquisition, including amortization associated with the transaction. As a reminder, in the prior year, we had significant amount of certain items primarily related to the termination of the proposed merger with US Foods.
Now I'd like to transition to 3 business updates. First, regarding Brakes. As a reminder, we initially guided that the acquisition will be modestly accretive to fiscal 2017 earnings per share by low to mid-single digits. We are now updating that guidance due to finalizing the treatment of amortization as a certain item and believe this acquisition will be accretive to adjusted earnings per share by high single digits in fiscal 2017, with acceleration in subsequent years assuming constant currency.
For the first quarter, Brakes was approximately $0.04 accretive to our business on an adjusted basis. It is important to note that Brakes' business does have some seasonality as the performance is more heavily weighted to the first half of the year. Accordingly, we do not expect the same accretion each quarter, in particular in quarter number 3.
Second, regarding fuel expense. We expect the favorability we've had over the past few quarters to begin to lap in November.
Separately, we are enhancing our fuel strategy. In the past, we used a third party to forward buy fixed price contracts approximately 12 months out. Going forward, we are transitioning the management of our fuel expense by using derivatives to hedge our exposure. By separating the management of our fuel purchases from our risk management, we will allow for more effective management of the risks. We'll continue to cover approximately 2/3 of our needs with hedges in place to minimize volatility in price.
Finally, we are announcing today the upsizing of our credit facility from $1.5 billion to $2 billion and we'll upsize our commercial paper lines accordingly to provide greater liquidity to support our growing business.
In summary, we had a quality quarter reflecting continued momentum from our underlying business, including solid local case growth, strong gross profit dollar growth and good cost management. That said, we have more work to do in order to achieve the full financial objectives of our 3-year plan. We are committed to serving our customers and delivering a high level of execution in all areas of our business that improve our financial performance in both the near and long-term. I'm confident in our ability to continue to execute our plan.
Operator, we are now ready for Q&A.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
