headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, they have a lot of good work going on over there in their own transformation as we've spoken to a little bit before, so there's opportunity on the supply chain. They're doing some things with their warehouses where they're moving from multiple wareh
componenttext: Well, they have a lot of good work going on over there in their own transformation as we've spoken to a little bit before, so there's opportunity on the supply chain. They're doing some things with their warehouses where they're moving from multiple warehouses to service a market to one, which is more similar to what we see. And there's always opportunities on the administrative side of the business. So I think there will be opportunities. That's a big part of their plan. And I don't know that they'll get to our number necessarily because it's a different market, but there's certainly upside there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And, I guess, just last question. Can you comment on how cases trended throughout the quarter and the outlook for them going forward, I guess, just given that comparisons start to get tougher these next 2 quarters?
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And, I guess, just last question. Can you comment on how cases trended throughout the quarter and the outlook for them going forward, I guess, just given that comparisons start to get tougher these next 2 quarters?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Tom. So as I said, the local cases were up 1.9% in U.S. Broadline. And yes, that's been a little bit of a falloff from what we'd experienced in the last couple of quarters of fiscal year '16. I think based on what we're seeing in the restaurant
componenttext: So this is Tom. So as I said, the local cases were up 1.9% in U.S. Broadline. And yes, that's been a little bit of a falloff from what we'd experienced in the last couple of quarters of fiscal year '16. I think based on what we're seeing in the restaurant segment, I think we believe it will be -- continue to be a slight decline from what it's been at the end of last year, but we still feel fairly confident that we'll see continued case growth in the local segment of our business. We're very focused on, as Bill said in his comments, profitable growth. And we want to make sure that we're focused on those right customer segments, but we still believe we could grow our local cases.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Edward Kelly with Credit Suisse.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just start with a follow-up to that last question? Could you just help us understand what you're seeing from an organic case growth standpoint? I don't know how -- if you could sort of frame that for us at all relative to the 1.8% and the 1.9%? Just
componenttext: Can I just start with a follow-up to that last question? Could you just help us understand what you're seeing from an organic case growth standpoint? I don't know how -- if you could sort of frame that for us at all relative to the 1.8% and the 1.9%? Just curious as to the role that acquisitions are playing into this.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start and I'm going to let Joel and Tom maybe add some color here. But I would say that is largely the organic growth that we're experiencing. What Tom said was if you go back a year, I think we're in mid-2s, the high 2s in different quarters
componenttext: Well, let me start and I'm going to let Joel and Tom maybe add some color here. But I would say that is largely the organic growth that we're experiencing. What Tom said was if you go back a year, I think we're in mid-2s, the high 2s in different quarters, not every quarter was the same. So if you go back to my comments, I mean, basically, we're seeing some slowness out there. Softening, I guess, is a better word in terms of overall growth in the restaurant segment. And ours is off a little bit as well. So it just reinforces the importance of solidifying those customer relationships and getting penetration where there's that opportunity where customers are growing as well as continue to stay really locked in on retaining our customers and identifying new opportunities as we go along. So, I mean, the 1.8% to 1.9% is largely the organic growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's very helpful. And just sort of one second question here that I wanted to ask you about, and I kind of asked about it last quarter too. But you maintained your 3-year target. Your results so far have been really impressive. I mean, this
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's very helpful. And just sort of one second question here that I wanted to ask you about, and I kind of asked about it last quarter too. But you maintained your 3-year target. Your results so far have been really impressive. I mean, this is a great quarter. Can you just talk to us about how you're thinking about that goal at this point, whether you think we'll get an update at some point relatively soon? And as we just sort of sit back and try to consider how things play out from here, Bill, what are the moving parts that we should really be thinking about from here sort of like good or bad going forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the moving parts we've touched on here just now. I think we're seeing some softness out there. I think other people are seeing the same thing on a relative basis. And so we're very focused on trying to get our case growth back up over 2%. I
componenttext: Well, I think the moving parts we've touched on here just now. I think we're seeing some softness out there. I think other people are seeing the same thing on a relative basis. And so we're very focused on trying to get our case growth back up over 2%. I think that's very important. We're real pleased with how we're managing the margins and still growing the business and taking care of our customers in the right way, and a lot of the steps we took back in the spring to initiate deeper expense reductions are benefiting us right now. So I think the things that we can influence and control we're doing a really good job with. We're probably a little cautious in terms of the overall macro out there for our customers. We still got 2 points of deflation out there, largely driven by those Center of the Plate categories. So those will be 2 areas where we're probably a little bit cautious. Obviously, we're in our third year now of earnings growth and I think this is the fourth quarter of double-digit earnings growth on an adjusted basis. So obviously, the bar gets higher and we're ready for that. So we feel very good overall about what we're doing, a little cautious on the environment. I think to your first question, the way I'm looking at that, Ed, is we're one quarter into this year and we're just not quite to the halfway point of the 3-year plan. So I'm going to get a little further into this year and get halfway through the 3-year plan, and then I think we'll be able to reassess where we are on the goals.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Zach Fadem with Wells Fargo.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the M&A impact in the quarter, first of all, was there any M&A impact to U.S. Broadlines beyond Brakes? And then, secondly for Brakes, total sales came in a bit higher than I thought. Maybe you could talk about just volume trends there and what the
componenttext: So on the M&A impact in the quarter, first of all, was there any M&A impact to U.S. Broadlines beyond Brakes? And then, secondly for Brakes, total sales came in a bit higher than I thought. Maybe you could talk about just volume trends there and what the impact of FX was. And just with the high single-digit accretion for the year, what are you anticipating for total sales growth for the year for Brakes?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we're not going to get into bridges or trends on individual businesses within segments. But I think, as Tom pointed out -- I'm going to let Tom speak to this. Obviously, there's some challenges in the U.K. right now. We thought the Brakes Group per
componenttext: Again, we're not going to get into bridges or trends on individual businesses within segments. But I think, as Tom pointed out -- I'm going to let Tom speak to this. Obviously, there's some challenges in the U.K. right now. We thought the Brakes Group performed well given the environment and very nicely in France and Sweden. I think that's as much as I probably can add right now. Tom, you got anything?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, maybe to answer your first question too, Zach, the very little impact in U.S. cases from the acquisitions as we mentioned a minute ago, so those numbers were basically kind of organic growth numbers. And the only thing I'd add on Brakes is that
componenttext: Yes. Well, maybe to answer your first question too, Zach, the very little impact in U.S. cases from the acquisitions as we mentioned a minute ago, so those numbers were basically kind of organic growth numbers. And the only thing I'd add on Brakes is that we think the team is off to a really good start. Bill mentioned the transformational initiatives they've been operating against are all moving along nicely. And I think we feel very comfortable with, overall, how that business is performing. And the U.K. certainly has got some bumpiness in their economy driven by a lot of things going on over there right now, but I think we feel very comfortable with where they're at and how they're performing.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just add. I mean, you asked about the FX part of that. Obviously, the weakening sterling certainly plays into this, so there is some FX impact. But on an aggregate basis for the organization, we had fairly minor impact from FX for this qu
componenttext: Yes. And I would just add. I mean, you asked about the FX part of that. Obviously, the weakening sterling certainly plays into this, so there is some FX impact. But on an aggregate basis for the organization, we had fairly minor impact from FX for this quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then, just, I guess, let's -- I’ll take it on a high level here on the operating environment. Could you comment on the -- just a little bit about underlying restaurant trends? With them being a little choppy, are you see
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then, just, I guess, let's -- I’ll take it on a high level here on the operating environment. Could you comment on the -- just a little bit about underlying restaurant trends? With them being a little choppy, are you seeing any change to the competitive environment here, particularly with the impact of deflation versus food away from home -- or food at home widening a little bit? Are you seeing anything as far as just continued challenges for your customers and then competition from your peers?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the challenges are what I'd referenced. You've got several quarters in a row now where traffic is actually down. And while the spend is up, it's not rising at the same rate it was rising. So yes, there's clearly a softening out there, I mean
componenttext: Well, I think the challenges are what I'd referenced. You've got several quarters in a row now where traffic is actually down. And while the spend is up, it's not rising at the same rate it was rising. So yes, there's clearly a softening out there, I mean, whether it's because of the election or relative pricing between grocery store and restaurants, what others kind of critiqued out. I just -- look, I think there's ebbs and flows in any cycles of economies, and I think we're going through that right now. But I think it just puts a premium on quality operators, both in terms of our customer base as well as ourselves. And we feel good about what we're doing and we're doing everything we can to support our customers. As far as the competitive environment, I wouldn't say there's any change. It's acutely competitive as we've talked about before, all different types of competitors out there. We feel we're very well-positioned. It does play out differently in some markets. But overall, I'd say it's about the same.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Heinbockel with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe starting a question for Tom. When you think about moving case growth back up, is there a lot of clear things you can do to help your customers stimulate demand? Or is it really more taking share from other distributors in the environment we're in
componenttext: So maybe starting a question for Tom. When you think about moving case growth back up, is there a lot of clear things you can do to help your customers stimulate demand? Or is it really more taking share from other distributors in the environment we're in today?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, well, I'd say I'm not sure there's a lot more we can do to help stimulate demand. What we can do is make sure that each of our customers is operating as effectively as they can and that they've got, obviously, the right products and the right pricin
componenttext: John, well, I'd say I'm not sure there's a lot more we can do to help stimulate demand. What we can do is make sure that each of our customers is operating as effectively as they can and that they've got, obviously, the right products and the right pricing so that they can be successful. But as far as stimulating demand into their -- or traffic into their locations, that's a little bit harder, I think, from where we sit. But I think there's a lot we are doing to help them be successful and I think that's what we continue to focus and we believe very strongly that's our -- as much our responsibility as theirs to help ensure that they're healthy and effective in what they're doing. And obviously, the tools that we bring them every day, I think, makes a big difference there. What was the second part of your question?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it was really that -- if you're going to get case growth back up, is it more market share-driven? I guess, do you think, from what you can see, is your share -- the rate at which you're taking share from others in the space, maybe the smaller guys,
componenttext: Well, it was really that -- if you're going to get case growth back up, is it more market share-driven? I guess, do you think, from what you can see, is your share -- the rate at which you're taking share from others in the space, maybe the smaller guys, is that -- it looks like it's accelerating. Is that fair?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard for us to obviously know that directly because, as you know, lots of competitors in this environment. We certainly believe we're continuing to grow at least at the industry, if not outpacing that. As we talked for the last couple o
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard for us to obviously know that directly because, as you know, lots of competitors in this environment. We certainly believe we're continuing to grow at least at the industry, if not outpacing that. As we talked for the last couple of years, we have tried to focus our efforts in a couple of areas. One, where there is natural growth taking place. We talked in the past about some of the segments where you're seeing growth, whether it be the Hispanic Latino segment out there where we’ve really focused some of our energy and efforts to provide support to those operators or certainly looking at geographies where we've got opportunities. So I think we continue to execute our strategy, and we feel like it's working. And we're, hopefully, gaining share from lots of different places based on how well we're taking care of our customers.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, just lastly, if you think about supermarket foodservice, maybe just remind us kind of relative size of that business for you. It's still pretty small, I think. And where you think, as you look out 3, 5 years or longer, how much bigger
componenttext: All right. And then, just lastly, if you think about supermarket foodservice, maybe just remind us kind of relative size of that business for you. It's still pretty small, I think. And where you think, as you look out 3, 5 years or longer, how much bigger can that get?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is still relatively small for us. I don't have the exact numbers from Technomic, but I think that they say that, that retail segment, I think, is about 7% of the market, if my guess is -- if my memory serves me right. And I think that, for us, we
componenttext: Well, it is still relatively small for us. I don't have the exact numbers from Technomic, but I think that they say that, that retail segment, I think, is about 7% of the market, if my guess is -- if my memory serves me right. And I think that, for us, we certainly have opportunity to grow there. I think it really is a matter of what's the best way for us to grow there. We talked a couple of years ago about our relationship with Kroger. We feel like we continue to have opportunity as they grow in that space. But I think it really comes down to how consumers decide to purchase their food away from home. And that retail segment certainly, I know, is a big focus for a lot of the retailers to see if they could pick up maybe some more share from that consumer.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kelly Bania with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious if you could just talk a little bit about the local case growth. I know it's hard to really know exactly how much the market is growing there. But do you feel like you took some share there? I realize it slowed, but still pretty solid. So just any
componenttext: Curious if you could just talk a little bit about the local case growth. I know it's hard to really know exactly how much the market is growing there. But do you feel like you took some share there? I realize it slowed, but still pretty solid. So just any color around that 1.9%.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we just were talking, I feel like it really is hard. We don't have a good view for -- of the entire market. I'd say what we continue to see is we're getting growth from new customers. We are seeing a little bit of softness in some of the penetration of
componenttext: As we just were talking, I feel like it really is hard. We don't have a good view for -- of the entire market. I'd say what we continue to see is we're getting growth from new customers. We are seeing a little bit of softness in some of the penetration of existing customers. We think that might be driven by some of the more external information that's out there around restaurant traffic. But broadly speaking, we feel like we're just serving the broader independent restaurant segment well. And as we do that, we probably are gaining some share, but it's really hard to tell exactly where that might be coming from.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I guess, just another question on the 3-year target. So I realize you may not be updating those or feel the need to update those. But, I guess, given that Brakes is now just a significant part of the story over the next couple of years,
componenttext: Got it. And then, I guess, just another question on the 3-year target. So I realize you may not be updating those or feel the need to update those. But, I guess, given that Brakes is now just a significant part of the story over the next couple of years, do you have any color just on how we should think about that 3-year target with Brakes included?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kelly, I'm going to start and I'm going to let Joel give you a little more on this. So one of the reasons we are providing more detail at this time on the segment information is to make sure that we're clear on the international versus the U.S. And then,
componenttext: Kelly, I'm going to start and I'm going to let Joel give you a little more on this. So one of the reasons we are providing more detail at this time on the segment information is to make sure that we're clear on the international versus the U.S. And then, what we will do -- so we have a 3-year target and we have a 3-year goal. And we will continue to track that in calls like this and investor presentations periodically and give you some sense on where we are in that original goal for the businesses that existed at that time, and then how we're doing on the rest of it. So we're going to simultaneously track that 3-year goal and also begin to build a new 3-year plan here over the next few months, and then we'll put that out to you at some point in calendar '17.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think, Kelly, the thing I would add to that is it's just as a reminder, we -- part of this target was to be very clear with all of you in the way that we are holding ourselves accountable and ultimately hold us accountable is this very clear an
componenttext: Yes. And I think, Kelly, the thing I would add to that is it's just as a reminder, we -- part of this target was to be very clear with all of you in the way that we are holding ourselves accountable and ultimately hold us accountable is this very clear and specific target for the legacy business. And so as we go through this, again, what you can expect from us is to continue to have a very clear delineation, again, both how we look at the organization as a whole, but continue very clear tracking on the things that we talked about at our original Investor Day and, I think, tracking our targets against that. So that will be, hopefully, very clear and separate it out for all of you.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vincent Sinisi with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of reconcile, obviously, we know that there were some puts and takes with Brakes and tax and all that type of stuff this quarter, but you did several times, of course, again, say today about the softening from the macro, which you had
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of reconcile, obviously, we know that there were some puts and takes with Brakes and tax and all that type of stuff this quarter, but you did several times, of course, again, say today about the softening from the macro, which you had alluded to last quarter as well. So, I guess, maybe any more color you can give on that restaurant softness in terms of any particular types of customers or geographies? And kind of going forward, do you expect things to get kind of sequentially worse or more just kind of roughly stay around these levels which are off the kind of previous highs?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vinny, I'll start. Look, the one thing I would point us to is, on an adjusted basis, if you exclude the impact of Brakes, we grew our operating income 15%. And that's the fourth quarter in a row where we've got double-digit increases on adjusted operating
componenttext:
Vinny, I'll start. Look, the one thing I would point us to is, on an adjusted basis, if you exclude the impact of Brakes, we grew our operating income 15%. And that's the fourth quarter in a row where we've got double-digit increases on adjusted operating income. So I think that -- what we feel good about and, hopefully, what that tells others is whether we've got 2.5% or 3% case growth or 1.5% to 2% case growth, we're doing everything we can on the top line as well as how we manage it from there to deliver on our commitment. And so at this point, we feel very good about how we're managing the environment.
In terms of where it goes from here, I can just tell you, internally, Tom and his team are very, very focused on penetration, on improved retention and, where appropriate, bringing on new quality customers. So we're doing everything we can in a disciplined way to grow that top line. But clearly, it puts a premium on managing our expenses here and continue to find ways to price in a way that works for us as well as for our customers. So that's the part we can control and influence. As far as where the market goes, it's really hard to call right now, given everything that's going on in the country. But we're preparing for where we're at, I think, to continue a while longer. Hopefully it gets somewhat better. But we're not really on the business of making those projections.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. That's helpful. Maybe just a quick follow-up on Brakes specifically. In the past, I think we were all kind of given the impression that, at this point at least, it was more or less going to kind of stay on its own, largely kind of be run separa
componenttext: Yes. Okay. That's helpful. Maybe just a quick follow-up on Brakes specifically. In the past, I think we were all kind of given the impression that, at this point at least, it was more or less going to kind of stay on its own, largely kind of be run separately over there. Can you guys -- I know it's still early, but just kind of give us maybe more of a qualitative sense of kind of the last few months how that overall integration is going and if you think there are opportunities to kind of bring it more under kind of one roof over time?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, the way we're looking at this strategically is there's a lot of exciting things about Brakes. We've talked about quality of their team, the part of Europe that they now bring us into and our ability to use that business as a platform for futu
componenttext: Well, again, the way we're looking at this strategically is there's a lot of exciting things about Brakes. We've talked about quality of their team, the part of Europe that they now bring us into and our ability to use that business as a platform for future acquisition growth and a lot of other things. So strategically, the way we look at it is it's a -- along with Canada, it's the 2 foundational parts of our international business. And we expect it to continue to grow and to allow us to continue to find ways to do acquisitions. And that's basically it from my perspective. Joel, do you want to add something?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what I would just say to give a little bit of color is that, I mean, we certainly have regular ongoing conversation and business reviews with their team. But again, as Bill mentioned, just to remind you, when we talked about this deal initial
componenttext: Yes. I think what I would just say to give a little bit of color is that, I mean, we certainly have regular ongoing conversation and business reviews with their team. But again, as Bill mentioned, just to remind you, when we talked about this deal initially is, again, we -- they have a very strong management team. We feel really good about their people and the work that they're doing that’s continued to transform their business. We certainly see that, again, as an opportunity to run that business stand-alone. Given there's minimal overlap in the business we have, we certainly continue to look for opportunities though to try to get the upside in the deal. But I would just tell you, again, a lot of good ongoing dialogue, but certainly they've got a strong management team running that business as a stand-alone entity.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marisa Sullivan with Bank of America.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about gross margin, excluding Brakes. It's still up very significantly in the quarter, and so I wanted to get your sense on what were the key drivers. You mentioned 4. How would you rank them during the quarter specifically? And also
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about gross margin, excluding Brakes. It's still up very significantly in the quarter, and so I wanted to get your sense on what were the key drivers. You mentioned 4. How would you rank them during the quarter specifically? And also how did deflation impact the gross margin this quarter?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Tom. Let me -- I did talk about 4 different drivers, and I think we continue to believe each of those is contributing to the work we're doing. It's hard to pull out the deflation component. We know it certainly impacts the gross margin percent,
componenttext: So this is Tom. Let me -- I did talk about 4 different drivers, and I think we continue to believe each of those is contributing to the work we're doing. It's hard to pull out the deflation component. We know it certainly impacts the gross margin percent, but it's also, I think, probably most important to think about those other 3 areas that we're focused on because that's how we manage the dollar side of it. Category management continues to be a very positive for us. As you know, we've been basically in that operating model now for the last 3 years. And it's -- while we've gone through, I'd say, the major cycle with that. We continue to work with our suppliers and we look at long-term partnerships that continue to provide value for us and, ultimately, for our customers. So category management continues to be a very important part of what we do and how we operate. Revenue management has been something that now is fully deployed within our organization. And I think we've got a really good set of processes and tools and, ultimately, routines for our sales and merchandising teams to leverage in the marketplace. And it allows us to be, I think, a little quicker on our feet and be able to do the things that we need to do to make sure that our customers' pricing is right on a regular basis. And it's driving really more consistency I know for our customers as well. And then, lastly, partly with the work we're doing in category management, but a continued focus on Sysco Brand, which brings value also to our customers and obviously delivers additional profitability for Sysco has been a key driver for us. And we continue to see improvement within our local customers with our local business. And we, again, saw an improvement in Sysco Brands this last quarter. So it really is a combination of all of those. And it's hard for us to kind of tease apart each of them individually, but I can tell you that each of them is definitely playing a role.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add there, Marisa, is the thing I feel the best about here is we -- going back to Tom's prepared comments, we grew the gross profit dollars over 4% in U.S. Foodservice business, so deflation hurts you when you talk about gross profi
componenttext: The only thing I would add there, Marisa, is the thing I feel the best about here is we -- going back to Tom's prepared comments, we grew the gross profit dollars over 4% in U.S. Foodservice business, so deflation hurts you when you talk about gross profit dollars. So all those things Tom just outlined, I think, are all key reasons why we're able to do that in an environment where you're looking at meaningful deflation.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, if I could just follow up on the revenue management. Now that it's fully deployed, when do you anticipate seeing more of the benefit flow through?
componenttext: Got it. And then, if I could just follow up on the revenue management. Now that it's fully deployed, when do you anticipate seeing more of the benefit flow through?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's -- when I say it's fully deployed, I mean, it's been out there now for a couple of quarters, and so I think we're seeing the benefits right now. If you -- if the question is does that have an end point? I think it's too early to even kn
componenttext: Well, I think it's -- when I say it's fully deployed, I mean, it's been out there now for a couple of quarters, and so I think we're seeing the benefits right now. If you -- if the question is does that have an end point? I think it's too early to even know that. It's an ongoing process that we follow now. And I think it's really more about being disciplined in how we approach pricing in the marketplace.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Mandeville with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Mandeville with Jefferies.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, just kind of sticking with the gross profit dollar growth subject here. When I think about your $500 million EBIT growth goal for -- over the next 3 years or through 2018, if you will, can you remind me what the inflation or deflation assumption was
componenttext: Bill, just kind of sticking with the gross profit dollar growth subject here. When I think about your $500 million EBIT growth goal for -- over the next 3 years or through 2018, if you will, can you remind me what the inflation or deflation assumption was originally?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The original model -- and I’ll take it. It’s Joel. That was -- it was about 2%. If you recall, we had a volume -- differential between our volume and sales growth that we rolled out when we initially talked about at a 2% rate.
componenttext: Yes. The original model -- and I’ll take it. It’s Joel. That was -- it was about 2%. If you recall, we had a volume -- differential between our volume and sales growth that we rolled out when we initially talked about at a 2% rate.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, I suppose kind of following up to that. Now that we're on our fifth quarter of consecutive deflation, but also considering how well you guys have been driving your gross profit dollar growth despite this backdrop, how do we think
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, I suppose kind of following up to that. Now that we're on our fifth quarter of consecutive deflation, but also considering how well you guys have been driving your gross profit dollar growth despite this backdrop, how do we think about kind of you guys reaching that ultimate goal? I believe the original mix was somewhere -- 55% to 65% of that $500 million EBIT growth goal came from gross profit dollar growth.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think -- I'll start with that and you guys can add in. I think it's -- I think we're still looking at that in a relatively consistent way as we had initially outlined. I think the really important part of this, though, is to -- one of the t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think -- I'll start with that and you guys can add in. I think it's -- I think we're still looking at that in a relatively consistent way as we had initially outlined. I think the really important part of this, though, is to -- one of the things we've talked about a bit externally is this gap or this delta between our growth in gross profit dollars and our growth in expense dollars. And so one of the things -- again, we certainly have done a good job of managing through this deflationary time and still continue to grow our growth in gross profit dollars. We've also done a good job, I think, of focusing and driving expenses downward as both Bill and Tom have talked about. And I think when we looked at that plan and sort of the puts and takes of what was going to drive it, we certainly knew there were -- we could have had more inflation, could have had less inflation, some of those factors are what they are. But the reality of it is our continued focus on that gap and that delta between the -- between those 2 numbers, I think, is really important.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think where we're at right now and I think where we've been, to your point, over the last few quarters is we're not on track to hit the sales number, okay? I think the original goal we were looking at 4% sales growth with 2 points of inflation and,
componenttext: Yes. I think where we're at right now and I think where we've been, to your point, over the last few quarters is we're not on track to hit the sales number, okay? I think the original goal we were looking at 4% sales growth with 2 points of inflation and, directionally, about the same amount of GP growth. So we've got to get the GP a different way and that's what we've been able to do here so far, and we're really encouraged by that as well as manage the expenses. So I think it's more of a play on the top line than anything else.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And just the one final thing I'd add to that is the -- if you recall, when we increased our targets from $400 million to $500 million, that was, again, primarily driven by some change in some of the way we viewed our expenses. And so, again, if you'r
componenttext: Yes. And just the one final thing I'd add to that is the -- if you recall, when we increased our targets from $400 million to $500 million, that was, again, primarily driven by some change in some of the way we viewed our expenses. And so, again, if you're going to look at that shift again a little bit, it's, as I mentioned earlier, pretty consistent with the top and, again, a little bit more of a shift toward some of the expense side as we roll out when we increased our targets.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's helpful. And then, just a quick housekeeping one for you, Joel. What's the reasonable tax rate to be assuming on a go forward?
componenttext: All right. That's helpful. And then, just a quick housekeeping one for you, Joel. What's the reasonable tax rate to be assuming on a go forward?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think at the end of last year, we guided somewhere in the 35% to 36% range. So with some of the -- one of the things we've talked about at this was actually a tax law change in the U.K. that moved the statutory rate essentially from 18% to 17%.
componenttext: Yes. So I think at the end of last year, we guided somewhere in the 35% to 36% range. So with some of the -- one of the things we've talked about at this was actually a tax law change in the U.K. that moved the statutory rate essentially from 18% to 17%. I would say that would take our view of that probably on the low end of the guidance that we put out before. A couple of things in this quarter, I think, that we called out that were some onetime deals. And so I would say the rate you see in this quarter is a bit lower than you should anticipate going forward. But I think low end of our guidance is probably a fair way to look at that.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ajay Jain with Pivotal Research Group.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ajay Jain with Pivotal Research Group.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I had a question on the currency impact. I think, Joel, you mentioned that the impact overall wasn't that significant in the quarter. And my understanding is that any hedges that were in place were terminated at the end of last year, and I'm also sur
componenttext: Yes. I had a question on the currency impact. I think, Joel, you mentioned that the impact overall wasn't that significant in the quarter. And my understanding is that any hedges that were in place were terminated at the end of last year, and I'm also sure that you're very well aware that there was a pretty dramatic swing in the exchange rate for the pound year-over-year during the quarter. So can you give any more color on why there wasn't any significant drag from currency in the quarter? I would have assumed that earnings would have been better without the currency impact, but I'm just surprised that you're saying there really wasn't that much of an impact at all.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Ajay, I mean, I think the point I was really making is without a doubt, you're correct in your statement regarding the hedges. I think -- if you think about the magnitude of the Brakes business as a percentage of our entire business, there's
componenttext: Yes. I think, Ajay, I mean, I think the point I was really making is without a doubt, you're correct in your statement regarding the hedges. I think -- if you think about the magnitude of the Brakes business as a percentage of our entire business, there's really where my comment was targeted at that. What we've talked about over the past few quarters was a difference that was primarily driven by the Canadian exchange rate, but that has pretty much mitigated, frankly. And so, again, if you think about that business as a percentage of our total, certainly the Brakes earnings would have been higher if you factor the sterling, the weakness in the sterling. But, I guess, my comment was really on the whole organization, the overall impact wasn't that significant.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, to Joel's point, you're talking about 65% of 10% of the business.
componenttext: I mean, to Joel's point, you're talking about 65% of 10% of the business.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I also just wanted to follow up on the earlier questions on the 3-year plan, and maybe I'll just frame my question a little differently. So I know you're going to be giving an update later in the year. But since you are tracking your progress
componenttext: Got it. And I also just wanted to follow up on the earlier questions on the 3-year plan, and maybe I'll just frame my question a little differently. So I know you're going to be giving an update later in the year. But since you are tracking your progress pretty closely, can you just at least confirm where things are right now on a run-rate basis relative to that $500 million growth target? So if you were to give a current snapshot, can you confirm whether you're comfortably ahead of plan or if there is still supposed to be kind of like more back-end loaded assumptions on those 3-year objectives?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, I feel good about where we're at. We're 5 quarters into it. We've been trending 10% to 15% earnings growth every quarter. That's consistent with the plan. We've got some benefit next year with the depreciation as it relates to the business tech
componenttext: As I said, I feel good about where we're at. We're 5 quarters into it. We've been trending 10% to 15% earnings growth every quarter. That's consistent with the plan. We've got some benefit next year with the depreciation as it relates to the business technology. So from where I sit, I would say we're comfortably on track right now and looking to reassess here at the end of the second quarter.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the way -- and I'll just add to that. I mean, I think at the end of last year, we've talked about some initial percentage targets. I think at the end of last year, we were probably -- we were slightly ahead of those targets. I think what we'v
componenttext: Yes. I think the way -- and I'll just add to that. I mean, I think at the end of last year, we've talked about some initial percentage targets. I think at the end of last year, we were probably -- we were slightly ahead of those targets. I think what we've talked about though -- and again, we had a strong quarter this quarter. But on an ongoing basis, we've -- I said it and Bill said it before, I mean, we'd certainly like to get a couple of quarters under our belt before we think about doing anything differently there. And so that's really the way I would think about our progress. We're feeling good, we're in a good place, but let's see how this plays out.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, how would you describe -- if you could comment on the case volume trends at Brakes year-over-year in the U.K. market in particular? I mean, can you confirm if they were positive or negative?
componenttext: Okay. And finally, how would you describe -- if you could comment on the case volume trends at Brakes year-over-year in the U.K. market in particular? I mean, can you confirm if they were positive or negative?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we're -- we've got an international segment. We're going to give you some color on the components of that. I would tell you that their business softened through the calendar year even before Brexit. And I think it's more about just the uncertainty
componenttext: Again, we're -- we've got an international segment. We're going to give you some color on the components of that. I would tell you that their business softened through the calendar year even before Brexit. And I think it's more about just the uncertainty in that economy, whether it was leading up to Brexit or post-Brexit. And it's -- if you read all the different accounts, so far, it hasn't been as bad perhaps as people thought it might have been. And I think we're seeing that as well. On the other hand, there's still a lot of uncertainty here over the next 2 or 3 years. So I think they're -- as Tom said in his prepared remarks, I think they performed reasonably well given the environment.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JP Morgan.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of John Ivankoe with JP Morgan.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: One quick one and then one question, if I may. Firstly, there seems to be some confusion about what non-GAAP D&A should be for the business in '17 and maybe even '18. Bill, I think in the last question, you mentioned some technology write-off that you had
componenttext: One quick one and then one question, if I may. Firstly, there seems to be some confusion about what non-GAAP D&A should be for the business in '17 and maybe even '18. Bill, I think in the last question, you mentioned some technology write-off that you had done recently that may benefit that D&A line. But I hate to ask such a specific question because a lot of people are -- do have some really different estimates. Can you give us a little bit more specific help on that specific line?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so let me start with that, and then -- so I'll take a couple of things on that. So one of the things you'll see in our certain item reconciliation this quarter is that -- you will see this in our Q. Our D&A is up a bit for this quarter, and it's for
componenttext: Well, so let me start with that, and then -- so I'll take a couple of things on that. So one of the things you'll see in our certain item reconciliation this quarter is that -- you will see this in our Q. Our D&A is up a bit for this quarter, and it's for a couple of different reasons. Number one, as we talked about last year, we actually expected some -- due to the write-off of the SAP system, there was an acceleration of the amortization related to that. And so there is, again, say, roughly $30 million, I'd say, of the certain item related to that this year that's part of our D&A. There's also -- as a result of the Brakes deal, there is both additional depreciation and amortization as part of that. And so I think if you look at our overall D&A expense for this particular quarter relative to where we've been, those are really the 2 primary contributors on that line as it relates to this. What Bill is referring to as -- in his comment earlier, if you recall, at the time when we increased our target from $400 million to $500 million at, again, a while back, we had made a couple of comments as it related to that. Number one was the fact that a component of that difference was related to the fact that we -- with the changeover in our technology strategy that there would be some benefits once, again, the asset was fully written off. Again, there is accelerated amortization we'll be experiencing at the end of last year and through this year, but there’d be benefit of that starting in 2018. So I think that's really what Bill is relating to on that. And so, hopefully, that gives you some clarity on some of the comments and a little bit of the breakdown on that. But you should expect that accelerated amortization from that plus the Brakes to be present throughout the rest of this year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can confirm that was what I was alluding to.
componenttext: I can confirm that was what I was alluding to.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. And I think I did understand that. But I think if you look at Street estimates, you'll see the people have some pretty different estimates for D&A, like unusually different estimates for D&A in '17 and '18, and that's why I was wondering if you
componenttext: Yes. Okay. And I think I did understand that. But I think if you look at Street estimates, you'll see the people have some pretty different estimates for D&A, like unusually different estimates for D&A in '17 and '18, and that's why I was wondering if you were willing to just give a little bit more specific guidance on that one specific line.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean...
componenttext: Yes. I mean...

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think you guys need to adjust this quarter, go through a certain item schedule, work with Neil, and I think I would expect that we'll get more consistency there.
componenttext: Look, I think you guys need to adjust this quarter, go through a certain item schedule, work with Neil, and I think I would expect that we'll get more consistency there.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. We will do our best as always. And then, the next question, obviously, the restaurant industry, just speaking from an operator perspective, slower traffic, higher labor cost. I mean, it's one of the obvious things that a restaurant company does
componenttext: All right. We will do our best as always. And then, the next question, obviously, the restaurant industry, just speaking from an operator perspective, slower traffic, higher labor cost. I mean, it's one of the obvious things that a restaurant company does is come to their food supplier and try to get the lowest price as possible. I mean, are you seeing your restaurant customers may be asking even more from you than they have in the past, that even if they see your gross margin results and they ask you to give some of the gross margin back to them as they try to protect their own profitability?

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Tom. So I'd say, John, a couple of things. As we said earlier, it continues to be very competitive out there, whether it's a chain restaurant customer or a street customer for us. And I think the way we try to look at value we bring to those
componenttext: Well, this is Tom. So I'd say, John, a couple of things. As we said earlier, it continues to be very competitive out there, whether it's a chain restaurant customer or a street customer for us. And I think the way we try to look at value we bring to those customers is certainly beyond just price. We offer a wide range of, obviously, products and services to these folks. We believe we bring them value each and every day. We talked a little bit about Sysco Brand earlier, and Sysco Brand is a great example of where we're able to bring basically lower cost of goods to our customers and put them in a position where they can earn as much as they can from their offering. But it's well beyond just products and pricing. And so I'd say it's the whole portfolio of things we bring to them that's allowed us to be successful and certainly what we believe is the right strategy for us going forward, but it doesn't take away from the fact that it's competitive out there each and every day, and we just have to make sure that we're doing those right things in the market. We absolutely believe we need to be price competitive, and that's one of the components of what we focus on.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, John, just to reinforce that, this is happening in an environment of 2 points of deflation right now. So the customers, they're benefiting from the food cost deflation. What we're doing, what Tom addressed earlier with the revenue management
componenttext: And I think, John, just to reinforce that, this is happening in an environment of 2 points of deflation right now. So the customers, they're benefiting from the food cost deflation. What we're doing, what Tom addressed earlier with the revenue management is using a lot of tools to be more consistent, more targeted in our pricing, but we still need to compete, as he points out, every day for that business. And interestingly, to me, on the data that we see, to your point, while they're benefiting from deflation, they've got some labor pressures that had been out there for a while now, but the restaurant as a group continue to pass along about a 2-point increase to their customers and that has been incredibly consistent through every cycle that we've seen here. So I think, right now, they are managing it pretty well and the deflation is helping them. At some point, I guess, it could become more acute if we were to see the deflation reverse, but as I think Joel pointed out, we don't see that happening here, at least not in this calendar year.

headline: Sysco Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 07, 2016
